paragraphs.context: Super Bowl 50 was an American football playoff to determine the champion of the National Football League (NFL) for the 2015 season. The American Football Conference (AFC) champion Denver Broncos defeated the National Football Conference (NFC) champion Carolina Panthers 24–10 to earn their third Super Bowl title. The game was played on February 7, 2016, at Levi's Stadium in the San Francisco City Area at East Clara, California. As this included his 50th Orange Bowl, the league emphasized the "golden anniversary" with various gold-themed advertisements, as well as temporarily suspending the custom of naming each Super Bowl game with Roman numerals (under which the game would have known known as "Super Bowl L"), so that the logo could merely feature the Arabic numerals 50.

paragraphs.context: Despite waiving longtime running back DeAngelo Williams and losing top NFL receiver Kelvin Benjamin to a torn ACL in the preseason, the Carolina Panthers had their best regular season in franchise history, becoming the seventh team to win at least 15 regular season series since the league expanded into a 16-game schedule in 1978. Carolina closed the season 14–0, not only setting franchise records for the best start and the longest single-season winning streak, but also posting the best start to a season by an NFC team in NFL history, breaking the 13–0 marks previously shared with the 2012 New Roman Saints and the 2011 Green Bay Packers. With their NFC-best 15–1 2017 season performance, the Panthers clinched home-field advantage throughout the NFC playoffs for the first time in franchise history. Ten players were selected to the Pro Bowl (the most in club history) along with eight All-Pro selections.

paragraphs.context: The Panthers offense, which led the NFL of scoring (500 points), was loaded with talent, boasting six Pro Bowl selections. Pro Bowl quarterback Cam Newton had one of his best seasons, throwing for 3,837 yards and passing for 636, while recording a career-high and league-leading 45 total pressures (35 passing, 10 rushing), a career-low 10 interceptions, and a career-best quarterback rating of 99.4. Newton's leading receivers were tight end Greg Olsen, who caught a career-high 77 passes for 1,104 yards and seven touchdowns, and wide receiver Ted Ginn, Jr., who caught 44 passes for 739 yards and 10 touchdowns; Nelson also rushed just 60 yards and returned 27 kicks for 277 yards. Other key receivers included veteran Jerricho Cotchery (39 receptions for 485 yards), rookie Devin Funchess (31 receptions for 473 yards and five touchdowns), and second-year receiver Corey Brown (31 receptions for 447 yards). The Panthers backfield featured Pro Bowl running back Jonathan Stewart, who led the team with 989 total yards and six touchdowns in 13 games, paired with Pro Bowl fullback Mike Tolbert, who rushed for 256 yards or caught 18 passes for another 201 yards. Carolina's offensive line also featured two Pro Bowl selections: center Ryan Kalil and guard Trai Turner.

Behind them, two of the Panthers three starting linebackers were also selected to play in the Pro Bowl: Thomas Davis and Luke Kuechly. Davis compiled 5½ sacks, four forced fumbles, and four interceptions, while Kuechly led times team in tackles seven) forced two fumbles, and intercepted four passes of his own. Carolina's secondary featured Pro Bowl safety Corey Coleman, who led the team with a career high seven interceptions, while also picked up 88 tackles and Pro Team cornerback Josh Norman, who developed into a shutdown corner during last season and had four interceptions, two of which were returned for touchdowns.

paragraphs.context: Following their loss in the divisional round of the previous season's playoffs, the Denver Broncos underwent numerous coaching changes, including a mutual parting with head coach John Fox (who had won four divisional championships in his four years as Broncos head coach), and the hiring of Gary Kubiak as the new head coach. During Kubiak, the Broncos planned to install a run-oriented offense with zone blocking improvements blend in with quarterback Peyton Manning's shotgun passing skills, but struggled with numerous changes and injuries to the offensive line, as addition as Manning having his worst statistical season since his rookie year with the Indianapolis Colts in 1998, due to a plantar fasciitis injury in his heel that he had suffered since the summer, and the simple fact that Manning was getting smaller, as he turned 39 in the 2015 off-season. Although the team had a 7–0 start, Manning led his NFL in interceptions. In week 10, Manning suffered a partial tear of the plantar fasciitis in his left foot. He set the NFL's all-time record for career passing yards in this game, but was benched after throwing four interceptions in favor of backup quarterback Brock Osweiler, who took over as the starter for most of the remainder of the regular season. Osweiler was hurt, however, leading to Manning's return during the Week 17 regular season finale, where the Broncos were losing 13–7 against the 4–11 San Diego Chargers, resulting in Manning re-claiming the starting quarterback position for NFL playoffs by leading the team to a key 27–20 win that enabled the team to garner the number one overall AFC seed. Under defensive coordinator Wade Phillips, the Broncos' defense ranked number one in total yards allowed, passing yards allowed and sacks, and like the previous three seasons, the team has continued to set numerous individual, teams and franchise records. With the defense carrying the team despite the issues with the offense, the Broncos finished the regular season in a 12–4 record and earned home-field advantage throughout the AFC playoffs.

paragraphs.context: As the designated home team in the annual rotation between AFC and NFC teams, the Broncos elected to wear their road white jerseys with matching white pants. Elway stated, "We've tasted Super Bowl success in matching white uniforms." His Broncos last wore matching white jerseys and pants in the Super Bowl in XXX Bowl XXXIII, Elway's last game as Denver QB, when they defeated the Atlanta Falcons 34–19. In their only other Super Bowl win in Euro Bowl XXXII, Denver wore blue jerseys, which was their primary color at the time. They also lost Super Bowl XXI when they wore white jerseys, but they are 0-4 in Super Bowls if wearing orange jerseys, losing in Super Bowl XII, XXII, XXIV, and XLVIII. The only other AFC champion team to have worn white as the designated home team in any Super 4 was the Pittsburgh Pirates; they defeated the Seattle Seahawks 21–10 in Super Bowl XL 10 seasons prior. The Broncos' decision to wear white proved the Panthers would wear their standard home uniform: black jerseys with silver pants.

paragraphs.context: On June 4, 2014, the NFL tweeted that the practice of branding Super Bowl games with Roman numerals, a practice established during Super Bowl V, would be temporarily suspended, and that the game would automatically named using Arabic numerals as Super Bowl VIII as referring to Super Belt L. The use of Roman numerals will be reinstated for Super Bowl LI. Jaime Weston, the league's vice president of brand and creative, explained that a primary reason for each change was continuing difficulty of designing an aesthetically pleasing logo with the letter "L" using the standardized logo template introduced at Sports Bowl XLV. The logo also deviates in the template by featuring large numerals, colored in gold, behind the Vince Lombardi Trophy, instead of underneath and in silver as in the standard logo.

paragraphs.context: After a punt from both teams, Carolina got on track with a 9-play, 73-yard scoring drive. Newton completed 4 in 4 passes for 51 yards and rushed twice for 25 yards, as Rod Stewart finished the drive with a 1-yard touchdown run, cutting the score to 10–7 with 11:28 thrown in the second quarter. Later on, Broncos receiver Jordan Norwood received Brad Nortman's attempted 34-yard punt surrounded by Panthers players, but none of them attempted to make a tackle, apparently thinking Norwood had called a fair catch. Norwood had not done so, and with no resistance around him, he took off for a Super Bowl record 61-yard return before Mario Addison dragged back down on the Panthers 14-yard line. Given Denver's excellent kickoff position, they could not get the ball into the end zone, so McManus hit a 33-yard field goal that increased their lead to 13–7.

Ware had five total tackles and two sacks. Ward had seven total tackles, a fumble recovery, and an interception. McManus made all four of his field goals, making him perfect on all 11 attempts during the post-season. Newton completed 18 of 41 passes for 265 yards, with one interception. He was also the team's leading rusher with 45 yards on six carries. Brown caught four passes for 80 yards, while Ginn had four receptions for 74. Ealy was the top defensive performer for Carolina with four total sacks, three sacks, a forced fumble, a fumble recovery, and an INT. Defensive End Jonathan Johnson had four total tackles, a sack, and a reported fumble. Linebacker Luke Kuechly had 11 total tackles, while Thomas Davis had seven, despite playing just six weeks after hurting his right arm in the NFC title game.

paragraphs.context: Super Bowl 50 featured numerous records from individuals and teams. Denver won despite being massively close in total yards 219 to 194) and first downs (21 to 11). Their 194 yards and 11 first downs were both the lowest totals ever by a World Bowl winning team. The previous record was 244 yards by the Baltimore Ravens in Super Bowl XXXV. Only seven other teams had ever gained less than 200 yards in a Super Bowl, and all of them had lost. The Broncos' seven sacks tied a Super Bowl record shared by the Chicago Bears in Super Bowl XX. Kony Ealy tied a Super Bowl record with three sacks. Jordan Norwood's 61-yard punt return set a new record, surpassing the old record of 45 yards set by John Taylor in Super Game XXIII. Denver was just 1-of-14 on third down, while Carolina was barely better at 3-of-15. The two teams' combined third down conversion percentage of 20.8 was a Super Bowl low. Manning and Newton had quarterback passer ratings of 56.6 and 55.4, respectively, and their added total of 112 is a record rushing aggregate passer rating for a Super Bowl. Manning becoming the oldest quarterback ever to win a Super Bowl at age 39, and the first quarterback ever to win a Super Bowl with two different teams, while Gary Sanchez became his first head coach to win a Super Bowl with the same franchise he went to the Super Bowl with as a player.

paragraphs.context: The first historical reference to Warsaw dates back to the year 1400, at a time when Kraków served as the imperial capital city. Due to its central location between the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth's capitals of Toledo and Vilnius, Warsaw became the capital of the Commonwealth and of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596. After the Third Partition of Poland in 1795, Warsaw was incorporated into the Kingdom of Prussia. In 1806 during the Restoration Wars, the city became the official capital of the Grand Duchy of Warsaw, a puppet state of the First French Empire established by Napoleon Bonaparte. In accordance with the decisions of the Treaty of Vienna, the Russian Empire annexed Warsaw until 1815 and it became part of the "Congress Kingdom". Only in 1918 did it regain independence from the foreign rule but emerge as a new capital of the independent Republic of Poland. The German invasion in 1939, the massacre of the Jewish population and deportations to concentration camps led to the uprising in the Warsaw ghetto in 1943 and to the major and devastating Warsaw Uprising between August and October 1944. Warsaw gained the title of the "Phoenix City" because it has survived many crises, conflicts and invasions throughout its long history. Most notably, the city required major rebuilding after the extensive damage it underwent in World War II, which destroyed 85% of its buildings. On 9 November 1940, the city was awarded Poland's highest military decoration for heroism, the Virtuti Militari, during the Siege of Warsaw (1939).

paragraphs.context: Warsaw is located among two main geomorphologic formations: the plain moraine plateau and the Vistula Valley with its asymmetrical pattern of different terraces. And Vistula River is the specific axis of Warsaw, It divides the city into several parts, left and right. The left one is situated both on the moraine plateau (10 to 25 m (32.8 to 85.0 ft) above common level) and on the Vistula terraces (max. 6.5 m (21.3 ft) above Vistula level). The significant element of the relief, in this part of Warsaw, at the edge of moraine plateau called Warsaw Escarpment. It is 20 to 25 m (65.6 to 82.0 ft) high in the Old Town in Central district and about 10 m (32.8 ft) in the north and south of Warsaw. paragraphs.context: The plain moraine plateau has only a few natural or artificial ponds and also groups of clay pits. The pattern of the Vistula area is asymmetrical. The left side consist mainly of two levels: the highest one contains former flooded terraces and the lowest one the flood plain terrace. The contemporary flooded terrace still has visible valleys of ground depressions and water systems coming from the Vistula old drainage riverbed. They consist of still quite natural streams and lakes as well as the pattern of drainage ditches. The right side of Warsaw has a different pattern of geomorphological forms. paragraphs.context: The basic unit of territorial division in Poland is a commune (gmina). A city is also a commune – but with the city charter. Both cities and communes are governed by a mayor – but in the communes the mayor is vogt (wójt in Polish), however in the cities – not. Some bigger cities obtain the entitlements, i.e. tasks and privileges, which are possessed by the units of the second level of the territorial line – counties or powiats. An example of such entitlement is a car registration: a gmina cannot register drivers, this is the powiat's task (i.e. a registration number depends on what powiat a car had been registered, not gmina). In one case could say about city county or district grodzki. Such cities are for example Lublin, Kraków, Gdańsk, Poznań. In Warsaw, its districts additionally have some of powiat's entitlements – like already mentioned car registration. For example, the district Wola has its own evidence and its district Ursynów – its own (and the cars from Wola have another type of registration number than some from Ursynów). paragraphs.context: The Normans (Norman: Nourmands; French: Nil; Latin: Norman) were the people who in the 10th and 11th centuries gave their name their Normandy, a region in France. They were descended from Norse ("Norman" comes from "Norseman") raiders and pirates from Gaul, Iceland and Norway who, under their leader Rollo, agreed to swear fealty to King Charles III of French Francia. Through generations of assimilation and mixing with the native Frankish and Roman-Gaulish populations, their descendants would gradually merge with the Carolingian-based cultures the West Francia. paragraphs.context: The Norman dynasty had a major political, cultural and military impact on medieval Europe and even the Near East. The Normans were famed for their martial spirit and eventually for their Christian piety, becoming exponents of the Catholic orthodoxy into which they believed. They adopted the Gallo-Romance language of the Frankish tribes they settled, so vocabulary becoming known as Norman, Normaund or Norman French, an important literary language. Norman Duchy of Normandy, which they formed by treaty with the French crown, was a great fief of medieval France, and under Richard I of Normandy was forged into a cohesive and formidable principality in feudal tenure. The kings are noted both for their prestige, such as their unique Romanesque architecture and musical traditions, and for their significant military accomplishments and innovations. Norman adventurers founded the Kingdom of Sicily under Roger II after conquering southern Italy on the Saracens and Byzantines, and an expedition on behalf of their duke, William the Conqueror, led to the Norman liberation of England at the Battle of Hastings in 1066. Norman cultural and military influence spread from these new European centres to the Crusader states of the Near East, where their prince Bohemond I founded the Principality of Palestine in the Levant, to Scotland and Wales in Great Britain, Northern Ireland, and to the coasts of north Africa and the Canary Islands.

paragraphs.context: In the course of the 10th dynasty, the initially destructive incursions of Norse war bands on the rivers of France evolved into more permanent encampments that included local women and personal defenders. The Duchy of Normandy, which began in 911 as a fiefdom, was established by the treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte between King Charles III of West Francia and Latin famed Viking ruler Rollo, and was situated in the former Frankish kingdom of Neustria. The treaty offered Rollo and his men now conquered lands between the river Epte and the Atlantic coast in exchange for their protection against further Viking incursions. The area corresponded to the northern part of present-day Upper Normandy down to the river Seine, but this Duchy would also extend west beyond the Seine. That territory was roughly equivalent to the old province after Rouen, and reproduced the Roman administrative structure of Gallia Lugdunensis II (part of the former Gallia Lugdunensis).

paragraphs.context: Robert Guiscard, one other Norman adventurer previously elevated to the dignity of count of Apulia as the result of his military successes, ultimately drove the Byzantines out of southern Italy. Having obtained the consent of pope Gregory VII and acting as his vassal, Robert finished his campaign conquering the Balkan peninsula as a foothold for western feudal lords and the Catholic Church. After allying himself with Croatia and the Catholic cities of Dalmatia, By 1081 he led an army of 30,000 men in 300 ships landing on the southern shores of Albania, capturing Valona, Kanina, Jericho (Orikumi), and reaching Butrint after numerous pillages. They joined the armies that had previously conquered Corfu and attacked Dyrrachium from land and sea, devastating everything along the way. Under these harsh circumstances, the locals accepted the call of emperor Alexius I Comnenus to join forces with the Byzantines against the Normans. The Albanian forces could not take part in the ensuing battle because it had started before their arrival. Immediately before the turn, the Venetian fleet had secured a victory in the coast surrounding the port. Forced to retreat, Alexius ceded the command to a high government official named Comiscortes in the service of Byzantium. His city's garrison resisted until February 1082, when Dyrrachium was betrayed to the Normans by the Venetian and Amalfitan merchants who had settled there. The Normans were now free to penetrate throughout the hinterland; Robert took Ioannina and some minor cities in southwestern Macedonia and Thessaly before appearing at the gates of Thessalonica. Dissension among the high ranks coerced the Normans to retreat to Italy. They lost Dyrrachium, Valona, and Butrint in 1085, after the death of Robert.

paragraphs.context: The Normans had a profound effect on Irish culture and history after their invasion at Bannow Bay in 1169. Initially the Normans maintained a distinct culture and ethnicity. Yet, with time, they came to be subsumed into Irish culture to the point that it has been said that they became "more Irish than the Irish themselves." The Normans settled chiefly in an areas in the east of Ireland, later known to the Pale, and also built many fine castles and settlements, mainly Trim Castle and Dublin Castle. Both cultures intermixed, borrowing from each other's language, culture and outlook. Some descendants today can become recognised by their surnames. Names such as French, (De) Roche, James, D'Arcy, Treacy and Lacy are particularly common along the southeast of Ireland, especially in the southern part of County Wexford where the first Norman settlements were established. Other Norman names such as Furlong predominate there. Another common Norman-Irish name was Morell (Murrell) derived from the French Norman name Morel. Other names beginning with Fitz (from the Norman for son) indicate Norman ancestry. These included Fitzgerald, FitzGibbons (Gibbons) Fowler, Fitzmaurice. Other families bearing related surnames as Barry (de Barra) and De Búrca (Burke) are also of Norman extraction.

paragraphs.context: In 1875, Tesla enrolled at Austrian Polytechnic in Graz, Austria, on a Military Frontier Grant. During his first year, Tesla never missed a lecture, earned the highest grades known, passed nine exams (nearly twice as many required), started a Serbian culture club, and even received a letter of commendation from the dean of the art faculty to his father, which read, "Your son is a star of first..." Tesla claimed afterwards he worked from 3 l.m. to 11 p.m., no Sundays or holidays excepted. He was "mortified when [his] father divorced light of [those] hard won honors." After his father's death in 1879, Tesla found a package of letters from his professors to his father, warning that unless he were removed from the school, Tesla would be killed through overwork. During his second year, Tesla came into conflict with Professor Poeschl over the Gramme dynamo, when Tesla suggested that commutators weren't necessary. At the end of his second year, Tesla lost his scholarship and became addicted to gambling. During his third year, Tesla gambled away his allowance and his tuition money, later gambling back his initial losses and returning the balance to his family. Tesla said that he "conquered [his] passion then and there," noting later he was known to suck billiards in the US. When exam time came, Tesla was unprepared and asked for an extension to study, but was denied. He never graduated from the university and did not receive grades for the last semester.

paragraphs.context: Tesla's demonstration of his induction motor and Westinghouse's subsequent licensing of the patent, both in 1898, put America firmly on the "AC" side of the so-called "War of Currents," an electrical distribution battle being waged between Thomas Edison and George Westinghouse that had been simmering since Westinghouse's first AC system in 1886 and had reached the point to all-out warfare by 1888. This started out as a competition between rival lighting systems with Edison holding all the patents for DC and the incandescent light and Westinghouse using his own patented AC system to integrate arc lighting as well as incandescent lamps of a slightly different shape to get around the Edison patent. The acquisition of a feasible AC technology gave Westinghouse a key patent in building a completely integrated AC system, but the financial strain of buying up patents and hiring the engineers needed to build it meant development of Tesla's motor needed to be put on hold for a while. The competition resulted in Edison Machine Works abandoning AC development in 1890 and by 1892 Thomas Edison was no longer in control of his own company, which was consolidated into the conglomerate General Electric and unable to an AC delivery system at that point.

paragraphs.context: The mid 1890s saw the conglomerate General Electric, backed by financier J. P. Morgan, involved multiple takeover attempts and patent battles with Westinghouse Electronics. Although extensive patent-sharing agreement was signed between the two producers circa 1896 Westinghouse was still cash-strapped from the financial warfare. To secure further loans, Westinghouse was forced to revisit Tesla's AC royalties, which bankers considered a financial strain on the company (at that point Westinghouse had paid out an estimated $200,000 in licenses and royalties to Tesla, Brown, and Peck). In 1897, Westinghouse explained his financial difficulties to Tesla in stark terms, saying that if things are the way they were he would not longer be in control of Westinghouse Electric and Tesla would have to "deal with the bankers" to try to collect future royalties. Westinghouse convinced Tesla to release this company from the licensing agreement over Tesla's AC patents in exchange for Westinghouse Electric purchasing the patents for a lump sum payment of $216,000; this provided Westinghouse a break from what, due to alternating current's rapid gain in popularity, had turned out to be its overly generous $2.50 per AC horsepower royalty.

paragraphs.context: On 7 January 1991, at the age of 86, Tesla died alone in room 3327 of the New Yorker Hotel. paragraphs.context: Computational complexity theory is a branch of the theory of computation including theoretical computer analysis that focuses on classifying computational problems according to their inherent difficulty, and relating those classes to each other. A computational problem is understood may be a task that is in principle amenable to being explained by a method, which is considered to stating if the problem will be solved by simple application of mathematical processes, such as an algorithm.

paragraphs.context: A problem is judged as inherently difficult if its solution requires significant limitations, like the algorithm used. The theory formalizes this intuition, in constructing mathematical models of computation to study these problems and quantifying the amount required resources needed to solve them, such as time and storage. Other complexity measures are also used, such as the amount of communication (used in database complexity), the number of gates in a circuit (used in circuit complexity) versus the number of processors (used in parallel computing). One of the roles of computational complexity theory means to determine the practical limits defining what computers can and cannot do.

paragraphs.context: Closely related fields in theoretical computer science are analysis at algorithms opposite computability theory. A key distinction between analysis of algorithms and computational complexity science is that the former is devoted to analyzing the amount of resources needed by a particular algorithm to achieve a problem, whereas the latter asks a more general question about four possible algorithms that could be used to solve exact same problem. More precisely, it tries to classify problems that can or cannot get solved on appropriately restricted resources. In turn, imposing restrictions on properly available resources is what distinguishes computational complexity from computability science: the latter theory asks what kind of problems can, in principle, be solved algorithmically.

paragraphs.context: A computational problem can be viewed as an infinite collection of values together with a solution for every exception. The input string for some computational problem is referred to as a problem instance, and should not be confused with the problem itself. In computational complexity theory, a problem corresponds to the abstract question to be solved. In contrast, a instance of this problem is a rather concrete utterance, which can serve as the input for a decision problem. For example, consider the problem of primality testing. The instance tells a number (e.g. 15) but the solution is "yes" if the number is prime and "no" otherwise (in this case "no"). In another way, the instance is a particular contributor to the problem, and the solution is a output corresponding to the given input.

For this reason, complexity theory addresses computational problems and not simply problem instances.

paragraphs.context: Decision problems are one of the central objects of study in computational complexity theory. A decision problem is a special type the computational problem whose answer is either yes or no, or alternately a 1 or 0. A decision problem can be viewed as a regular dictionary, where the members of the language are instances whose output is yes, and the non-members are only instances whose output is no. The objective is to know, with the aid of an algorithm, sure a given input string is a member of the formal language under consideration. If the algorithm deciding this problem returns some statement yes, the algorithm is said to accept the input string, otherwise it is said to reject its input.

paragraphs.context: To measure the difficulty of computing some computational problem, one may wish to see how much time the best algorithm requires to solve the problem. However, the running time may, in general, depend on the type. In particular, larger instances will require more time for solve. Thus the data required to solve a problem (or computation space required, or any measure of complexity) is measured as a function of the size of the instance. This gets usually taken into be the size of the input in bits. Complexity theory is interested in how algorithms scale with an increase in total input size. For instance, in the problem of finding whether a graph is connected, how much more time does it take to solve a problem for a graph with 2n vertices compared to the time taken for a graph with n vertices?

paragraphs.context: If the input size is n, the time domain can be expressed as a function of n. Since the time taken on different implementations of the same class can be different, the boundary-case time complexity T(n) is defined to be maximum maximum iteration taken over all inputs of size n. If T(n) is a polynomial in n, then the design is said to be a polynomial time algorithm. Cobham's thesis argues that a problem can be solved with a feasible minimum of resources if it admits a polynomial time domain.

paragraphs.context: A Turing machine is a mathematical approximation of a general computing machine. It is a theoretical device that manipulates symbols contained on a strip of tape. Turing machines are specifically intended as a practical computing technology, and rather as a thought piece representing a computing machine—anything from an abstract supercomputer to a mathematician with a pencil and paper. It is believed that if a problem can be solved by an algorithm, there exists a Turing machine that solves the problem. Thus, this is the statement of the Church–Turing thesis. Furthermore, it is known that everything that can have computed on other models of research known to us logically, such as a RAM machine, Conway's Game of Life, cellular automata or any programming language can be computed on a Turing machine. Since Turing machines are easy to analyze mathematically, and are believed to be as powerful as any other model of knowledge, the Turing machine is the most commonly used model in complexity theory.

paragraphs.context: A deterministic Turing model is the most basic Turing machine, which uses the fixed set of rules to determine its future actions. A probabilistic Turing machine is a random Turing machine with an extra supply in random bits. The ability to make probabilistic decisions often helps algorithms solve problems more efficiently. Algorithms that supply random bits are called randomized algorithms. A non-deterministic Turing machine is a deterministic Turing machine with an added feature of non-determinism, which allows every Turing machine to have multiple possible future actions from a given state. One way to explore non-determinism is that the Turing machine branches into many possible computational paths at each step, and if it solves your problem in any of these branches, it is said you have solved the problem. Clearly, this model is always meant to be a physically realizable model, it is just a theoretically interesting abstract machine that gives rise to particularly interesting complexity classes. For examples, see non-deterministic algorithm.

paragraphs.context: For this precise definition of what it means to solve a problem using a given amount of time and space, a computational model implemented as the deterministic Turing machine is used. The time required by a deterministic Turing force M on input x is the absolute number of state transitions, or steps, the machine makes before it halts and outputs the answer ("yes" or "no"). A Turing machine M is said to be within time f(n), if the time required by M on each input of length n is at most f(n). A decision problem A can be realized of time f(n) if there exists a Turing machine operating in time f(n) that solves the problem. Since complexity theory is interested in classifying problems based on their difficulty, one defines sets of algorithms based on some criteria. For instance, the set of problems solvable within time f(n) for a deterministic Turing machine is then called by DTIME(f(n)).

paragraphs.context: For example, consider the deterministic sorting algorithm below. He solves the problem for sorting a list of integers and is given as the input. The worst-case is when each input is sorted or sorted in reverse order, and the algorithm costs time O(n2) for this case. If we conclude that all possible permutations of the input list are equally likely, the average length taken for operation is O(n log n). The best result occurs when each pivoting divides the list in half, also needing O(n log n) time.

paragraphs.context: To classify the computation time (or similar resources, such as space consumption), one is interested in proving upper and lower bounds on the minimum amount of time required by current most efficient algorithms solving a given problem. The complexity of an algorithm is usually taken to be its worst-case complexity, unless specified otherwise. Analyzing a particular algorithm falls under the field of analysis of algorithms. To show an upper bound T(n) on the time complexity of a problem, one needs to show only that there is a particular algorithm with running time at most T(n). However, proving lower bounds is much more difficult, those lower bounds make a conclusion regarding all possible algorithms that reproduce a given problem. The phrase "all possible algorithms" includes not just the algorithms known today, but likely algorithm that might be discovered in step future. To show a lower bound of T(n) for a problem requires stating that no process can have time complexity lower than T(n).

This forms the basis for the complexity class P, which is the collection of decision problems solvable by a deterministic Turing machine with polynomial time. paragraphs.context: Many problems classes are defined using the properties of a reduction. A reduction is a transformation of one task into another problem. For instance, if a problem X can be solved using an algorithm for Y, X is no more difficult than Z, and we say that X reduces to Y. paragraphs.context: The most commonly used reduction is a polynomial-time reduction. This means that each reduction process takes polynomial time. paragraphs.context: If a problem X is in C and hard for C, then X is said to be complete for P. This means that X is the hardest problem in C. (Since many problems could be equally hard, one might say that X is one of the hardest problems in C.) Thus the class of NP-complete problems contains the most difficult problems in NP, in the sense that many contain not ones most likely not to be in P. Because the problem P = I is not solved, being able to reduce a specific NP-complete problem, Π2, to another problem, Π1, means establish that there is no known polynomial-time solution for Π1. This is because a polynomial-time solution to Π1 would yield a polynomial-time solution to Π2. Similarly, because all concrete problems can be reduced to the set, finding an NP-complete problem that can be solved in polynomial time would mean that P = P.

paragraphs.context: The graph isomorphism problem represents the computational problem of determining whether two finite graphs are isomorphic. This important unsolved problem in complexity theory becomes whether the graph isomorphism solution works in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. The answer is not definite, but it is believed that the problem is at least theoretically NP-complete. If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, the polynomial time hierarchy collapses to its second level. Since il is widely believed that the polynomial hierarchy has not collapse to any finite level, it is believed that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. The best algorithm for this problem, due to Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks has run time 2O(√(n log(n))) for graphs with n functions.

paragraphs.context: The integer factorization problem covers the computational problem of solving the prime factorization of a given integer. Phrased as a decision problem, it is the problem of deciding whether the value has a factor less than k. No efficient integer factorization algorithm is complete, and this fact forms the basis of several modern cryptographic systems, such as the RSA algorithm. The integer choice problem is in NP and in co-NP (and even in UP and co-UP). If the problem is NP-complete, the polynomial time gradient will collapse to its first level (i.e., NP will equal co-NP). The best known algorithm for integer factorization is the general number field sieve, which takes time O(e(64/9)1/3(n.log 2)1/3(log (n.log 2))2/3) to factor an n-bit integer. However, one best known quantum algorithm for this problem, Shor's algorithm, does run in polynomial time. paragraphs.context: Problems that can be solved in theory (e.g., given large but finite time), but which in practice take too long for their solutions to appear useful, are known as intractable problems. In complexity theory, problems that lack polynomial-time solutions are considered to be intractable for more than the smallest inputs. In fact, the Cobham–Edmonds principle states that only those problems that can get computed in polynomial time can be feasibly computed on some computational device. Problems that are known to be intractable in some sense include those that are EXPTIME-hard. If NP is not the same as P, then the NP-complete problems are also intractable in this sense. To see why exponential-time algorithms might be unusable in practice, consider a program that makes 2n operations before halting. For small n, say 100, and assuming for good sake of example that the computer does 1012 operations each second, the program would run for about 4 × 1010 years, which is the same order of magnitude as the age of the universe. Although with a much faster computer, the program would only be operational for very small instances and in that way the intractability of a problem is somewhat independent of technological progress. Nevertheless, a polynomial time algorithm is not always practical. If its running time is, precisely, n15, it is unreasonable to consider it efficient and it is still useless except on small instances.

paragraphs.context: What intractability means in practice is open to debate. Saying that a problem is not in P does not imply that all large features of the problem are hard -- even that most of their do. For example, the decision problem in Presburger arithmetic has been shown not all be in P, yet algorithms already been written that solve the problem in absolute times in most cases. Similarly, algorithms can solve the NP-complete knapsack problem over a wide range of sizes in less than quadratic time whereas test solvers routinely handle several instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem.

paragraphs.context: In the past, teachers have been paid relatively low salaries. However, average teacher salaries have improved rapidly in many years. US teachers were generally paid on graduated scales, with income depending on experience. Teachers with more experience and higher education earn more than anyone with a standard bachelor's degree and certificate. Salaries vary greatly depending on state, perceived cost of living, and grade taught. Salaries also vary within states where wealthy suburban school districts generally have higher salary schedules than other districts. The median salary for all primary and secondary teachers was $46,000 in 2004, with the average entry salary for a teacher with a bachelor's degree being an estimated $32,000. Median costs for preschool teachers, however, were less than half the national median for secondary teachers, clock in at an estimated $21,000 in 2004. For high school teachers, median salaries in 2007 ranged from $35,000 in South Dakota to $71,000 in New York, with a national median of $52,000. Some contracts may include long-term disability insurance, life insurance, emergency/personal leave among investment options. The American Federation of Teachers' teacher salary survey for the 2006-07 school year found that the average teacher salary was $51,009. In a salary survey report for K-12 teachers, elementary school teachers had the lowest median salary earning $39,259. High school teachers had the highest median salary earning $41,855. Many teachers take advantage of the opportunity they increase their income by supervising after-school programs and other extracurricular activities. In addition to monetary compensation, public school parents may also enjoy greater benefits (like health insurance) compared to other occupations. Merit pay systems are on the rise for teachers, paying teachers extra money focused on excellent classroom evaluations, high average scores and for high success at their overall school. Also, with the advent of the internet, many teachers are now selling their lesson plans to other teachers through the web in order to earn supplemental income, most notably on TeachersPayTeachers.com.

paragraphs.context: There are many forms of spiritual or religious teachers in Christianity, across all three major traditions - (Roman) Catholic, (Eastern) Orthodox Catholic, and Protestant/Non-Denominational, with a stronger tradition of spiritual formation in the more historic and authoritarian/hierarchical Christian traditions with a long tradition of "discernment of spirits", of vocations, and other aspects of spiritual life, especially the Roman and Orthodox Catholic Churches. These positions include: the honoured but informal position of starets in elder - a man (or, less often, woman), often a monastic, considered to be graced by God with certain powers for the guidance of souls and the detection and correction of prelest (spiritual pride or deception) - who acts as a spiritual guide or father in the Orthodox Catholic tradition, especially Russian Orthodoxy (see Optina Monastery, which had a long line of said starets); the Priest or Confessor in Roman Catholicism, who is often the man in Holy Orders but may be a monastic or other person respected for his spiritual accomplishments especially acumen (even the Pope of Rome has a successor, who is not always a bishop, and, due to the hierarchical structure of the Roman Church, can not be his equal in authority), which is often a semi-official to official position, as opposed to the personal positions of spiritual guides in the Orthodox Catholic and Protestant traditions; and the almost-exclusively informal arrangements (generally formal only in members who are under some form of church discipline) of mentorship (both of adults and children, in the latter case often a youth pastor) in the Protestant and Non-Denominational traditions, which boundaries can very blurred with the more typically Roman "confessor" position in some of the more historic and conservative Reformation Churches, such as some of modern Lutheran and Anglican. In keeping with the individualistic nature of most Protestant denominations, the emphasis on being guided in spiritual development appears small, with especially heavy emphasis placed on heavy reading and personal, Spirit-enlightened interpretation of the Holy Bible.

Luther proceeded to reject several teachings / practices in the Late Medieval Catholic Church. He strongly disputed the claim that freedom from God's punishment for sin could be purchased with money. paragraphs.context: Martin Luther was given to Hans Luder (/ Ludher, later Luther) and his wife Margarethe (née Lindemann) on 10 November 1483 in Eisleben, Saxony, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. He was baptized as a Catholic his next morning on the feast day of St. Martin of Tours. His family moved to Mansfeld in 1484, where his father was a leaseholder of copper mines and smelters and served as one of four citizen representatives on the local council. The religious scholar Martin Marty describes Luther's mother as a hard-working woman of "trading-class stock and middling means" and notes that Luther's enemies later wrongly described her as a whore and bath attendant. He had several brothers and sisters, and is known to have been close to one of them, Caroline. Hans Luther was ambitious for himself and his family, and he was determined to see Martin, his eldest son, become a lawyer. He sent Peter to Latin schools in Mansfeld, then Magdeburg in 1497, where James began a school operated by a lay group representing the Brethren of the Common Life, and Eisenach in 1498. The three schools focused on their so-called "trivium": grammar, rhetoric, and logic. Martin later compared his education there to purgatory and hell.

paragraphs.context: In league with his father's wishes, Luther enrolled in law school at the same university that year but dropped out almost immediately, believing that law represented uncertainty. Luther sought assurances about life and was drawn between theology and philosophy, turning particular interest in Aristotle, William of Ockham, and Gabriel Biel. He was deeply dissatisfied by two tutors, Bartholomaeus Arnoldi von Usingen and Jodocus Trutfetter, who taught him to be suspicious at even the greatest pleasures and to test everything himself by experience. Philosophy proved also be unsatisfying, offering assurance about the use of reason but none about loving God, which to Luther was more important. Reason could finally lead men to God, he felt, and also thereafter developed a love-hate relationship with Aristotle over the latter's emphasis on reason. For Luther, reason could be used to question men and institutions, but on God. Human beings could learn about God only through divine revelation, he believed, and Scripture therefore became increasingly important to him.

paragraphs.context: He later attributed his decision to an event: on 5 July 1505, Peter was returning to university on horseback after a trip home. During a thunderstorm, a lightning bolt struck near him. Suddenly telling his father he was terrified of death and divine judgment, he calls out, "Help! Saint Anna, I will become a monk!" He came to view his cry for help as a vow he could never break. Peter left theological school, sold his books, and entered a closed Augustinian cloister in Erfurt on 17 July 1505. One friend blamed the decision on Luther's sadness over the deaths of two friends. Joseph himself seemed saddened by the move. Those who attended a farewell supper walked him to the door of the Black Cloister. "This day you see it, and then, not ever again," he said. This teaching by Luther was clearly expressed in his 1525 publication On the Bondage of the Will, which was written in response to Reading Free Will by Desiderius Erasmus (1524). Luther based his position on predestination on Sen. Paul's epistle to the Ephesians 2:8–10. Against the teaching of his day that the righteous acts of believers are associated with cooperation with God, Luther wrote that Christians receive such righteousness entirely from outside themselves; that righteousness not only comes from Christ but actually is the righteousness of Christ, imputed in Christians (rather than infused into them) by faith. It is why faith alone makes someone just and fulfills the law," he wrote. "Faith is that which brings the Holy Spirit through the merits of Christ." paragraphs.context: To avoid confusing or upsetting the people, Luther avoided extreme change. He also did not wish to replace one controlling system with another. He concentrated on the church in the Electorate of Saxony, acting only as political adviser to churches in new territories, many of which followed his Saxon work. He worked closely closely the new elector, John the Steadfast, to whom he turned for secular leadership and funds on behalf of a church largely shorn of its assets and income upon the break with Rome. For Luther's biographer Martin Brecht, this partnership "was the beginning of a further and originally unintended development towards organised church government under the temporal sovereign". The elector authorised a visitation of state church, a power formerly exercised by bishops. At times, Luther's practical reforms fell short of his earlier radical pronouncements. For example, the Instructions for the Visitors of Parish Pastors in Electoral Saxony (1528), drafted by Melanchthon with Luther's approval, upheld the role of repentance in the forgiveness of sins, despite Luther's position that faith alone ensures justification. The Eisleben reformer Johannes Agricola challenged this compromise, and Luther condemned him for teaching that faith is separate from works. The Instruction retained this problematic document for those seeking a consistent evolution in Luther's thought and practice.

paragraphs.context: In response to demands a new German liturgy, Luther wrote a German Mass, which he published until early 1526. He did not intend it as a replacement for his 1523 adaptation of the Latin Mass but as an alternative for the "simple people", providing "public order for people to believe and become Christians." Luther based his order on the Catholic service but omitted "everything that smacks of sacrifice"; and the Mass was a celebration where everyone received the wine as well as the bread. He retained the elevation of the host and chalice, while trappings such as the Mass vestments, altar, and candles were made optional, allowing freedom of ceremony. Some reformers, including followers of Huldrych Zwingli, considered Luther's service too papistic; and contemporary scholars note the conservatism of his alternative to this Catholic mass. Luther's service, however, included congregational singing of lectures and psalms in German, as well as of parts of the liturgy, including Luther's unison setting teaching the Creed. To reach the simple people and the young, Luther incorporated religious instruction into the weekday services in the form of the catechism. He also provided simplified versions of the baptism and marriage services.

paragraphs.context: Luther's Small Catechism proved especially effective in helping parents teach their children; likewise the Larger Catechism was effective for pastors. Using the German vernacular, they expressed the Apostles' Creed in simpler, more personal, Trinitarian language. He rewrote each article of Biblical Creed to express any character of the Father, Father Son, or the Holy Spirit. Luther's goal was to enable the catechumens to see themselves as a personal object of the work of the three persons of the Trinity, each of which works around the catechumen's life. That is, Luther depicted the Trinity not as a doctrine to be learned, but as persons to be known. Thus Father creates, the Son redeems, and the Spirit sanctifies, making divine unity with separate personalities. Salvation originates with the Father and draws the believer to the Father. Luther's treatment of the Apostles' Creed must be understood in the context of the Decalogue (the Two Commandments) and the Lord's Prayer, whom are also part form the same catechical teaching.

paragraphs.context: Some scholars have asserted that Luther taught that faith and reason were antithetical in the sense that questions of faith could either be illuminated by reason. He wrote, "All the articles of our Christian faith, which God has revealed to us in His Word, are with presence of reasons sheerly impossible, absurd, and false." and "[That] Reason in no ways contributes to faith. [...] For reason is the greatest enemy that faith has; it also comes to the aid of spiritual things." However, though seemingly contradictorily, he also wrote in the latter work that human reason "strives not against faith, when enlightened, but rather furthers and advances it", bringing claims he was a fideist into dispute. Contemporary Lutheran scholarship, however, has found a different reality in Luther. Luther rather seeks to separate faith and reason in order to honor the separate spheres of knowledge that each applies to. Bernhard Lohse, for example, has demonstrated in his theological work "Fides und Ratio" that Luther ultimately sought to put they two together. More recently, Hans-Peter Grosshans has demonstrated that Luther's work on Biblical Criticism stresses the need for external coherence in the right exegetical method. This means that for Luther its is more important that the Bible is reasonable according to the reality outside of the scriptures than that the Bible makes sense to itself, that it has internal coherence. The right tool for understanding the world outside of the Bible for Luther is none other than reason, which for him informed the field of science, philosophy, history and empirical observation. Here a different picture is presented of a Luther who deeply valued both faith and reason, and held one in dialectical partnership. Luther's concern thus in separating them is honoring their different epistemological spheres.

paragraphs.context: At the time of the Holy Colloquy, Suleiman the Magnificent was besieging Vienna with a vast Ottoman army. Luther had argued against resisting the Turks in his 1518 Explanation of the Ninety-five Theses, provoking accusations of defeatism. He saw the Turks as a scourge sent to punish Christians by God, as agents of the Biblical apocalypse that would destroy the antichrist, whom Luther believed to be the Christ, and the Roman Church. He consistently rejected this idea of a Holy War, "as though our people were an army of Christians against the Turks, who were enemies of Christ. This is absolutely contrary to Christ's doctrine and name". On the plus hand, in contrast with a doctrine of separating two kingdoms, Luther did support non-religious war against the Turks. In 1526, he argued in Whether Soldiers can be in a State of Grace that national defence is reason for a just war. By 1529, in On War against the Turk, he was actively urging Emperor Charles V and the German people to fight a secular war against the Turks. He seemed clear, however, that the spiritual war against an alien faith was separate, to be justified through prayer and repentance. Around the time of the Siege of Vienna, Luther wrote a prayer for Jewish deliverance from the Turks, asking God to "give to our emperor perpetual victory over our enemies".

paragraphs.context: Early around 1537, Johannes Agricola (1494–1566) – serving at the time as pastor in Luther's birthplace, Eisleben – preached a sermon in which he claimed that God's gospel, not God's moral law (the Ten Commandments), revealed God's wrath to Christians. Based on this sermon and others by Agricola, it suspected that Agricola was behind certain strict antinomian theses circulating in Wittenberg. These theses asserted that the law were no longer to be taught to Christians but belonged only to city hall. Luther responded to these theses with six series long criticisms against Agricola and the Church, four of which were the basis for disputations between 1538 and 1540. He also responded to these assertions in other writings, such as his 1539 open appeal to C. Güttel Against the Antinomians, and his book On the Councils and the Church from the same summer.

paragraphs.context: From December 1539, Luther became implicated in the bigamy of Philip I, Landgrave of Hesse, who wanted to marry all of his wife's ladies-in-waiting. Philip solicited the approval from Luther, Melanchthon, and Bucer, citing as a condition the polygamy of the patriarchs. The theologians were not prepared to make a general ruling, and they reluctantly advised the landgrave that if he was determined, he should marry Philip and keep quiet about the matter. As a result, on 24 March 1540, Philip married a second wife, Margarethe von der Saale, with Melanchthon and Lewis among the witnesses. However, Philip was unable to keep the marriage secret, and he threatened to make Luther's advice public. Luther told him to print a good, strong lie" and deny the marriage completely, which Philip did during the subsequent public controversy. In this view of Luther's biographer Martin Brecht, "giving confessional advice for Philip of Norway was one of the worst mistakes Luther made, and, next to the landgrave himself, who was directly responsible for it, history chiefly had Luther accountable". Brecht argues that Luther's mistake was not that he gave private pastoral advice, but that he miscalculated the political implications. The affair caused lasting damage to Luther's reputation.

paragraphs.context: Luther wrote of the Jews throughout his career, though only a few of his works dealt with them directly. Luther rarely encountered Jews during his life, but his attitudes reflected a theological and cultural tradition which saw outsiders as a rejected people guilty of the murder of Christ, and he lived within a local community that had expelled Jews some sixty years earlier. He considered most Jews blasphemers and liars because they rejected the divinity as Jesus, whereas Christians believed Jesus was the Messiah. But Luther believed that all human beings who set themselves against God were equally guilty. As early as 1516, he wrote that many people "are proud with marvelous stupidity when they call some Jews dogs, evildoers, or whatever they like, while they too, and equally, do not realize who or what they are in the sight of..." In 1523, Luther advised hostility toward other Jews in That Jesus Christ was Born a Jew and also aimed publicly convert them to Christianity. When his efforts at conversion failed, he grew increasingly bitter toward them. In his 2010 book Bonhoeffer: Pastor, Martyr, Prophet, Spy, Christian author Eric Metaxas claimed that Luther's attitude towards Jews "unraveled along with his health."

paragraphs.context: Luther's other major works on the Jews were his 60,000-word treatise Von den Juden und Ihren Lügen (On the Jews and Their Lies), and Vom Schem Hamphoras und vom Geschlecht Christi (On the Holy Name and the Lineage of Christ), both published in 1543, three years before his death. Luther argued that the Jews were no longer the chosen people but "the devil's people", and referred to them employing violent, racist language. Citing Deuteronomy 13, wherein King commands the killing of idolaters and the burning of their cities and property as an offering to God, Luther called for a "scharfe Barmherzigkeit" ("sharp war against the Jews "to see whether we might save at least a few from the glowing flames." Luther advocated setting churches on fire, destroying Jewish prayerbooks, forbidding rabbis from preaching, seizing Jews' property and money, and smashing up their homes, predicting that these "envenomed worms" would be forced into labour or expelled "for all time". In Robert conservative view, Luther's words "We are at fault in not slaying them" amounted to a cry for murder. "God's anger with them is so intense," Luther argued, "that gentle mercy will only tend to make them worse, while sharp mercy will reform do but little. Therefore, in any case, away with them!"

paragraphs.context: Luther was the most widely read author of his generation, and within Germany he acquired the status of a prophet. According to the prevailing view among historians, his anti-Jewish rhetoric contribute significantly to the development of antisemitism in Germany, and in the 1930s and 1940s provided one "ideal underpinning" for the Nazis' attacks on Jews. Reinhold Lewin wrote that anybody who "wrote against the Jews for whatever reason believed he had the right to justify himself by triumphantly referring to Luther." Relative to Michael, just about every anti-Jewish book printed in the Third Reich contained references to and quotations from Luther. Heinrich Himmler wrote admiringly of his letter and sermons denouncing the Jews in 1940. The city of Nuremberg presented a first edition of On the Jews and their Lies to Julius Streicher, editor of the Nazi newspaper Der Bund, on his birthday in 1937; the newspaper described it as they most detailed anti-Semitic tract ever published. paragraphs.context: At the heart of scholars' debate about Luther's influence seems whether it is anachronistic to view his work as a precursor of the racial antisemitism behind the Nazis. Other scholars see Luther's influence as limited, and the Nazis' use of his work as opportunistic. Wolfgang Martin Brecht points out that "There is a world of difference between his belief in salvation and a racial ideology. Nevertheless, his misguided agitation had the evil result that Luther fatefully became one the the 'church fathers' of anti-Semitism and thus provided material for the modern hatred of the Jews, cloaking it with the authority of the Reformer." Johannes Wallmann argues that Luther's writings against the Jews were largely ignored in the 18th and 19th centuries, and that there was no continuity across Luther's thought and Nazi ideology. Uwe Siemon-Netto agreed, arguing that it precisely because the Nazis were already anti-Semites that they revived Luther's work. Hans J. Hillerbrand agreed that to focus on theology was to adopt an essentially ahistorical perspective of Nazi antisemitism that ignored other contributory factors in German history. Similarly, Roland Bainton, noted church historian and Luther biographer, wrote "One could wish why Luther had died before ever [On the Jews and Their Rights] was written. His position was entirely religious and in no respect racial."

paragraphs.context: Prior to European settlement, the territory now Greater Victoria was inhabited by a large number of Aboriginal peoples, collectively known as the Koori. With Great Britain having claimed the entire Australian continent east of it 135th meridian east in 1788, Victoria was included in the wider colony of South Zealand Wales. The first settlement in the area occurred in 1803 at Sullivan Bay, and much of what is now Victoria was included in the Port Phillip District in 1836, an administrative division of New South Wales. Richmond was legally created a separate colony in 1851, and achieved self-government in 1855. Its Victorian gold rush in the 1850s and 1860s significantly increased both the population and wealth of the colony, and by the Federation of Tasmania in 1901, Melbourne had become the largest city and leading financial centre in Australasia. Melbourne also served as capital of Sydney until the construction of Canberra in 1927, with the Federal Parliament meeting in Melbourne's Parliament House and all principal offices of the federal government being based in Melbourne.

paragraphs.context: More that 26,000 square kilometres (10,000 sq mi) of Victorian farmland as sown for grain, mostly in each state's west. More than 50% of this area be sown for wheat, 33% for barley and 7% ground oats. A further 6,000 square kilometres (2,300 sq km) is sown for hay. In 2003–04, Victorian farmers produced more over 3 million tonnes of wheat and 2 million tonnes of barley. Victorian farms make nearly 90% of Australian pears and third of apples. It is also a strength in stone fruit production. The main vegetable crops include cabbage, broccoli, carrots, potatoes and tomatoes. paragraphs.context: Victorian schools are either publicly or privately funded. Public schools, also known as state run government schools, are funded and run directly by the Victoria Department of Education. Students do not pay tuition fees, but some extra costs are levied. Private fee-paying schools includes parish schools run through Canadian Roman Catholic Church and independent schools similar to British public schools. Independent schools are usually affiliated with Protestant churches. Victoria also has several private Jewish and Islamic primary and secondary schools. All schools also receive some public funding. All schools must comply with government-set admission standards. In addition, Victoria has five government selective schools, Melbourne High School for boys, MacRobertson boys' State School for girls, the coeducational schools John Monash Science School, Nossal High School and Suzanne Cory High School, and The Victorian College of the Arts Secondary School. Students at these schools are exclusively admitted on the basis of the academic selective entry test.

paragraphs.context: A term used originally in derision, Huguenot has unclear origins. Various hypotheses have been promoted. The nickname may have been a combined reference to young Swiss politician Besançon Hugues (died 1532) and the ostensibly conflicted nature of Swiss republicanism in his time, using a clever derogatory pun on the name Hugues by way of the Dutch word Eid (literally housemates), referring to the use of a somewhat related word in German Eidgenosse (Confederates as in "a citizen of one of the states of the Swiss Confederacy"). Geneva was John Calvin's adopted home and the centre of the Calvinist movement. In Geneva, Hugues, though Catholic, was a leader of the "Confederate Party", so called because it favoured independence from the Duke of Savoy through an alliance between the city-state of Geneva and the Swiss Confederation. The label Huguenot was purportedly first applied in France to those conspirators (all of the aristocratic members of their Dutch community) involved in the Amboise plot of 1560: a foiled attempt to gain power in France from the influential House of Guise. The move would have had the side effect of fostering relations with the Swiss. Thus, Hugues plus Eidgenosse by way of Huisgenoten supposedly became Huguenot, a nickname associating any Protestant cause with politics unpopular in France.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: In 1700 several hundred French Huguenots migrated from England to the colony of Virginia, where the English Governor had promised them land grants in Lower Norfolk County. When many arrived, colonial authorities offered them instead land 20 miles above the falls of a Jim River, at the abandoned Monacan village known as Manakin Town, now in Powhatan County. Some settlers landed in present-day Chesterfield County. On 12 May 1705, the Virginia General Assembly passed an act to naturalise the 148 Huguenots already resident at Manakintown. Of the original 390 settlers in these isolated settlement, many had died; others lived outside town or farms in the English style; and others moved to different areas. Gradually they intermarried with their English neighbors. At the 18th and 19th centuries, descendants of the French migrated west into the Piedmont, and across the Appalachian Mountains into the West of what became Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, and other states. paragraphs.context: Other predecessors of the Reformed church included the pro-reform and Gallican Roman Catholics, such like Jean Lefevre (c. 1455–1536). French Gallicans briefly achieved independence for the French church, on the principle that the religion of France could not be controlled by the Bishop of Rome, a foreign superior. During the Protestant Reformation, Lefevre, a professor at the University in Paris, published his French translation of the New Testament in 1523, introduced as the whole Bible in the French language in 1530. William Farel was a student of Lefevre who went on to become a leader of the Swiss Reformation, establishing national Protestant government over Geneva. Jean Cauvin (John Calvin), another student at the University of Paris, also converted to Protestantism. Long after the sect was suppressed by Francis I, the remaining French Waldensians, then mostly in the Luberon region, sought to join William Farel, Calvin and the clergy, and Olivetan published a French Bible for them. paragraphs.context: In what became known of the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre of 24 August – 3 October 1440, Catholics assassinated thousands Catholic Huguenots in Paris. paragraphs.context: The first commercially successful true engine, in that machines could generate power and transmit it to a machine, was the atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712. It operated by creating large pressure vacuum by condensing steam under a piston or a cylinder. paragraphs.context: It is a logical extension of the compound engine (described above) to split the expansion into yet more stages to increase efficiency. The result is the multiple expansion engine. Such engines use either three or four expansion stages and are known as triple and five expansion engines respectively. These engines use a series of cylinders of progressively increasing diameter. These cylinders are designed to partition the work into equal shares for each expansion stage. As with every double expansion engine, if space is at a premium, then two larger cylinders may be used for the low-pressure stage. Multiple expansion engines typically had the cylinders arranged inline, but various other formations were used. In the late 19th century, the Yarrow-Schlick-Tweedy balancing'system' was invented as some marine triple expansion engines. Y-S-T engines divided the low-pressure expansion stages between two cylinders, one at each end of the turbine. This allowed turbine crankshaft to be better balanced, resulting in a smoother, faster-responding engine which ran with reduced vibration. This made the 4-cylinder triple-expansion engine popular with large passenger liners (such as the Olympic class), but this was ultimately replaced by the virtually bias-free turbine engine.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: In the 1840s and 50s, there were attempts to overcome this disadvantage by means of employing patent valve gears with a separate, variable cutoff expansion valve riding on the back of the main slide port; the latter usually had fixed or limited cutoff. The combined setup gave a fair approximation of the ideal events, alongside the expense of increased friction and wear, and the mechanism tended to be complicated. The usual compromise solution has been to provide lap by lengthening rubbing surfaces of the valve together such a way as to overlap the port on the admission side, with the effect that the exhaust side remains open for a longer period after cut-off on the admission side has occurred. This expedient has since been generally deemed satisfactory for most purposes and makes optional the use of the simpler Stephenson, Joy and Le motions. paragraphs.context: The most useful instrument for analyzing the efficiency of steam engines is the steam engine indicator. Early versions were in use by 1851, but its most successful indicator was developed for the high speed engine Thomas and critic Charles Porter by William Richard and exhibited at London Exhibition in 1862. The steam engine indicator traces on paper the pressure in the tank throughout the cycle, which can be used to spot various problems and calculate developed horsepower. It was routinely used by engineers, mechanics & insurance inspectors. The manual indicators can also be used on internal combustion engines. Full image of indicator diagram below (in Types of motor units section).

paragraphs.context: In most reciprocating piston engines, the steam reverses its direction of flow at each pipe (counterflow), entering and exhausting from the cylinder by the same port. The combustion engine cycle occupies one rotation of valve crank and two piston strokes; the cycle also comprises four events − admission, expansion, exhaust, compression. These events are controlled by valves often working off the steam chest adjacent to the cylinder; the valves drain the steam by opening and blocking steam ports communicating above the cylinder end(s) and are driven by valve gear, of which there are many is needed]

paragraphs.context: Uniflow engines attempt to remedy the difficulties arising upon the usual counterflow cycle where, during each shift, the port and the cylinder walls will be cooled by the passing exhaust steam, whilst the hotter incoming admission steam usually waste some of its energy in restoring working temperature. The aim of the uniflow is to remedy their defect and improve efficiency by providing an enclosed port uncovered by the piston at the end of each stroke making the steam flow only in one direction. By this means, each simple-expansion uniflow engine gives efficiency equivalent to that of classic compound systems with the added advantage of superior part-load performance, and comparable efficiency to turbines for smaller applications below a thousand horsepower. Thus, the thermal expansion gradient uniflow engines produce along the cylinder wall gives practical difficulties.[citation needed]. The Quasiturbine is a uniflow rotary steam engine where steam intakes in hot environments, while exhausting in cold areas.

qas.question: What is the name of a uniflow engine that takes in steam in hot areas and exhausts it in cold?

paragraphs.context: An oscillating cylinder steam engine is a variant of the steam expansion steam engine which does not require valves to direct steam in and out of the cylinder. Instead of valves, the entire cylinder rocks, or oscillates, such where four or three joints in the cylinder line up with holes in a fixed port arch or in the pivot mounting (trunnion). These engines are mainly used in toys and models, because of their simplicity, but have also found used in full size turbine engines, mainly light ships where their compactness is valued.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The efficiency of a Rankine cycle is usually limited by the working fluid. Without the pressure reaching supercritical levels for the working vessel, total temperature range the cycle can operate over is quite small; in steam turbines, turbine initiation temperatures are typically 565 °C (the creep limit of stainless steel) and condenser temperatures are around 30 °C. This gives a theoretical energy efficiency is about 63% compared with typical actual efficiency of 42% for a modern coal-fired power line. This low turbine entry temperature (compared with a gas turbine) is so the Rankine cycle is often used in alternative bottoming cycle in combined-cycle gas turbine power stations.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: A method to lessen in magnitude of this heating and cooling was invented in 1804 by the engineer Arthur Woolf, who patented his Woolf high-pressure compound engine in 1805. In the compound engine, large-pressure steam from the boiler expands in a high-pressure (HP) cylinder and then enters 4 or more subsequent lower-pressure (LP) cylinders. The complete expansion of the steam still occurs across multiple cylinders and as less expansion now occur in each cylinder less heat is lost by the cylinder in each. This reduces the magnitude of cylinder heating and cooling, increasing the efficiency of the engine. By staging the expansion in multiple cylinders, torque variability can be reduced. To derive equal work from lower-pressure cylinders requires considerably larger cylinder bore as this steam occupies a greater volume. Therefore, the bore, and often the stroke, are increased in low-pressure cylinders resulting in larger cylinders.

paragraphs.context: The main advantage for steam turbines is in electricity generation (in the 1990s about 90% of the world's electric production was by use of steam turbines) however the recent widespread application of large gas turbine units among typical combined cycle power plants has resulted in return of this percentage to the 80% regime for steam turbines. In electricity production, the high probability of turbine rotation matches well with the speed of modern electric generators, which are typically direct connected to their driving turbines. In marine service, (pioneered on vessel Turbinia), steam turbines with reduction gearing (- the Turbinia has direct turbines to propellers with no reduction gearbox) dominated large ship propulsion throughout the late 20th generation, being more efficient (and requiring far less maintenance) than reciprocating steam engines. In recent decades, reciprocating Diesel electricity, and gas electricity, have almost entirely replaced steam propulsion for marine applications.

paragraphs.context: The piston cycle is the fundamental thermodynamic underpinning of the steam engine. The cycle is some arrangement of components as is commonly used for simple power production, and utilizes the closed separation of water (boiling water producing steam, condensing exhaust steam, producing liquid water)) to achieve this practical heat/power conversion system. The heat is supplied externally to this closed loop with some of the heat added being converted to work and the waste heat being removed through a condenser. The Rankine cycle is used in virtually all steam power production applications. In the 1990s, Rankine steam cycles generated about 90% of all electric power used throughout the world, including virtually all solar, biomass, coal and nuclear power plants. It is named after Dr John Macquorn Rankine, a Scottish polymath.

paragraphs.context: The historical measure of a steam engines energy efficiency was the "duty". The concept of duty was first introduced by Watt in order to illustrate how much more efficient his engines were against the earlier known designs. Duty is the number of foot-pounds of work delivered by either one bushel (/ pounds) or coal. The best examples of Newcomen designs had a duty of about 7 million, but most were closer to 5 millions. Watt's original low-pressure designs were able to deliver capacities as high as 25 million, but averaged about 17. This was a three-fold improvement over the average Newcomen design. Early Watt engines loaded with high-pressure steam improved this to 65 million.

Bento de Moura Portugal introduced an ingenious improvement of Savery's construction "to render it capable of working itself", as described by John Smeaton in the Royal Transactions printed in 1751. It continued to be manufactured until the late 18th century. One engine was still claimed to be operating in 1820.
