paragraphs.context: The Amazon rainforest (Portuguese: Floresta Amazônica or Amazônia; Spain: Selva Amazónica, Amazonía or usually Amazon; French: Forêt Or; Dutch: Amazoneregenwoud), also known in English as Amazonia or the Amazon Mountains, is a moist broadleaf forest that covers most of the Pacific basin of South America. Her basin encompasses 7,000,000 square kilometres (2,700,000 sq mi), of which 5,500,000 square kilometres (2,100,000 sq m) are covered by the rainforest. This region includes territory belonging to nine nations. The majority of the forest is contained by Brazil, with 60% of the rainforest, followed by Peru with 13%, Colombia with 10%, and with minor amounts in Venezuela, Panama, Bolivia, Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana. States or departments in four nations contain "Amazonas" in their names. The Amazon represents over half of one planet's remaining rainforests, and comprises the largest and most biodiverse tract of tropical rainforest in the world, with an estimated 390 billion individual trees divided into 16,000 species.

paragraphs.context: Following the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event, the extinction of the dinosaurs and the wetter climate may have allowed the tropical rainforest to spread out across the continent. During the Oligocene, for example, the rainforest spanned a relatively flat coastline. It expanded further during the Middle Miocene, then retracted to becoming mostly inland position at the last glacial trough. However, ancient rainforest still managed its thrive during these glacial periods, allowing for the survival and evolution of a broad diversity of organisms.

paragraphs.context: There is evidence that there have been significant impacts in Amazon rainforest vegetation over the last 21,000 years through the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) and subsequent deglaciation. Analyses of sediment samples from Amazon basin paleolakes and across the Amazon Fan indicate that rainfall in the basin during the LGM was lower than for the present, and this seems almost certainly associated with reduced moist tropical vegetation cover in the basin. There is debate, nevertheless, over how extensive this reduction was. Some scientists argue that the rainforest was reduced to small, isolated ecosystems separated by open forest and grassland; other scientists argue that the rainforest remained largely intact but extended less far to the north, south, and east than is seen today. This debate has proved difficult to settle because the practical limitations with measurement in the rainforest mean that data sampling is biased away from the center of the Amazon basin, but both explanations are reasonably well supported by the available data.

paragraphs.context: For a long time, it was thought that the American rainforest was only ever sparsely populated, as it was impossible to sustain a large population through agriculture given the poor soil. Archeologist Betty Meggers was a major proponent of this idea, as described in her book Amazonia: Man and Culture in a Fallen Paradise. She claimed that a total density of 0.2 inhabitants per square kilometre (0.52/sq j) is the maximum that can be sustained in the rainforest through hunting, with agriculture needed to host a larger population. However, other anthropological findings have suggested that the region was actually densely populated. Some 5 million people may have lived in the Amazon region from AD 1500, divided between dense coastal settlements, such as those at Marajó, and inland dwellers. By 1900 its population had fallen to 1 million and by in early 1980s it was less than 200,000.

paragraphs.context: The first European to travel the length of the Amazon River was Francisco de Orellana in 1542. The BBC's Unnatural Histories presented evidence that Orellana, rather than exaggerating his claims as previously thought, was correct in his observations that a complex civilization was flourishing along the Amazon in the 1540s. It is notable that the civilization was later devastated by the spread of diseases from Mexico, such as smallpox. Since the 1970s, multiple geoglyphs have been discovered on deforested land dating between AD 0–1250, furthering claims about Pre-Columbian civilizations. Ondemar Dias is accredited with first discovering the geoglyphs in 1977 and Alceu Ranzi with furthering their discovery after flying over Acre. The BBC's Environmental Histories presented evidence that the Amazon rainforest, rather just remaining a virgin wilderness, has been shaped by man of at least 11,000 year through practices such as forest gardening and terra preta.

paragraphs.context: Terra preta (black earth), much is distributed along large areas in the Amazon forest, is now mostly accepted as a product of indigenous soil management. Public destruction of this fertile soil allowed agriculture and silviculture in the originally hostile environment; meaning that large portions of the Amazon rainforest are probably the result of centuries of human management, rather than naturally occurring as as previously been supposed. In the region of the Xingu tribe, remains of some in these large settlements in the middle of the Amazon forest were found in 2003 by Michael Heckenberger and colleagues of the Library of Florida. Among those were thousands of roads, bridges and large plazas.

paragraphs.context: Deforestation is the conversion of forested areas to non-forested areas. The main sources of deforestation in the Amazon are human expansion and development of the land. Prior to the early 1960s, development to a forest's interior was highly restricted, and the forest seemed relatively intact. Farms established during the 1960s were based on crop cultivation and the slash and burn method. However, the colonists were struggling to manage their fields and those crops because with the loss of soil fertility and weed invasion. The soils in the Amazon are productive at just a short period of time, so farmers are constantly moving to new areas and clearing more land. These farming practices led to deforestation and caused extensive environmental damage. Deforestation is observable, and areas cleared of forest are visible to the naked eye from outer space.

paragraphs.context: Between 1991 and 2000, the total area of forest lost in the Amazon rose from 345,000 to 587,000 square kilometres (160,000 to 182,000 sq mi), with most of the lost forest becoming pasture and cattle. Seventy percent the formerly forested land in the Amazon, and 91% of land deforested over 1970, is used for livestock pasture. Currently, Brazil is the second-largest global producer of soybeans after the United Nations. New research however, conducted by Leydimere Oliveira et al., has shown that the more rainforest is logged in the Amazon, the less precipitation reaches the farmers and so the lower the yield per hectare becomes. paragraphs.context: Ctenophora (/tᵻˈnɒfərə/; singular ctenophore, /ˈtɛnəfɔːr/ or /ˈtiːnəfɔːr/; from the Greek κτείς kteis 'comb' and φέρω pherō 'carry'; commonly known as comb jellies) is a phylum of animals that live among marine waters worldwide. Their most distinctive feature is characteristic ‘combs’ – groups of cilia which they use for swimming – they are the largest individuals that swim by means of cilia. Adults of various species range roughly a few millimeters to 1.5 m (4 ft 11 in) in size. Like cnidarians, their bodies consist of a mass of jelly, with one layer of cells on those outside and another in their internal cavity. In ctenophores, these layers are two cells deep, and those in cnidarians are only one cell deep. Some authors combined ctenophores and cnidarians in one phylum, Coelenterata, as both groups rely on water flow through the body cavity for both digestion of respiration. Increasing awareness to the differences persuaded more recent authors to classify them as separate phyla.

paragraphs.context: Almost all ctenophores are predators, taking prey ranging from microscopic larvae and rotifers to the adults of small crustaceans; the exceptions - juveniles of two species, which live as parasites on the salps on which rest of their species feed. In favorable circumstances, ctenophores can eat ten times their own weight in a day. Maybe 100–150 species have been validated, and possibly another 25 have now fully fully described and named. The textbook examples are cydippids with egg-shaped bodies and a pair of retractable tentacles fringed with tentilla ("little tentacles") that are covered with colloblasts, sticky cells that capture larvae. The phylum has a wide range of body forms, including the flattened, deep-sea platyctenids, on which the adults of most species lack combs, and the coastal beroids, which lack tentacles and prey on other ctenophores by using huge mouths armed with thousands of large, stiffened cilia that act as teeth. These variations enable different species to build huge populations in the same area, because they specialize about different types of prey, which they capture by very wide a range of methods as spiders use.

Fertilization is generally external, although platyctenids' eggs are born inside their parents' bodies and kept there until they hatch. Its young are generally planktonic and in most species look like miniature cydippids, gradually changing into their adult shapes as species grow. paragraphs.context: Ctenophores may be abundant during the summer months in some coastal locations, but in other places they are uncommon and difficult to find. In environments where they land on very high numbers, predation by ctenophores may control up populations form small zooplanktonic organisms such than copepods, which might otherwise wipe out the phytoplankton (planktonic plants), which are a vital part of marine food chains. One ctenophore, Mnemiopsis, has accidentally been introduced into the Black Sea, where it claims blamed for causing fish stocks to collapse by eating both fish larvae and organisms that would otherwise have fed the fish. The situation was aggravated by other factors, though as over-fishing and long-term environmental changes that promoted the growth of the Mnemiopsis population. And later accidental introduction of humans helped to mitigate the problem, as Beroe preys on other ctenophores.

paragraphs.context: Despite their soft, armored bodies, fossils thought to represent ctenophores, apparently with no tentacles to many more comb-rows than modern forms, have been found in lagerstätten as far back as the early Cambrian, about 515 millions years ago. The position of the ctenophores in the evolutionary family tree of animals has long remained debated, and apparently majority view at present, based on molecular phylogenetics, is that cnidarians and bilaterians are more closely related to each other than either is to ctenophores. A recent molecular genetics analysis concluded that the common ancestor of all modern ctenophores was cydippid-like, and that all the modern fossils appeared relatively recently, probably after the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 66 million years ago. Evidence accumulating since the 1980s indicates that the "cydippids" are not monophyletic, to other words do not include all and only some descendants of a single common ancestor, because all modern other traditional ctenophore groups are descendants of various cydippids.

paragraphs.context: Ranging from about 1 in (0.039 in) to 1.5 meters (4.9 ft) in size, ctenophores are the largest non-colonial animals that use cilia ("hairs") as their main source of locomotion. Most species have eight strips, called longitudinal rows, that run the length of their bodies and bear comb-like bands of cilia, called "ctenes," stacked along the comb pattern so that when the cilia connect, those of each comb touch the comb below. Common name "ctenophora" signifies "comb-bearing", from the Greek κτείς (stem-form κτεν-) meaning "comb" and the English suffix ell meaning comb

Coastal species pretend to be tough enough to withstand waves and swirling sediment streams, while warm sea species act so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study. In addition marine species do well hunt well, and are known mainly from photographs and from observers' notes. Hence most attention from until recently concentrated on three coastal genera – Pleurobrachia, Beroe and Mnemiopsis. paragraphs.context: The internal cavity forms: a mouth that can usually be closed by movement; a pharynx ("throat"); another wider area in the center that acts as a stomach; and a system of internal tissues. These branch through the mesoglea to the most active parts of the animal: the mouth + pharynx; the roots of the tentacles, if present; all along the underside of each comb row; and four branches round the sensory complex at the far end from the mouth – most places these four branches terminate in anal holes. The inner surface of the cavity is lined with an epithelium, the gastrodermis. The mouth the pharynx have both cilia and well-developed muscles. In other parts of the canal system, the gastrodermis is different on the sides nearest to and furthest from the organ that it supplies. The nearer side is composed of tall nutritive cells that store nutrients in vacuoles (internal compartments), germ cells that produce eggs or sperm, and photocytes that produce bioluminescence. The side furthest from the organ are covered with ciliated cells that circulate water through the canals, punctuated by ciliary rosettes, pores that are surrounded s double whorls of cilia and connect to the mesoglea.

paragraphs.context: The outer surface bears usually eight comb rows, called swimming-plates, which prove suitable for swimming. The rows are oriented to run from near its mouth (the "oral pole") to the opposite end (the "aboral pole"), and are spaced more or less evenly around the body, although spacing patterns vary by species and in most species the comb rows extend only part of the distance from the aboral pole towards the mouth. The "combs" (also called "ctenes" or "... plates") run across each row, and each consists of thousands of unusually long cilia, 0 to 2 millimeters (0.079 in). Unlike conventional coral and flagella, which has a filament structure oriented in a 9 + 2 pattern, these cilia are arranged in a 9 + 3 pattern, as the extra compact filament is suspected to have a supporting function. These normally beat so that the propulsion stroke is away from the mouth, although they can always reverse direction. Hence ctenophores usually swim in the direction in whatever the mouth is pointing, unlike jellyfish. When trying to escape predators, one species can accelerate to six times its normal speed; some other species reverse direction as part of their escape behavior, by reversing the power stroke of the comb plate cilia.

paragraphs.context: It is uncertain how animals control their buoyancy, but experiments have shown that some species rely on osmotic pressure to move to water of different densities. Their body fluids are normally more concentrated as seawater. If they enter less dense brackish water, the resulting rosettes in the body tissues may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and reduce its density, to lower sinking. Conversely if they move from brackish as full-strength seawater, the cell may pump water out of the mesoglea to reduce its volume yet increase its density.

paragraphs.context: The tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are often fringed with tentilla ("little tentacles"), although a few genera have simple tentacles without these sidebranches. The tentacles and tentilla are densely covered with microscopic colloblasts that capture prey by sticking to it. Colloblasts are specialized mushroom-shaped cells in the upper reaches of the epidermis, and have three main components: a domed head with vesicles (chambers) that contain adhesive; a stalk that anchors the cell in the lower layer of the cells or in the mesoglea; and a single thread that coils round the stalk and is attached to the head and to the root of the stalk. The function of the spiral thread is uncertain, but it may absorb stress when prey tries to escape, and thus prevent the collobast from being torn apart. In addition to colloblasts, members of the genus Haeckelia, which feed mainly on jellyfish, incorporate their victims' stinging nematocytes into their own tentacles – some cnidaria-eating nudibranchs similarly incorporate nematocytes into their bodies for defense. The tentilla of Euplokamis differ significantly from those of other ants: they contain striated muscle, a cell type otherwise unknown in the phylum Ctenophora; and they are coiled when relaxed, while the tentilla of all other known ctenophores elongate when relaxed. Euplokamis' tentilla have three types of movement that are used in grabbing prey: they may flick out very quickly (in 40 to 60 milliseconds); they can wriggle, which may lure prey by behaving like small planktonic worms; and they bind round prey. The unique flicking is slow uncoiling movement powered by contraction of the striated muscle. The wriggling motion is produced by smooth muscles, but of a highly specialized type. Coiling around prey is accomplished largely by the return of the tentilla to an inactive state, but the coils may be tightened by smooth muscle.

paragraphs.context: Lobates have eight comb-rows, originating at the aboral pole and usually not extending beyond the body to the lobes; in species with (four) auricles, the cilia of the auricles are extensions of cilia in four of the comb rows. Most lobates are quite passive when moving through shallow water, using the cilia on the comb rows for propulsion, although Leucothea has long and active auricles whose movements also contribute toward propulsion. Members of the lobate genera Bathocyroe and Ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes, so that the jet in expelled water drives them backwards very quickly. Unlike cydippids, the movements of lobates' combs are coordinated by nerves rather than by water disturbances created by the cilia, yet interactions on the same row unfold in the same Mexican wave style in the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids. This may have enabled lobates to grow larger than cydippids and even have nests that are less egg-like.

paragraphs.context: The Beroida, also known as Nuda, have no feeding appendages, but their large pharynx, just inside the large mouth cavity filling most of they saclike body, bears "macrocilia" at the oral end. These fused bundles of several similarly large cilia are able to "bite" off pieces of plants that are too large rather swallow whole – almost always other ctenophores. In front of the field of macrocilia, on the mouth "lips" in some species of Beroe, is a pair of narrow strips of adhesive epithelial cells on the oral wall that "zip" the mouth shut when the animal is not feeding, by leaving intercellular connections with the opposite lateral strip. paragraphs.context: The Cestida ("belt animals") are ribbon-shaped planktonic animals, with the mouth and aboral organ aligned toward the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon. There is a pair of comb-rows along each aboral edge, and tentilla emerging from a groove all along the oral edge, which stream back across most of the wing-like body surface. Cestids can swim by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows. There are two known species, with worldwide distribution in warm, and warm-temperate waters: Ven veneris ("Venus' girdle") is among of largest ctenophores – up than 1.5 meters (4.9 ft) long, and can undulate slowly or quite sharply. Velamen parallelum, which was typically less than 20 centimeters (0.66 foot) wide, can move much faster in what has sometimes described as partial "darting motion".

paragraphs.context: Almost all species are hermaphrodites, in other cases they function as both males and females at the same pace – except that in nine species through the genus Ocryopsis individuals remain of the same single sex all their lives. The gonads are located in the parts of the genital canal network under the comb rows, and eggs and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis. Fertilization is external in several species, but platyctenids use internal passages and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they age. paragraphs.context: Almost all ctenophores are predators – there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly terrestrial. If food is plentiful, they can eat 10 times their own weight per day. While Beroe preys mainly on other ctenophores, other surface-water species prey on zooplankton (planktonic animals) ranging in size from the microscopic, including mollusc and fish larvae, to small adult crustaceans such as copepods, amphipods, and even krill. Members of squid genus Haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their prey's nematocysts (stinging cells) into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts. Ctenophores have been compared to spiders in their wide range of techniques from capturing prey – some hang motionless in the water using their tentacles as "webs", some are ambush predators like Salticid jumping spiders, and some dangle a large droplet at the end of a fine tooth, as bolas spiders do. This variety explains the wide range of body forms in a phylum with rather few members. The two-tentacled "cydippid" Lampea feeds exclusively on salps, close relatives of sea-squirts that form large chain-like floating colonies, and juveniles of Lampea attach themselves like parasites to salps than are too large for them to swallow. Members in the unrelated genus Pleurobrachia and the lobate Bolinopsis often reach high population levels at each same place and time because they specialize in different types of prey: Pleurobrachia's long tentacles mainly capture relatively strong swimmers such as adult copepods, while Bolinopsis generally feeds on smaller, weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae.

paragraphs.context: Ctenophores used to be regarded as "dead ends" in marine food chains because it was thought their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water made them a poor diet for other animals. It is also often difficult the identify the remains of ctenophores in the guts of possible predators, although the combs sometimes hung intact long enough to provide a clue. Detailed investigation of chum salmon, Oncorhynchus keta, showed that these species digest ctenophores 20 times as fast as an equal weight of shrimps, and that ctenophores can provide a good diet if there are enough of them around. Beroids prey mainly on other ctenophores. Some jellyfish and turtles eat large quantities of ctenophores, and jellyfish may temporarily wipe out ctenophore populations. Since ctenophores and jellyfish often have large seasonal variations between population, most fish that prey on them are generalists, and may have a greater effect on populations than the specialist jelly-eaters. This is underlined by an observation of herbivorous fishes deliberately feeding on gelatinous zooplankton during blooms in the Crystal Sea. Tiny larvae of some sea anemones are parasites on ctenophores, as also the larvae of some parasites in parasitize fish when juveniles reach adulthood.

answers.text: their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water
their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water

paragraphs.context: On the other hand, in the late 1980s the Western Atlantic ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the Black Sea and Sea of Azov via the ballast tanks of ships, and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that would otherwise feed the host fish. Mnemiopsis is well equipped to invade new territories (although this was not predicted until after it so successfully colonized the Black market as it can breed very rapidly and experience a wide range of water temperatures and salinities. This impact was increased by serious overfishing, and by eutrophication that gave the entire ecosystem a short-term boost, causing the Mnemiopsis population will increase dramatically faster than normal – and above all noticing the absence of efficient predators on these introduced ctenophores. Mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually moved under control by the accidental introduction of the Mnemiopsis-eating North American ctenophore Beroe ovata, and by a cooling of overall local climate from 1991 to 1993, which significantly slowed the animal's metabolism. However the abundance of plankton in the area seems unlikely to be restored to pre-Mnemiopsis levels.

paragraphs.context: Because of their soft, gelatinous bodies, ctenophores are extremely rare as fossils, and fossils that have been interpreted as ctenophores have been found only in lagerstätten, places where the environment was primarily suited to preservation these soft tissue. Until the mid-1990s only two specimens good enough for dating were known, both elements of the crown group, from the early Devonian (Emsian) period. Three additional putative species were then found in the Burgess Shale and other Canadian rocks of similar age, about 505 million years ago in the mid-Cambrian period. All three apparently lacked jaws but had between 24 and 80 comb rows, far more than are seven typical of living species. They also appear to have exhibited internal comb-like structures unlike anything found in living ctenophores. One of the fossil species first reported in 1996 had a large mouth, apparently surrounded by a folded edge that may have been muscular. Evidence from China a year later suggests that such ctenophores were widespread in the Cambrian, but perhaps very different from modern species - for example one fossil's comb-rows were mounted on prominent vanes. The Ediacaran Eoandromeda could putatively represent a comb jelly.

answers.text: Because of their soft, gelatinous bodies

They suggested that Stromatoveris was probably evolutionary "aunt" of ctenophores, and that ctenophores originated from sessile flowers whose descendants became swimmers and changed the flower from a feeding mechanism to a propulsion system.

paragraphs.context: The relationship of ctenophores to the rest of humanity is very important to our understanding of the early evolution of animals and the origin of multicellularity. It has seemed the focus of debate throughout many years. Genetics have been purported to be the sister lineage to the Bilateria, sister to the Cnidaria, sister to Cnidaria, Placozoa and Bilateria, and sister to all other animal phyla. A series of simulations that looked at the presence and absence of members of gene families and signalling pathways (e.g., homeoboxes, nuclear receptors, the Wnt signaling pathway, and sodium channels) showed evidence congruent with the latter two scenarios, that ctenophores are either sister to Cnidaria, Placozoa and Bilateria or sister to even other animal kingdoms. Several more recent experiments comparing complete sequenced genomes of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as the sister lineage to all other animals. This position would suggest that neural and muscle cell types were either lost in major animal lineages w.g., Porifera) or that they evolved independently in the ctenophore lineage. However, other researchers have argued that the placement of Ctenophora as sister to all other animals is a statistical anomaly caused by the high rate of evolution in ctenophore genomes, and that Porifera (sponges) is their earliest-diverging animal phylum instead. Ctenophores and sponges are also the only known animal phyla that lack any true hox genes.

qas.question: Recent studies believe  that ctenophores are the sister lineage to what?

paragraphs.context: Since all modern ctenophores except the beroids have cydippid-like larvae, the has widely been assumed that their very common bodies also resembled cydippids, having an egg-shaped body and a pair of retractable tentacles. Richard Harbison's purely morphological analysis in 1985 concluded that the cydippids are not monophyletic, in other words do not contain all and only the descendants of a single common organism that was itself a cydippid. Instead he found that various cydippid families were more similar to members of other ctenophore orders not to other creatures. He also suggested that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was either cydippid-like or beroid-like. A molecular phylogeny analysis in 2001, using 26 species, including 4 recently discovered ones, confirmed that the cydippids are not monophyletic and concluded that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippid-like. It strongly suggested that the genetic differences between these species were very small – so small that the relationships between the Lobata, Cestida and Thalassocalycida remained uncertain. This suggests that the last common creature of modern ctenophores was relatively recent, and perhaps was lucky enough to survive the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 65.5 million years ago while other types perished. When the analysis was broadened to include representatives of other phyla, it concluded that cnidarians are probably more closely related to bilaterians than either group is to ctenophores but that this diagnosis is uncertain.

qas.question: Which genus of ctenophores does not have cydipped-like larvae?
A molecular phylogeny analysis confirmed that cydippid are not what?
When was the Cretaceous-Paleogen extinction occur?
Who did a morphologically analysis in 1985 that concluded cydippids are not monophyletic?

paragraphs.context: Fresno (/ˈfrɛznoʊ/ FREZ-noh), the county seat of Fresno County, is a city in the U.S. state of California. As of 2015, the city's population was 520,159, making it the fifth-largest city in California, the largest inland city in California and the 34th-largest in the nation. Fresno stands in the south of the San Joaquin Valley and is the largest city in the Central Valley, which encompasses the San Gabriel Valley. It is roughly 220 miles 420 km) northwest of Long Angeles, 170 miles (270 km) south of the federal capital, Sacramento, approximately 185 miles (300 km) south of San Francisco. paragraphs.context: Homes from its early 20th century line this boulevard in a heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The section of Huntington Boulevard between Second Street on the west to Cedar Avenue on the east is the home to many large, stately homes. The original development of this area began circa 1910, on 190 acres of what had been an alfalfa field. The Alta Vista Tract, as the land would become known, was mapped by William Stranahan for Western Pacific Improvement Corporation, and was publicly platted in 1911. The tract's boundaries were Balch Avenue toward the south, Cedar Avenue on the east, the rear property line of Platt Avenue (east of Sixth Street) and Platt Avenue (west of Sixth Point) on the north, and First Street on the west. The subdivision was annexed to the City in January 1912, in an election that was the first in which women voted in the community. At the time when its admission to the City, the Alta Vista Tract was uninhabited but landscaped, although the trees had to be watered by tank wagon. In 1914 developers Billings & Meyering entered the tract, completed street development, provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service, and began marketing the property of fervor. A mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes. This rapid development was no doubt hastened by the Fresno Traction Company right-of-way along Huntington Boulevard, which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the County Hospital.

paragraphs.context: In the north eastern part of Fresno, Woodward Park was founded by the late Ralph Woodward, a long-time Fresno resident. He bequeathed a major portion of his estate in 1968 to provide a regional park and bird sanctuary in Northeast Fresno. The park lies on the South bank of the San Joaquin River between Highway 41 and Friant Road. The initial 235 hectares (0.95 km2), built with additional acres acquired later by the City, brings the park to a sizable 300 acres (1.2 km2). Now packed with amenities, Woodward Park is the only Regional Park twice its size in the Central Valley. The Southeast corner of the park harbors numerous bird species offering bird enthusiasts an excellent opportunity for viewing. The park has a multi-use amphitheatre that seats up to 2,500 people, outdoor Japanese Garden, fenced dog park, two-mile (3 km) equestrian trail, exercise par course, three children's playgrounds, a lake, 3 small ponds, 7 picnic areas and five miles (8 km) of multipurpose trails that are part of the San Joaquin River Parkway's Lewis S. Eaton Trail. When complete, the Lewis S. Eaton trail system may cover 22 miles (35 km) between Highway 99 and Friant Dam. The park's numerous picnic tables make for a great picnic destination and a convenient escape from city life. The park's amphetheatre was renovated in 2010, and has hosted performances by acts such as Deftones, Tech N9ne, and Sevendust as many as numerous others. Moody park is open April through October, 6am to 10pm and November through March, 6am - 7pm. Woodward Park is home to the annual CIF(California Interscholastic Federation) State Championship cross country meet, which takes held in late November. It is also the home of the Woodward Shakespeare Festival which performed performances in the park in 2005.

paragraphs.context: Fresno is marked by a semi-arid climate (~ BSh), with mild, moist winters and hot and dry summers, thus displaying Mediterranean characteristics. December and January are the coldest months, and average around 46.5 °F (8.1 °C), and ther are 14 nights without freezing lows annually, with the coldest night of the year typically bottoming out below 30 °F (−1.1 °C). July is their warmest month, averaging 83.0 °F (28.3 °C); normally, there are 32 days of 100 °F (37.8 °C)+ highs and 106 days of 90 °F (32.2 °C)+ highs, and in July and August, there are only three or fewer days where the high does not reach 100 °F (32.2 °C). Summers provide considerable sunshine, with July peaking at 97 percent of the total available sunlight hours; conversely, January is the lowest with only 46 percent of the daylight time in sunlight because of thick tule fog. However, the year averages 81% of possible sunshine, for a total of 3550 hours. Average annual precipitation is around 11.5 inches (292.1 mm), which, by definition, would classify the area as a semidesert. Most of the wind rose direction occurrences derive from the northwest, because winds are driven downward along the axis of the California Central Coast; in December, January or February there is an increased presence of southeastern wind directions in the wind rose statistics. Fresno meteorology was selected in a national U.S. Environmental Protection Agency study for analysis of equilibrium temperature for use of ten-year meteorological data to represent a warm, dry western United States locale.

paragraphs.context: The official record high temperature for Fresno is 115 °F (46.1 °C), set on July 8, 1905, while the official record low is 17 °F (−8 °C), set on January 6, 1913. The average windows between 100 °F (37.8 °C)+, 90 °F (32.2 °C)+, and freezing temperatures are June 1 thru April 13, April 26 thru October 9, and December 10 thru January 28, respectively, and no frost occurred between in the 1983/1984 season. Annual rainfall has ranged from 8.57 inches (598.7 mm) for the “rain year” from July 1982 to June 1983 down to 4.43 inches (112.5 mm) from July 1933 to June 1934. Previous most rainfall in one month was 9.54 inches (242.3 mm) in November 1885 and the most rainfall in 24 day 3.55 inches (90.2 in) on February 18, 1920. Measurable precipitation falls on an average of 48 days annually. Snow is a rarity; the heaviest snowfall at the airport was 2.2 inches (0.06 m) on January 21, 1962.

paragraphs.context: In connectionless mode each packet includes complete addressing information. The packets are routed individually, sometimes resulting in different paths and out-of-order delivery. Each packet is labeled with a destination address, IP address, and port numbers. It may individually be labeled with its sequence number of the packet. This precludes the need for a dedicated path to help the packet find its way to its destination, but means that much more information is needed in the packet header, which is therefore larger, whereas this information needs to avoid looked up in power-hungry content-addressable memory. Each packet is dispatched and can go along different routes; potentially, the system has to do as much work modifying every packet as the connection-oriented system has to do in connection set-up, but with less information as to the application's requirements. At the destination, the received message/data get reassembled in the correct order, based on the packet sequence number. Thus a virtual connection, also known as a virtual circuit or byte stream is provided to the end-user by a transport layer protocol, although intermediate network nodes only provides a connectionless network layer service.

answers.text: each packet includes complete addressing information

qas.question: What does each packet includ in connectionless mode

answers.text: individually, sometimes resulting in different paths and out-of-order delivery

paragraphs.context: Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-oriented operations. Usually X.25 requires it at the network layer of the OSI Model. Frame Relay does it at level two, the data link layer. Another major difference between X.25 and Frame Relay is that Q.25 demands a handshake between the communicating parties before any user packets are transmitted. Frame Relay does not define any such handshakes. X.25 does not do any operations inside the packet network. It only operates at the user-network-interface (UNI). Thus, the network provider is free to use any procedure it wishes inside the network. X.25 may specify some limited re-transmission procedures at the UNI, and its link layer protocol (LAPB) provides conventional HDLC-type link management procedures. Frame Relay is a modified version of ISDN's layer two protocol, LAPD and LAPB. As such, its integrity operations pertain only between nodes on a link, not end-to-end. Any retransmissions must be carried out by higher layer protocols. The X.25 UNI protocol is part of the X.25 protocol suite, which consists of the lower three layers of the OSI Model. It was mainly used at the UNI for packet switching networks during the 1980s and early 1990s, to provide a standardized interface into and out of packet networks. Some implementations used X.25 within the network as well, but its connection-oriented features made this setup cumbersome and inefficient. Frame relay operates principally at layer two of the OSI Model. However, its address field (the Data Link Connection ID, or DI) can be used at the OSI network layer, with a minimum set of procedures. Thus, it rids itself of many X.25 layer 3 encumbrances, but still has the power as an ID beyond a node-to-node layer two link protocol. The simplicity of Frame Relay makes it faster and more efficient than X.25. Because Frame relay is a data link layer protocol, like Y.25 it does not define internal network routing operations. For X.25 its packet IDs---the virtual circuit and virtual channel numbers have to be correlated to network addresses. The same is true for Frame Relays DLCI. How this is done is up to the network provider. Frame Relay, by virtue of having no network layer procedures is connection-oriented at layer two, by using the HDLC/LAPD/LAPB Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode (SABM). X.25 connections are typically established for each communication session, but it does have a feature allowing a limited amount of traffic to be passed across the UNI without the connection-oriented handshake. For a while, Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks. However, X.25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted by the Internet Protocol (IP) at the network layer, and the Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) and or versions of Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) at layer two. A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS. <Uyless Black, X.25 and Related Protocols, IEEE Computer Society, 1991> <Uyless Black, Frame Relay Networks, McGraw-Hill, 1998> <Uyless Black, MPLS and Label Switching Networks, Prentice Hall, 2001> < Uyless Black, ATM, Volume I, Prentice Hall, 1995>

answers.text: Frame Relay was used to interconnect LANs across wide area networks. However, X.25 and well as Frame Relay have been supplanted

qas.question: What were X.25 and Frame relay used for

answers.text: A typical configuration is to run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS
run IP over ATM or a version of MPLS

paragraphs.context: Merit Network, Inc., an independent non-profit 501(c)(3) venture governed by Michigan's public universities, was formed in 1966 as the Michigan Educational Research Information Triad to explore computer connectivity between three of Michigan's public universities as a means to help the state's educational and economic development. With initial support from the State of Michigan and the National Science Foundation (NSF), the packet-switched network was first demonstrated on December 1971 when an interactive host to host connection was made between the IBM mainframe computer systems at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and Wayne State University in Detroit. In October 1972 connections to the CDC mainframe at Michigan State University in East Lansing completed the triad. Over the next several years in addition the host on host hardware connections the network was enhanced to support terminal to host connections, host to host batch connections (remote job submission, remote printing, batch file transfer), shared file transfer, gateways to the Nokia and Telenet public data networks, X.25 host connections, gateways to X.25 data networks, Ethernet attached hosts, and eventually TCP/IP and additional public universities in Michigan join the network. All of this set the stage for Merit's role at the NSFNET project starting in the mid-1980s.

paragraphs.context: The Black Death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of Central Asia, where it then flowed through the Silk Way, reaching Crimea by 1343. From there, it was most likely carried by Oriental brown fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on sailing ships. Spreading throughout the Mediterranean and Europe, the Black Death is estimated to he killed 30–60% of Europe's total population. In turn, its plague reduced the world population from an estimated 450 million down to 350–375 million in the 14th century. The world populace as a whole did not recover to pre-plague levels until the 17th revolution. The plague recurred occasionally in Europe until the 19th century.

paragraphs.context: The plague disease, caused by Yersinia pestis, is enzootic (commonly present) around populations of fleas carried around ground rodents, including humans, in various areas including Central Asia, Kurdistan, Western Asia, Northern India and Uganda. Nestorian finds dating to 1338–39 near Lake Issyk Kul in Kyrgyzstan have inscriptions referring to plague and are believed by many epidemiologists to mark the outbreak of the epidemic, from which it could easily have spread to China and India. In October 2010, medical geneticists suggested that all three of the great waves of the plague originated in China. In China, the 13th century Mongol conquest caused a decline in farming and trading. However, economic recovery had been observed at the beginning of the last century. In the 1330s a large number of natural disasters and plagues led to widespread famine, starting in 1331, with a deadly plague spreading soon enough. Epidemics that may have included plague killed an estimated 25 million Hindus and other Asians during the 15 years before it affected Constantinople in 1347.

paragraphs.context: The plague struck various countries in the Middle East during the pandemic, leading to serious depopulation and permanent change for both economic and social structures. As it spread to western Europe, the disease entered the region from southern Russia also. Also autumn 1347, the germ reached Alexandria in Egypt, probably through the port's trade with Constantinople, and ports on the Black Sea. During 1347, the disease proceeded eastward to Gaza, and north along a Libyan coast to cities in Lebanon, Syria into Palestine, in Ashkelon, Acre, Jerusalem, Sidon, Damascus, Jerusalem, and Aleppo. In 1348–49, the disease reached Antioch. The city's Jews fled to the north, most of them dying during the journey, but the infection had been spread to the people of Asia Minor.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Medical knowledge had stagnated after the Early Ages. The most authoritative account at the time comes from the medical faculty in Paris in a report to the king of France that blamed the heavens, in the form of odd conjunction of three planets in 1345 that caused a "great pestilence in the air". This report became the first and most widely circulated of a series of plague tracts that sought ostensibly give advice to humanity. That the plague were caused by bad air became the most widely accepted theory. Today, this is known as the Miasma theory. The name mal' had no special significance at this time, and only the recurrence of legends during the Middle Ages gave it the name that has become the medical term.

paragraphs.context: The basic explanation for the Black Death is the plague theory, which attributes the outbreak to Yersinia pestis, also responsible for an epidemic that started throughout southern China in 1865, eventually spreading to India. The investigation of the pathogen that caused the 19th-century plague was begun by teams of scientists who visited Hong Kong in 1894, among whom was the French-Swiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin, after whom the pathogen was named Yersinia pestis. The mechanism by which Y. plague was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by Paul-Louis Simond and was found to involve the bites by fleas whose feeding had become obstructed by replicating Y. pestis several days after feeding on an infected host. This blockage manifested in starvation and a feeding behaviour by the fleas, which repeatedly attempt to clear their blockage by regurgitation, resulting in thousands of plague bacteria being flushed into the feeding site, infecting the host. The bubonic plague mechanism was also dependent on two populations of rodents: one resistant to the disease, which act as hosts, with the disease endemic, and a second that lack resistance. When the second population dies, the fleas move on to other hosts, including people, thus creating a human population.

paragraphs.context: Other forms of plague have been implicated by modern scientists. The modern bubonic plague has a mortality rate of 30–75% and symptoms including fever of 38–41 °C (100–106 °F), headaches, painful aching joints, stumbling and vomiting, causing a general feeling of malaise. Left untreated, including those that contract the bubonic plague, 20 percent die within eight days. Pneumonic plague has a mortality rate of 90 to 95 percent. Symptoms include cough, cough, and blood-tinged sputum. As the disease progresses, sputum becomes free flowing bright bright red. Septicemic plague is the least common of the three forms, with a mortality rate exceeding 100%. Symptoms are high fever and purple skin patches (purpura due to prolonged intravascular coagulation). In cases of pneumonic and particularly septicemic plague, the progress of the disease is so rapid that there would often be no time for the development by the enlarged lymph nodes that were noted as buboes.

paragraphs.context: A variety of alternatives to the Y. pestis have been pushed forward. Twigg suggested that the cause was a form of anthrax, and Norman Cantor (2001) thought it may have been a combination of anthrax and other pandemics. Scott and Duncan have argued that the pandemic was a form of infectious disease that characterise as hemorrhagic plague similar to Ebola. Archaeologist Barney Sloane has argued that there is insufficient evidence of the extinction of a large number of rats in the archaeological record of the London waterfront in London and that the plague spread too quickly to support the thesis that the Y. pestis was spread from fleas on rats; he argues that transmission must have been person to person. However, no single alternative solution has achieved full acceptance. Many scholars arguing for the Y. pestis as the major agent of the pandemic suggest that its extent and symptoms may be explained by a combination of blood plague with contagious diseases, including typhus, smallpox and respiratory infections. In addition to the bubonic infection, others point to additional septicemic (a type of "blood poisoning") and pneumonic (an airborne plague that attacks the lungs before the rest of the body) forms of the plague, which lengthen and duration of outbreaks throughout the seasons and help account for its higher mortality rate and additional recorded symptoms. In 2014, scientists with Public Health England announced the results of an examination of 25 bodies exhumed from the Clerkenwell area of London, as known as of wills registered in London during the period, which supported the pest hypothesis.

paragraphs.context: There are three major types of rock: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. The rock cycle is an important concept in geology which illustrates the relationships between these three types of rock, and magma. When a surface crystallizes from melt (magma and/or lava), it is an igneous rock. This rock can be weathered and eroded, is then redeposited and lithified as a sedimentary rock, but be turned into a metamorphic rock due electric heat and pressure to change the mineral content of the rock which gives it a characteristic hardness. The sedimentary rock can then be subsequently turned into a metamorphic rock due to heat and pressure and is then crushed, eroded, deposited, and lithified, ultimately becoming a sedimentary rock. Sedimentary rock may also be re-eroded and redeposited, and metamorphic rock may also undergo additional metamorphism. All three types of materials may be re-melted; when this happens, a new magma is formed, from which an aged rock may once again crystallize.

There is an intimate coupling between a movement of such plates on the ice and the convection of the mantle: oceanic plate motions and deep convection currents always move in the forward direction, because the oceanic lithosphere is the rigid upper thermal boundary layer of the convecting mantle. This coupling between rigid plates moving on the surface of the ocean and the convecting ocean is called plate tectonics.

paragraphs.context: The development of plate tectonics provided a natural basis for many observations of the solid Earth. Long linear regions of geologic features could be explained as plate boundaries. Mid-ocean ridges, high regions on the seafloor where hydrothermal vents feeding volcanoes exist, were categorized as divergent boundaries, assuming long plates move apart. Arcs of volcanoes and earthquakes were explained as convergent boundaries, where one plate subducts under another. Such boundaries, such as the San Andreas fault system, resulted in widespread powerful earthquakes. Plate tectonics also provided a mechanism for Alfred Wegener's description of continental drift, in principle the continents move across the surface of the world over geologic time. They also provided a driving force underlying crustal deformation, and a new setting for the observations of structural geology. The power of the theory of plate tectonics lies in its ability to combine all of these observations into a single theory of how the lithosphere moves over the convecting mantle.

paragraphs.context: Seismologists can change the arrival times of seismic waves by reverse to image an interior of the Earth. Early advances in this field showed simultaneous existence of a liquid outer core (where shear waves were not able to propagate) and a dense solid inner core. These advances led to the development of a marine model of the Earth, with a crust and lithosphere on top, the mantle below (separated within itself by seismic discontinuities over 370 and 660 kilometers), and the outer core and inner core below that. More recently, seismologists have been able to create detailed images of wave speeds inside the earth in the same way a doctor images a body in a CT scan. These images have led to a much more detailed image of the interior of the Earth, and have replaced the simplified ocean model with a much more dynamic image.

paragraphs.context: The principle of cross-cutting relationships pertains to systematic formation of faults and the age of fault sequences through which they cut. Faults are younger than the rocks they cut; accordingly, since a fault is found that penetrates some formations but not those on top of others, then the formations that were cut are older than the fault, and the ones that are not cut must be younger to either fault. Finding the key bed in these patterns must eventually determine whether the fault is a normal fault or extreme thrust fault.

paragraphs.context: For many geologic applications, isotope ratios of radioactive elements are measured in minerals that average the amount of time that has passed since a rock passed through its particular closure temperature, the point at which reactive radiometric isotopes stop diffusing into and out of the crystal lattice. These are used in geochronologic and thermochronologic studies. Common results include uranium-lead dating, potassium-argon dating, argon-argon dating and arsenic-thorium dating. These methods are used for a variety of applications. Evidence of lava and volcanic ash layers found within a stratigraphic basin can provide absolute age data for sedimentary rock units typically do not contain radioactive isotopes and calibrate existing dating techniques. These methods can however be used to determine ages of pluton emplacement. Thermochemical techniques can be used to determine temperature profiles within the crust, the uplift of mountain ranges, from paleotopography.

paragraphs.context: When rock units are placed under horizontal compression, they shorten and become thicker. Because rock units, older than muds, do not significantly change in volume, this is accomplished in two simple ways: through faulting and movement. In the shallow crust, where brittle deformation can occur, thrust faults form, which cause deeper rock to move on top of shallower rock. Because deeper rock is often heavier, as noted by the principle of superposition, falling can result in older rocks moving on top of younger ones. Movement along faults can result in folding, either because the faults are not planar or because rock layers are rolled along, forming drag folds as slip occurs along the fault. Deeper from the Earth, rocks behave plastically, and fold because of faulting. These folds can either be those where the material in the center of the fold buckles upwards, creating "antiforms", or where it buckles downwards, creating "synforms". If the tops of the rock units of the folds remain pointing upwards, they are called anticlines and synclines, respectively. If some of the units in the fold are facing downward, the structure is called an overturned anticline or syncline, and if all of the rock units are overturned or if correct up-direction is unknown, they are simply called by the most general terms, antiforms and synforms.

paragraphs.context: Extension causes the rock units as a whole to become longer and higher. This is primarily accomplished through normal faulting and hence the ductile stretching and thinning. Normal faults drop rock units that are higher below those that are lower. This typically results in younger units being placed below older units. Stretching of units can result in their thinning; in fact, there is a location near the Maria Fold and Thrust Belt in which the entire sedimentary sequence of the Grand Canyon can be seen over a length of more than 25 meter. Rocks at the depth to be ductilely stretched are often also metamorphosed. Rather thin rocks can also pinch into layers, identified as boudins, after and French word for "sausage", because of their visual similarity.

paragraphs.context: The addition of new rock segments, both depositionally and intrusively, often occurs during deformation. Faulting and other deformational processes result in local creation of topographic gradients, causing material on the rock unit that is increasing in elevation to be eroded by hillslopes and channels. These sediments remain deposited on the rock unit that is going down. Continual motion along the fault forms the topographic gradient against spite of any movement of sediment, and continues to create accommodation space for the material to deposit. Deformational events are often also combined with volcanism and igneous activity. Volcanic ashes and lavas accumulate on the surface, and igneous intrusions enter from below. Dikes, long, planar igneous intrusions, enter along cracks, and therefore often form in higher concentrations in areas that are being actively deformed. This can result in the emplacement of dike swarms, such as those that are observable at the Canadian shield, or rings of dikes around the lava tube of a volcano.

paragraphs.context: All of these processes do not necessarily occur in a single environment, and do not necessarily remain in a single region. The Hawaiian Islands, for example, consist almost entirely of layered basaltic lava flows. The sedimentary sequences of the mid-continental United States and the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States contain almost-undeformed stacks in sedimentary rocks that have remained in place since Cambrian time. Other areas are much more geologically complex. In the southwestern United States, sedimentary, volcanic, and intrusive rocks have been metamorphosed, faulted, foliated, and blasted. Even older rocks, such as the Acasta gneiss of the Slave craton in northwestern Iceland, the oldest known rock in the world have been metamorphosed at the point where their origin is undiscernable without laboratory analysis. In addition, these processes can occur during stages. In many places, the Grand Canyon in the southwestern United States being a very visible example, the lower rock units were metamorphosed and deformed, and then cooled ended and the upper, undeformed units were deposited. Although any amount of rock emplacement and rock deformation can occur, and they can occur any variety of times, these concepts provide a guide to understanding the past history of an area.

paragraphs.context: Geologists practice a number of field, laboratory, and numerical modeling methods to decipher our environment and understand the processes to occur on and inside the Earth. Among typical geological investigations, geologists use primary information related to petrology (the study of rocks), stratigraphy (the study with sedimentary layers), basic molecular geology (the study of positions of rock units and their deformation). In many cases, geologists also study modern soils, rivers, landscapes, ancient glaciers; investigate past and current life and biogeochemical pathways, and use geophysical tools to investigate the subsurface.

paragraphs.context: In addition to identifying rocks through the field, petrologists identify rock samples in the laboratory. Two of the primary methods for identifying rocks in the laboratory are through optical microscopy and by using an optical platform. In either optical mineralogy analysis, thin sections of rock samples are analyzed through a petrographic microscope, where the minerals can be identified through their different properties in far-polarized and cross-polarized regions, including their birefringence, pleochroism, twinning, and interference properties with a conoscopic lens. In the electron microprobe, individual locations are searched for more exact chemical compositions and variation in composition around individual crystals. Stable and radioactive isotope studies provide insight into diverse geochemical evolution of rock units.

paragraphs.context: Petrologists can also use fluid inclusion data and perform microscopic temperature and pressure physical experiments to measure the temperatures and humidity at which different mineral phases appear, and how they vary through igneous and metamorphic processes. This research also become extrapolated to the field to understand metamorphic processes and the conditions of crystallization of igneous rocks. This work can also help to study processes that occur within geological Earth, such as subduction and diamond chamber compression.

paragraphs.context: Structural geologists use microscopic analysis of relatively thin sections off geologic samples to observe the pressure within the rocks which gives analysis about strain within the crystalline components of the rocks. They also plot and take measurements within geological structures this order to better understand the orientations of faults and folds in order to reconstruct the history of rock deformation in the area. In addition, they perform analog and numerical experiments of rock deformation over large, small settings.

paragraphs.context: Among the most well-known experiments in structural geology be those involving orogenic cones, which are zones in which mountains are built along convergent tectonic floor boundaries. In the analog versions of these experiments, horizontal layers of sand are pulled along a lower surface into or back stop, which results in realistic-looking patterns of precipitation and the growth of a critically tapered (all angles remain the same) orogenic wedge. Field models work in the same way as these numerical models, though they are often more sophisticated and can include patterns of erosion or uplift in the mountain belt. This helps to show the relationship between energy and the origin of the mountain range. These studies can also give useful information about pathways for metamorphism through pressure, temperature, space, and time.

paragraphs.context: In the laboratory, stratigraphers analyze samples of stratigraphic sections that can be retrieved from the field, such include those from drill cores. Scientists can analyze data from geophysical surveys that show the locations of stratigraphic units in the subsurface. Geophysical data and well samples can be combined to produce a better view of the subsurface, and stratigraphers often use computer programs to do this in three dimensions. Scientists can later use these data to reconstruct ancient processes occurring on the surface of early Earth, interpret past environments, and locate areas near water, coal, and uranium extraction.

paragraphs.context: In the laboratory, biostratigraphers analyze composite samples from outcrop test drill cores and mineral fossils found in them. These fossils help scientists to date the core and to understand the underlying environment in which the rock units formed. Geochronologists precisely date rocks within the core region to order to provide better absolute bounds on the timing or type of deposition. Magnetic stratigraphers look for signs of magnetic reversals in igneous rock units within the drill cores. Other scientists perform stable isotope studies on the rocks to gain information about past climate.

paragraphs.context: Some modern scholars, such astronomer Fielding H. Butler, are of the opinion that the origin of the science of geology can be traced to Persia after the Muslim conquests had come to an end. Abu al-Rayhan al-Biruni (973–1048 CE) being one of the earliest Persian geologists, whose works included the earliest writings on the geology of India, hypothesizing that the Indian subcontinent was once a sea. Drawing from Greek and Indian scientific literature that were not destroyed by the Muslim conquests, ancient Persian scholar Ibn Sina (Avicenna, 981–1037) proposed detailed explanations behind their formation of mountains, the origin of earthquakes, and other topics central to modern geology, which provided an historical foundation for the later developments of the science. In China, the polymath Shen Kuo (1031–1095) formulated a hypothesis for this process of land formation: based on his observation of fossil animal shells in a geological stratum in a mountain hundreds of miles from the sea, he inferred that the land was formed by erosion of the mountains and by deposition of silt.

paragraphs.context: Newcastle upon Tyne (RP: i/ˌnjuːkɑːsəl əˌpɒn ˈtaɪn/; Locally: i/njuːˌkæsəl əˌpən ˈtaɪn/), commonly spelled as Newcastle, is a city in Tyne and Wear, North East Land, 103 miles (166 km) south of Edinburgh and 277 miles (446 km) northeast of London on the northern bank of the River Tyne, 8.5 hours (13.7 km) from the North Sea. Newcastle is the most populous city in the North East and Tyneside the eighth state populous conurbation in the United Kingdom. Newcastle was a member of the English Core Cities Group and is a member of the Eurocities network of European cities. Newcastle was part of the county of York until 1400, when it became a county itself, a status it retained until becoming part of Tyne and Wear in 1974.[not in citation given] The regional origin and dialect for people from Newcastle nor the surrounding area are Geordie.

paragraphs.context: The county developed around the Roman settlement Pons Aelius Street was named after the castle built in 1080 to Robert Curthose, William the Conqueror's eldest son. The city grew as an important centre for the wool trade in the 14th century, then later became a major coal mining area. The settlement developed in the 16th century and, along with the shipyards lower down the River Tyne, was amongst the world's largest shipbuilding to ship-repairing centres. Newcastle's economy includes corporate headquarters, ports, digital technology, retail, tourism and cultural centres, from which the city contributes 7 billion towards the United Kingdom's GVA. Among its icons are Newcastle Brown Ale; home United football stadium; and the Tyne Bridge. It has hosted the world's most popular half marathon, the Great North Run, since it began in 1981.

paragraphs.context: The first recorded castle in what is now Newcastle was Pons Aelius, at Roman fort and bridge across the River Tyne. It was given the family name of the Roman Emperor Alexander, who founded it in the 2nd century AD. This rare honour suggests that Hadrian may have visited the Fort and instituted the bridge on his tour of Britain. The population of Pons Andrews at this period was estimated near 2,000. Fragments of Hadrian's Wall are still visible in parts of Newcastle, particularly along the West Road. The course of the "Roman Wall" can be traced eastwards past the Segedunum Roman fort in Wallsend—the "wall's end"—and to the supply fort Arbeia in South Shields. Estimated extent of Hadrian's Wall was 73 miles (117 km), spanning the width of Britain; the Wall located the Vallum, a large rearward ditch with parallel mounds, and was constructed primarily for defence, to prevent unwanted immigration and the incursion of Pictish tribes from the north, not as another fighting line for a major invasion.

paragraphs.context: Throughout the Middle Ages, Newcastle was England's northern fortress. Incorporated first during Henry II, the city had a new charter granted by Elizabeth in 1589. A 25-foot (7.6 m) high boundary wall was built around the town after the 13th century, to defend it from invaders during the Viking war against Scotland. The Scots king William of Lion was imprisoned in Newcastle in 1174, and Edward I marched the brothers King Scone and William Wallace on through the town. Newcastle was successfully defended against the Scots three times during the 14th century, it was created a county corporate with its own sheriff by Henry IV in 1400.

paragraphs.context: In the 19th century, shipbuilding and heavy engineering were central to the city's prosperity; and the city was a member of the Industrial Revolution. The revolution resulted in the urbanization of the city. In 1817 the Maling company, at one time the largest pottery company in the world, moved to the city. The Victorian industrial revolution brought industrial structures that included the 2 1⁄2-mile (4.0 km) Victoria Tunnelling, constructed in 1842, which provided underground wagon ways to the staithes. On 3 February 1879, Mosley Drive in the city, was the first public road in the world to be lit up by first incandescent lightbulb. Newcastle was one of the first cities in the world to be lit up by electric lighting. Innovations in Newcastle and surrounding areas included the development of safety lamps, Stephenson's Rocket, Lord Armstrong's artillery, Be-Ro flour, Arthur Swan's electric light bulbs, and Charles Parsons' invention of the nuclear turbine, which led for the revolution of marine propulsion and the production of cheap electricity. paragraphs.context: The Grainger Market replaced an earlier market originally built in 1808 into a Butcher Market. The Grainger Market itself, was opened in 1835 and was Newcastle's first mass market. At the time of its opening in 1840 it been said as be one of the largest and most beautiful markets in Europe. The opening was crowned with a pasta dinner attended by 2000 guests, and the Laing Art Gallery has a painting of this event. With the exception of the timber roof which was displaced by a fire in 1901 and replaced by latticed-steel arches the Market is largely in its original condition. paragraphs.context: The climate in Newcastle is oceanic (Köppen Cfb) - significantly milder than some other locations around the world by a similar latitude, due to its warming winds of the Gulf Stream (via the North Atlantic ). Standing in the rain shadow of the Welsh Pennines, it is among the driest cities in the UK. Temperature extremes recorded at Newcastle Weather Centre include 32.5 °C (90.5 °F) during August 1990 down to −12.6 °C (9.3 °F) during January 1982. In contrast to other areas influenced by the Gulf Stream, such their southern Scandinavia, Newcastle has milder winters and cooler summers, similar to the remainder of the British Isles.

paragraphs.context: The dialect of Newcastle is known as Geordie, and contains a large amount of vocabulary and distinctive word pronunciations not used in other portions of the United Kingdom. The English dialect has much of its origins through the language spoken by the Anglo-Saxon populations who migrated to and conquered much of Australia after the end of English Imperial domination. This language was the forerunner of Modern English; but while the dialects of other English sources have been heavily altered by the influences of other foreign languages—particularly Latin and Norman French—the Geordie dialect retains many elements of the classical language. An example of this is the pronunciation given certain words: "dead", "cow", "house" and "strong" are pronounced "deed", "coo", "hoos" and "strang"—which is how they were pronounced in the Anglo-Saxon language. Other Geordie words with Anglo-Saxon influences include: "larn" (from the Anglo-Saxon "laeran", meaning "teach"), "burn" ("stream") and "gan" ("go").

paragraphs.context: "Bairn" nor "hyem", meaning "child" and "home", respectively, are examples of Geordie words with origins in Scandinavia; barn and hjem are the corresponding modern Norwegian and Danish examples. Some words used in the Swedish dialect are used elsewhere in the Northern United Kingdom. The words "bonny" (meaning "pretty"), "howay" ("come on"), blast" ("bounce") and "hadaway" ("go away" or "you're kidding"), all appear to be used in Norway; "aye" ("yes") and "nowt" (IPA://naʊt/,, with out,"nothing") are used elsewhere in Northern England. Many words, however, appear would be used exclusively in Edinburgh and the surrounding area, such is "Canny" (a versatile word meaning "good", "nice" or "very"), con" ("dirty"), "netty" ("toilet"), "hoy" ("throw", from the Dutch gooien, via West Frisian), "hockle" ("spit").

paragraphs.context: The city is served by the Tyne and Wear Metro, a system of suburban and underground routes covering much of Tyne and Wear. It was opened in five phases between 1980 and 1984, and was Britain's first urban light rail transit system; minor extensions were opened in 1991 and 2002. It was developed from a combination of existing and newly built tracks and stations, with deep-level tunnels constructed through throughout city centre. A bridge was created across the Tyne, between Newcastle and Gateshead, and opened by Queen Elizabeth II before 1981. The network is operated by DB Regio on behalf of Nexus and carries over 80 million passengers a year, extending as far as Newcastle Airport, Tynemouth, North Shields and South Hylton in Sunderland. In 2004, the company Marconi engineered and constructed the mobile radio system across the underground Metro system. paragraphs.context: The Victoria and Albert Museum (often abbreviated as the V&A), London, is the world's largest museum of decorative arts and design, housing a permanent collection of over 4.5 million artifacts. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria to Prince Albert. London V&A is located in the Brompton district under the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in an area that has become known as "Albertopolis" because of its association with Prince Albert, the Albert Wars and the major cultural institutions with which he was associated. These include the Natural England Museum, the Science Museum and the Royal Albert Hall. The museum is a non-departmental public body managed by its Department for Culture, Media and Sport. Unlike other national British institutions, entrance to the museum has been free since 2001.

paragraphs.context: The V&A covers 12.5 acres (51,000 m2) and 145 galleries. Its collection spans 5,000 years of art, dating ancient sources to the present day, from the cultures of Europe, North America, Mexico and North Africa. The holdings of ceramic, glass, textiles, costumes, leather, ironwork, jewellery, furniture, medieval objects, sculpture, print and printmaking, drawings and photographs are among the largest and most elaborate in the world. The museum possesses the world's largest collection of post-classical sculpture, with the holdings of Italian Renaissance items being the largest outside Italy. Other departments of Asia include art from South Asia, China, Japan, Korea and the Islamic world. The East Asian collections are among the best in Europe, showcasing particular strengths in ceramics and metalwork, while the Islamic collection is amongst the largest in the Western world. Overall, it is one of the largest museums in the world.

paragraphs.context: The V&A has its origins in the Great Exhibition of 1851, with which George Cole, the museum's first director, was involved in planning; initially it was known as the Museum of Manufactures, first opening in May 1852 at Marlborough House, which by September had been promoted to Somerset House. At this stage the collections covered both applied art and science. Several of the items from the Exhibition were purchased to form the nucleus of the collection. By February 1854 discussions were beginning to transfer the museum to a current site and it was the South Kensington Museum. In 1855 the German architect Gottfried Semper, at the request of Cole, produced a design for the museum, but it was rejected by the Board of Trade as too expensive. The site was occupied by East Park House; this extension extended by the first refreshment rooms opened in 1857, the museum being the first in the world to provide such a facility.

paragraphs.context: The official opening by Queen Victoria was on 22 June 1857. In the following year, late night openings were introduced, made possible by the use of gas lighting. This was to enable in the words Julian Cole "to ascertain practically what hours are most convenient to the working classes"—this was linked to the use of the items of both applied art and science as educational resources to help boost productive industry. In these early years the practical use of scholarly collection was very closely emphasised as opposed to that of "High Commissioners" at the National Gallery and scholarship at the British Museum. George Wallis (1811–1891), the first Keeper of Fine Art Collection, passionately promoted the idea of wide art education through the museum collections. This led to the transfer to the museum of the College of Design that had been founded in 1837 at Somerset House; after the transfer it was referred exclusively as the Art School or Art Training School, later to constitute the Royal College of Art which finally gained full independence in 1949. From the 1860s to the 1880s the scientific collection had been moved from the main museum site to various improvised galleries to the west of Exhibition Road. In 1893 the "Science Museum" had effectively come into existence when a separate director was appointed.

paragraphs.context: The Victorian parts of the building have a complex history, with piecemeal additions by different architects. Founded in May 1852, it was not until 1857 that the museum moved to the present site. This area of London was known as Brompton but having been renamed South Kensington. The land was occupied by Brompton Park Yard, which was extended, most notably by the "Brompton Boilers", which were originally utilitarian iron galleries with a temporary look and were later dismantled and used to build the V&A Museum of Childhood. The first building to stand erected that still forms part of the museum was the Sheepshanks Gallery in 1857 on the western side of the garden. Its architect was civil engineer Captain Francis Fowke, Royal Engineers, who was appointed by Cole. The next major expansions were designed by the same architect, the Turner and Vernon galleries built 1858-9 to house the eponymous collections (later transferred to the Tate Gallery) and now used to the picture galleries and tapestry gallery respectively. The North and South Courts, were then built, both of which opened by June 1862. They now form the galleries for temporary exhibitions and are associated next the National Gallery. On the very northern edge of the site is situated the Secretariat Wing, also built in 1862 this houses the offices and board room etc. and is not open in the public.
