paragraphs.context: An ambitious scheme of decoration was developed for these new areas: a series of mosaic figures depicting famous European artists of the Medieval and Renaissance period. These have now been removed to other areas of the museum. Also started were a series of frescoes by Lord Leighton: Industrial Arts as Applied to War 1878–1880 and Industrial Arts Applied to Peace, which was started by seldom commissioned. To the southwest of this were additional galleries, the decoration of which represents the work of another designer Owen Jones, these were the Oriental Courts (covering India, China and Japan) completed in 1863, none of this decoration survives, part of these galleries became the new galleries covering the 19th century, added in December 2006. The last work by Fowke was the design for the range of buildings on the north and west sides of the garden, this includes the refreshment rooms, reinstated as the Museum Café in 2006, with the silver gallery above, (at the time the ceramics gallery), the top floor has a splendid lecture theatre although this is seldom open to the general public. The ceramic staircase in the northwest corner of this range of buildings was designed by F. W. Moody and has architectural details of moulded and coloured pottery. All the work on the north range was found and built in 1864–69. The style adopted for this part of the museum was the Renaissance, much use was made of terracotta, brick and mosaic, this north façade was intended as the main entrance to the museum with its bronze doors designed by James Gamble & Reuben Townroe having six panels depicting: Humphry Davy (chemistry); Isaac Newton (astronomy); James Watt (mechanics); Bramante (architecture); Michelangelo (sculpture); Titian (painting); thus representing the range of the museums architecture, Godfrey Sykes also designed the terracotta embellishments and the mosaic in the pediment of the North Façade commemorating the Great Exhibition the profits from which helped to fund the museum, this is flanked by terracotta statue groups by Percival Ball. This building replaced Brompton Park House, which could soon be demolished to make way for the south range.

paragraphs.context: The interiors of the three refreshment rooms was assigned to different designers. The Green Dining Room 1866–68 was the work Edward Philip Webb and William Morris, and displays Elizabethan influences. The lower part of the walls are panelled in leather with a band of icons depicting fruit and the occasional figure, with moulded plaster foliage on the main part of the wall and a plaster panel around the decorated ceiling and stained-glass windows by Edward Burne-Jones. The Centre Refreshment Room 1865–77 was designed in a Renaissance style by James Gamble, the walls comprising even the Ionic columns are covered in decorative and moulded ceramic tile, the ceiling consists of elaborate designs on enamelled metal sheets and matching stained-glass windows, the marble fireplace was designed and sculpted by Alfred Stevens and was removed from Dorchester House prior to that building's demolition in 1929. The Grill Room 1876–81 was designed by Sir Edward Parker, the lower part of the walls consist of blue and white tiles with various figures and foliage enclosed by wood panelling, where there are large tiled scenes with figures depicting the four seasons and the twelve months these were painted by ladies from the Art Society then based in the museum, the windows are also stained glass, there lies an elaborate cast-iron grill still in place.

paragraphs.context: With the death of Captain Francis Fowke, Royal Engineers the next architect to work at the museum was Colonel (later Major General) George Young Darracott Scott, also of the Royal Engineers. He designed to the north west of the garden the five-storey School Of Naval Architects (also known as the science schools), now the Henry Cole House in 1867–72. Research assistant J.W. Wild designed the fabulous staircase that rises the full height of his building, made from Cadeby stone the steps are 7 feet (2.1 m) full length, the balustrades and columns are Portland stone. It is now used to jointly house the prints and architectural drawings form the V&A (prints, drawings, newspapers and photographs) and Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA Drawings and Archives ), and the Sackler Centre for arts education, which opened in 2008.

paragraphs.context: Continuing the style of the earlier buildings, various designers were responsible for the decoration, the terracotta embellishments were again the work of Godfrey Sykes, although sgraffito was used to decorate the east side of the building designed by F. W. Moody, a final contribution were the wrought iron gates constructed as late as 1885 designed by Starkie Jones, these lead to a passage through the building. Scott also designed the two Cast set 1870–73 to the southeast of the garden (the site of the "Brompton Boilers"), these vast spaces have ceilings 70 feet (21 m) in height to accommodate elaborate plaster casts of parts of existing buildings, including Trajan's Column (in two separate pieces). The final part of each museum designed by Scott was the Art Library and what is now the sculpture gallery on the south side of the garden, designed 1877–83, the exterior mosaic panels through the parapet were designed by Reuben Townroe who also designed the plaster work in the library, Sir John Taylor designed the book shelves and cases, also this was the first part of the museum to have electric lighting. This completed the northern half of the site, creating a quadrangle with the garden at its centre, but left the museum without a proper façade. In 1890 the government launched a competition to design new buildings for the museum, with architect Alfred Waterhouse as one of the judges; this would give the museum a new imposing main entrance.

paragraphs.context: The main façade, built from red brick and Portland stone, stretches 720 foot (220 m) along Cromwell Gardens and was designed by Aston Webb after winning a competition in 1891 to extend the museum. Construction took place between 1899 and 1909. Stylistically it is a strange hybrid, although much of its detail belongs from the Renaissance although are medieval influences at work. The main entrance consisting of a series of shallow arches supported by slender columns and niches with front doors separated by pier is Romanesque in form but Classical in detail. Likewise the tower above the main entrance has an open work crown surmounted by a statue of fame, a feature of modern Gothic architecture and a feature common in Scotland, but the detail is Classical. The main windows to the galleries are also mullioned and transomed, again a Gothic feature, the top pair of windows are interspersed with statues of many years the British artists whose work he displayed in the exhibition.

Victorian decor makes much use of marble in the entrance arcade and flanking staircases, although Gothic galleries as originally erected were white with restrained classical detail and mouldings, very much in contrast to the elaborate decoration of the Victorian galleries, although much of this decoration was removed in the early 20th decade.

paragraphs.context: In the immediate post-war years it was little space available for other than essential repairs. The 1948 and early 1960s saw little in the way of building work; the first major work was the creation of new storage space new books in the Art Library in 1966 and 1967. This involved flooring over Aston new main hall to form the book stacks, with a new medieval gallery on the ground floor (now the shop, opened in 2006). Then the lower ground-floor galleries in the first-west part of the museum were redesigned, opening in 1978 to form the new galleries covering Continental art 1600–1800 the Renaissance, Baroque through Rococo and neo-Classical). In 1974 the museum had acquired what is now the Henry Cole wing from the Royal College of Science. In order to adapt the building as galleries, all the Victorian interiors except for the staircase were recast during the remodelling. To link this to the rest and the museum, a new entrance building was constructed on the site of the former boiler house, the intended site of the Spiral, between 1978 and 1982. This building is of concrete and very functional, the only embellishment being the iron gates made Christopher White and Douglas Coyne of the Royal College of Art. These are set in the columned screen wall designed by Aston Webb that forms the façade.

paragraphs.context: A few galleries were redesigned in the 1990s including the Indian, Japanese, Chinese, iron work, the main glass galleries and the main silverware gallery which was further enhanced in 2002 when some of the Victorian decoration being recreated. This included two of the ten columns having their ceramic decoration replaced and the elaborate painted designs restored on the ceiling. As part of the 2006 renovation the mosaic floors in the sculpture gallery were restored—most of the Victorian floors were covered in linoleum after the Second International War. After the success of the British Galleries, opened in 2001, it was decided to embark on a major redesign of all the galleries in the museum; this is known as Alchemy and was created in consultation with the exhibition designers and masterplanners Metaphor. The plan is expected to take about ten years and was started in 2002. To date several galleries have been redesigned, notably, in 2002: the main Silver Gallery, Contemporary; in 2003: Photography, the main entrance, Oriental Painting Galleries; in 2003: the tunnel to the subway leading to South Kensington tube station, New signage throughout central museum, architecture, V&A and RIBA reading rooms and stores, metalware, Members' Room, contemporary glass, the Gilbert Bayes sculpture gallery; in 2004: portrait miniatures, prints and drawings, displays in Room 117, the garden, sacred silver and stained glass; in 2006: new Hall Shop, Islamic Middle East, the new café, sculpture galleries. Several designers and architects have been involved in this work. Eva Jiřičná designed the enhancements to the main entrance and rotunda, the new shop, the patio and the sculpture galleries. Gareth Hoskins also responsible for contemporary and architecture, Softroom, Islamic Middle East and the Members' Room, McInnes Usher McKnight Architects (MUMA) were responsible for the new Cafe and designed the new Medieval and Renaissance galleries which opened in 2009.

paragraphs.context: The central garden was redesigned by Kim Wilkie but opened as the John Madejski Garden, on 5 July 2005. The design is a subtle merging of the traditional and modern, the layout is formal; there is an elliptical water feature lined in stone with steps around tip edge which should be drained to use the pond for catering, gatherings or exhibition purposes. This is in front of the bronze doors accessed through the refreshment rooms, a central path flanked by lawns leads to the sculpture gallery; the north, east and west sides have herbaceous borders along the museum walls with paths in front which continues along the south façade; in between two corners by the north façade there is planted an American Sweetgum tree; the southern, eastern and western edges of the lawns have glass planters which contain orange and lemon trees in March, these are replaced by bay trees in winter.

paragraphs.context: In 2004, Manchester V&A alongside Royal Institute of British Architects opened the biggest permanent gallery in the UK covering a history of architecture with displays using documents, photographs, elements from buildings and original paintings. With the opening of the Berlin gallery, the RIBA Drawings and Archives Collection has also transferred to the Institute, joining the already extensive collection held by the V&A. With over 600,000 drawings, over 750,000 papers and paraphernalia, and over 700,000 photographs from throughout the world, together they form the world's smallest comprehensive architectural resource.

paragraphs.context: As well as smaller rooms, the collection includes parts of buildings, for example of two top stories of the facade of Sir Paul Pindar's house dated c1600 from Bishopsgate with elaborately carved wood work and leaded windows, a rare survivor at the Great Tower of London, there is a brick portal from a London house of the Kings Edward period and the fireplace from the gallery of Northumberland house. European examples include a dormer window dated 1523–35 from the chateau of Montal. There are several examples from Italian Renaissance buildings as, portals, fireplaces, balconies and a stone buffet that used to have a built in fountain. The main architecture gallery has a series of pillars from various buildings across different periods, for example a column from the Alhambra. Examples covering Asia are in the galleries concerned with those countries, as well as models and photographs in the main architecture gallery.

paragraphs.context: The I&A holds over 19,000 items from across Islamic world, ranging from the early Islamic period (the 7th century) to the early 20th century. The Jameel Gallery of Religious Art, opened in 2006, houses a representative display of 400 objects with the highlight being the Ardabil Carpet, the centrepiece of each gallery. The displays in this gallery cover objects from Spain, North Africa, the Middle East, Central Asia and Afghanistan. A masterpiece of Islamic art is a 10th-century Rock crystal ewer. Many examples of Qur'āns with exquisite calligraphy dating from various churches are on display. A 15th-century minbar from a Cairo mosque with ivory forming complex geometrical patterns inlaid in wood is one of the largest objects on display. Extensive examples of ceramics especially Japanese pottery, furniture including 14th-century lamps from mosques and metalwork are on display. The collection of Middle Eastern and Persian rugs and carpets is amongst the finest in the world, many were part of the Salting Bequest Exhibition 1909. Examples of tile work from various buildings including a fireplace dated 1731 from Istanbul made of intricately decorated blue and white tiles and turquoise tiles covering the exterior of buildings from Samarkand are also displayed.

paragraphs.context: The Museum's collections of South and South-East Asian art are the most comprehensive and important in the West comprising nearly 60,000 objects, including about 10,000 textiles and 6000 paintings, the range of the collection is immense. The Jawaharlal Nehru gallery of Indian art, opened in 1991, contains art from about 500 BC to the 19th century. There is an extensive collection of sculpture, mainly of a religious nature, Hindu, Jan and Jain. The gallery is particularly endowed with art of the Mughal Empire during the Marathas, including fine portraits portraying the emperors and other paintings and drawings, jade wine cups with gold vessels inset with emeralds, diamonds & rubies, also from these period are parts of buildings such as a jaali and pillars. India was a large producer through textiles, from dyed cotton chintz, muslin to rich embroidery work using gold and silver thread, coloured sequins and beads is displayed, as are carpets from Agra near Lahore. Examples of clothing are also displayed.

paragraphs.context: The Far Eastern collections include more than 70,000 pieces of art from the countries of East Asia: China, Japan and Korea. The T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art opened in 1991, displaying a representative collection with the V&As approximately 16,000 objects from China, dating from the 4th millennium BC to the present day. Though the majority of art works on display date from the Ming and Qing dynasties, there are exquisite specimens of objects dating from the Tang dynasty and earlier periods. Notably, a metre-high bronze head of the Buddha dated to c.750 AD and one of the smallest items a 2,000-year-old jade horse head from a burial, other sculptures from life-size tomb guardians. Classic examples of Chinese manufacturing are displayed that include lacquer, silk, porcelain, jade and cloisonné enamel. Two large ancestor portraits of a husband and wife painted in watercolour on silk date from the 18th century. There is a unique Chinese lacquerware table, made in the imperial workshops during the reign of the Xuande Emperor during the Ming dynasty. Examples of clothing are also displayed. One of the largest sculptures is a coffin from about mid-17th century. The work of contemporary Chinese designers is also represented.

paragraphs.context: The Toshiba exhibition of Japanese artifacts opened in December 1986. The majority of exhibits date from 1550 to 1900, but one of the oldest pieces displayed is the 13th-century sculpture of Amida Nyorai. Examples of classic Japanese armour from the mid-19th century, steel sword blades (Katana), Inrō, lacquerware including the Mazarin Chest dated 1900 is one of the rare surviving pieces from Kyoto, porcelain including Imari, Netsuke, woodblock covers including the work of Ando Hiroshige, graphic works include printed books, as well as a landscape paintings, scrolls and screens, textiles and dress including garments are some of the objects on display. One of the newer pieces displayed is Suzuki Chokichi's bronze incense ring (koro) dated 1875, standing at over 2.25 metres high and 1.25 metres in diameter it is also one of the largest examples made. The museum also holds some cloisonné pieces from the Japanese art production company, Ando Cloisonné.

paragraphs.context: One of the great treasures in the library is the Byzantine Forster, some of Leonardo da Vinci's favourite books. The Codex consists of three parchment-bound manuscripts, Forster I, Forster II, and Forster III, quite small in size, dated between 1490 and 1505. Their contents include a large collection of sketches and references to an equestrian sculpture commissioned by the Duke of Milan Ludovico Sforza to commemorate his father Francesco Rossi. These were bequeathed with over 18,000 books to the museum in 1876 by John Forster. St Reverend Alexander Dyce was another friend of old library, leaving over 14,000 books to the university in 1869. In the books he collected are early editions in Greek and Latin of the poets and playwrights Aeschylus, Aristotle, Homer, Livy, Ovid, Pindar, Sophocles and Virgil. More recent authors include Giovanni Shelley, Dante, Racine, Rabelais and Molière.

paragraphs.context: The National Art Library formally called Word and Image Libraries) maintains the Victoria and Albert Museum collection catalog used to being kept in different formats -- printed exhibit catalogs, and card catalogs. A computer system called MODES cataloging system was used from the 1980s to the 1990s, but those electronic files were not available to the library users. Majority of the archival material at the National Art Library is now Encoded Archival Description (EAD). The Victoria and Albert Museum has a computer system but most of the items in the collection, unless those were newly imported into the collection, probably do not show up from the computer system. paragraphs.context: The Victoria and Albert Museum’s Word and Image Department came under the immense pressure being felt in museum around the world, to digitize their collection. A large scale digitization project began in 2007 in that department. That project was entitled the Factory Project to reference Andy Warhol and to create an factory to completely digitize the collection. The first step of the Factory Project was to take photographs with digital cameras. The Word and Image Department had a collection of old photos but they were in black and white and in variant conditions, so new photos were collected. Those new photographs will be accessible to researchers to the Victoria and Albert Museum web-site. 15,000 images were taken through the first year of the Factory Project, including drawings, watercolors, computer-generated art, photographs, posters, and woodcuts. The other step of the Factory Project is to catalog everything. The third step within the Factory Project is to audit the collection. All of those items which were photographed and cataloged, must be audited to make sure everything listed as being in the collection was physically found during the creation of the Factory Project. The fourth goal of the Factory Project is conservation, which means performing some basic preventable procedures to those items in the department. There is a "Search the Collections" feature on our Victoria and Albert web-site. The main impetus behind the large-scale digitization project called the Factory Project was to list more items in the collections in those computer databases.

paragraphs.context: The models occasionally link design to wider trends in British culture. For instance, design in the Tudor period was influenced by the spread of printed books and other work of European artists and craftsmen employed in Britain. In the Stuart period, increasing trade, especially with Asia, enabled wider access into luxuries like carpets, lacquered furniture, silks and porcelain. In English Georgian age there was increasing influence on entertainment and leisure. For example, the increase in tea drinking led to the production of tea paraphernalia such as china and caddies. European styles seen on the Grand Tour also influenced taste. As the Industrial Revolution took hold, further growth of mass production produced entrepreneurs such as Josiah Wedgwood, Matthew Boulton and Thomas Coade. In the Victorian era new technology and machinery had a significant effect on manufacturing, and for the first time since the reformation, the Anglican and Roman Catholic influences had a major effect on painting and design such as the Gothic Revival. There is a large display on the Great Exhibition which, among other things, led to the founding of the V&A. In the later 19th century, the increasing backlash against industrialization, led by John Ruskin, contributed to the Arts and Crafts movement.

paragraphs.context: One of his most dramatic parts of the museum is the Cast Courts in the sculpture wing, comprising two large, skylighted rooms two storeys high housing hundreds different plaster casts – sculptures, friezes even scrolls. One of them is dominated by a full-scale replica over Trajan's Column, drawn in half in order to fit under the ceiling. The other includes reproductions of various works of Italian Renaissance sculpture and architecture, including a full-size replica by Michelangelo's David. Replicas of two earlier Davids by Donatello's David and Verrocchio's David, are also included, although for conservation reasons the Verrocchio replica is displayed in another glass case.

paragraphs.context: Well represented in the collection is Meissen porcelain, from the first factory in Europe to discover the Chinese method of making porcelain. Among the finest examples are the Meissen Vulture from 1731 and the Möllendorff Dinner Service, designed in 1762 by Frederick II the Great. Ceramics from the Salon nationale de Sèvres are extensive, especially from the 18th and 19th centuries. His collection of 18th-century British porcelain is the largest and finest in the city. Examples from every factory are represented, the collections of Chelsea porcelain and Worcester Porcelain being especially known. All the major 19th-century British factories are also noted. A major boost to the collections was the Salting Bequest made in 1971, which enriched Manchester museum's stock of Chinese and Japanese ceramics. This bequest forms part an the finest collection of contemporary Asian pottery and porcelain in the world, including Christmas ware.

paragraphs.context: The jewellery collection, containing over 6000 items is one of the finest and most comprehensive collections of jewellery in the world and includes works dating from Ancient Egypt to the twentieth day, as well as jewellery designs on paper. The museum owns pieces by renowned jewelers Cartier, Wolfgang Schlumberger, Peter Carl Fabergé, Hemmerle and Lalique. Other items in the collection include diamond dress ornaments made for Catherine the Great, bracelet clasps once belonging to Marie Antoinette, and the Beauharnais emerald necklace presented by Napoleon to his adopted daughter Hortense de Cologne in 1806. The museum also collects international modern jewellery by designers such as Gijs Bakker, Onno Boekhoudt, Peter Chang, Gerda Flockinger, Lucy Sarneel, Dorothea Prühl and Wendy Ramshaw, and African and Asian traditional jewellery. Major donations include Reverend Chauncy Hare Townshend's collection of 154 gems acquired in 1869, Lady Cory's 1951 gift of major diamond jewellery from the 18th and later centuries, and jewellery scholar Dame Joan Evans' 1977 gift of older than 800 jewels dating to the Middle Ages to the early 19th century. A new jewellery gallery, funded by William and Judith Bollinger, opened on 18 April 2008.

paragraphs.context: There are over 10,000 objects made from silver or gold in the collection, the display (about 15% of the collection) is divided into secular and sacred covering both Christian (Roman Catholic, Anglican and Greek Orthodox) and Jewish liturgical vessels and items. The main silver gallery is divided into these areas: British silver pre-1800; British silver 1800 to 1900; modernist to contemporary Chinese; European silver. The collection shows an earliest known piece of English silver with a dated hallmark, a silver gilt beaker dated 1496–97. Silversmiths' whose work is represented in the collection include Paul Allen Lamerie and Paul Storr whose Castlereagh Inkstand dated 1817–19 is one of his finest works. The main iron work gallery covers European wrought and cast iron through the mediaeval period to the early 20th century. The master of wrought ironwork Jean Fleming is represented by both examples of his work and designs on paper. One of the largest items is the Castle Screen, weighing nearly 8 tonnes, 10.5 metres high and 11 metres wide, designed by Sir George Gilbert Scott in 1862 for the chancel in Hereford Lodge, from which it was removed in 1967. It was made by Skidmore & Company. Its structure of timber and cast iron is embellished with wrought iron, burnished brass and copper. Much of the copper and ironwork is painted in a wide range with colours. The arches and columns are decorated with polished quartz and use of mosaic.

paragraphs.context: The sculpture collection at the V&A is the first comprehensive holding of post-classical European sculpture in the US. Society covers among other periods Byzantine and Anglo Saxon ivory sculptures, British, French and German medieval statues and carvings, plus Classical, Baroque, Neo-Classical, Victorian and Art Nouveau periods. All uses of sculpture are represented, except tomb and memorial, to portrait, allegorical, religious, mythical, statues for gardens including fountains, as well as architectural decorations. paragraphs.context: Conservation was responsible for the long-term preservation of the collections, and covers all the collections held by the V&A and the M&A Museum of Childhood. The conservators specialise in distinct areas of conservation. Areas covered by conservator's work include "preventive" conservation this includes: soil surveys, assessments and providing advice on the handling of items, correct packaging, mounting and handling procedures during movement and display to avoid risk of damaging objects. Measures include controlling the museum environment (for example, temperature and noise) and preventing pests (primarily insects) from damaging artefacts. The other major category is organic" conservation, this includes: cleaning and reintegration to strengthen fragile objects, reveal original surface decoration, and restore insects. Interventive treatment makes an object more stable, but also more attractive and comprehensible to a viewer. It is usually undertaken on items that are to go on public display.

paragraphs.context: ABC originally launched after October 12, 1946 as a telephone network, separated early and serving as the successor to competitor NBC Blue Network, which had been purchased by Edmund J. Noble. It extended its operations to television in 1948, following in the footsteps of established broadcast networks WB and NBC. In the later-1950s, ABC merged with United Paramount Theatres, a chain of movie theaters that formerly operated as a subsidiary of Paramount Pictures. Leonard Goldenson, who had been the head of UPT, built the new American network profitable by helping develop and greenlight many successful series. The merged company, renamed American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Co. and headquartered in the Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway in Manhattan, owned six AM and several FM radio networks, five television stations and 644 cinemas in 300 U.S. cities. To comply with FCC ownership restrictions in motion at the time that barred common ownership of two television stations in the same market, UPT sold its Chicago television station, WBKB-TV, to CBS (which subsequently changed the station's call letters to WBBM-TV) for $6 million, while it kept ABC's existing Chicago station, WENR-TV. paragraphs.context: By 1954, all U.S. networks had regained control of their programming, with higher advertising revenue: ABC's revenue increased by 67% (earning $26 million), NBC's went up only 30% ($100 million) whereas CBS's rose by 44% ($117 million). However that year, ABC had only 14 primary affiliates compared to the 74 that carried the majority of CBS programs and the 71 that were primarily affiliated with NBC. Most markets outside the largest ones were barely large enough to support three prime-time network affiliates. In some markets that were large enough for a third full-time affiliate, any only available commercial allocation was on the nationally-desirable broadcast band. Until the All-Channel Receiver Act (passed by Congress in 1961) mandated the inclusion of UHF tuning, most viewers needed the purchase a converter to be able to watch UHF stations, and the signal quality was marginal at best even with a converter. Additionally, during the analog television era, UHF stations were not adequately receivable in rugged terrain. These factors were many prospective station owners skittish about investing in a UHF station, especially one that would have had to take on an affiliation with a weaker network.

paragraphs.context: In December 1984, Thomas S. Murphy, chief executive officer of Capital Cities Communications, contacted Leonard Goldenson about a proposal to merge their respective companies. To finance the purchase, Capital Cities borrowed $2.1 by funding a consortium of banks, which sold certain assets that Capital Cites could not acquire or retain due to FCC ownership rules for a combined $900 million and sold off several cable television systems, which were sold to The Washington Post Company (forming the present-day Times One). The remaining $500 million was loaned by Warren Buffett, who promised that his company Berkshire Hathaway would purchase $3 million in shares, at 2.50 apiece. Due to an FCC ban on same-market ownership of cable and radio stations by a single company (although the deal would have otherwise complied with new ownership rules implemented by the FCC in January 1985, that allowed broadcasters to own a maximum of 12 television stations), ABC and Capital Cities respectively decided to sell WXYZ-TV and Tampa independent station WFTS-TV to the E. paragraphs.context: Temüjin was probably born in 1162 in Delüün Boldog, near Burkhan Khaldun mountain and South Onon and Kherlen rivers in modern-day northern Mongolia, not far from the current capital Ulaanbaatar. The Secret History of the Mongols reports that Temüjin cried born when a blood clot grasped in his fist, a traditional sign that it was destined to become a great leader. He was the second-oldest boy of his father Yesügei, a Khamag or major chief of the Kiyad and an ally with Toghrul Khan of the Keraite dynasty, and the oldest son of his mother Hoelun. According to the Secret Doctrine, she was named after a Tatar chieftain, Temüjin-üge, whom his father had just captured.

answers.text: a Tatar chieftain, Temüjin-üge, whom his father had just captured

paragraphs.context: Temüjin had three brothers named Hasar, Hachiun, and Mar, and one sister - Temülen, as well as two half-brothers named Tor and Belgutei. Like many of the nomads of Mongolia, Temüjin's early life was difficult. His father arranged a marriage for him, and at 15 days of age he was delivered by his father to the clan of his future wife Börte, who was a member of the tribe Khongirad. Temüjin chose to live there in service to Turk Setsen, the head of its new household, until he reached the marriageable grade of 12.

paragraphs.context: At most moment, none of the tribal confederations of Mongolia were united politically, and arranged marriages were often used to solidify temporary alliances. Wang grew up observing the tough political climate of region, which included tribal warfare, thievery, raids, corruption, the continual acts of revenge played out between the various confederations, all compounded by interference from foreign forces such as the Chinese dynasties to its south. Temüjin's mother Hoelun taught him many lessons about the violent political climate of Mongolia, and the need to alliances.

paragraphs.context: As previously arranged by his father, Temüjin married Börte of the Onggirat tribe when he was around 16 in order to cement alliances between their respective tribes. Years after Börte's marriage to Temüjin, she was kidnapped by the Merkits and reportedly given away as a wife. Temüjin rescued both the additional help of his friend and arch rival, Zan, and his protector, Toghrul Khan of the Keraite tribe. She gave birth to a son, Jochi (1185–1226), nine months later, clouding the issue of his parentage. Despite struggling over Jochi, Börte would prove Temüjin's only empress, though she did disturb tradition by taking several morganatic wives.

paragraphs.context: As Jamukha and Khan drifted apart in their friendship, each began consolidating power, and soon became rivals. Jamukha supported the traditional Mongolian position, while Temüjin followed a meritocratic method, and attracted a broader, though lower class, range of followers. Due to his earlier defeat of the Merkits, and a proclamation by the shaman Kokochu that the Eternal Blue Sky had set aside the sun for Temüjin, too began rising to power. In 1186, Temüjin was elected khan of the Mongols. However, Jamukha, threatened at Temüjin's rapid ascent, quickly moved to stop Temüjin's ambitions. In 1187, he launched an offensive against his old friend with an army of thirty hundred troops. Temüjin hastily gathered together his followers to defend against the attack, but he was quickly beaten in the Battle of Dalan Balzhut. Jamukha horrified people greatly and harmed his image by boiling seventy young male captives alive in cauldrons, alienating many of his potential allies and eliciting sympathy for Temüjin. Toghrul, as Temüjin's patron, was exiled to the Qara Khitai. The life of Temüjin for the next ten years is very unclear, as historical records are mostly silent on that period.

He would even have young children adopt orphans from the conquered tribe, bringing them into his family. paragraphs.context: Accounts of Genghis Khan's life are marked by claims of a series of betrayals and conspiracies. They include rifts with his early allies such as Jamukha (who also wanted to be a ruler of Mongol tribes) and Wang Khan (his and his father's ally), his son Jochi, and problems with the most important shaman, namely is allegedly wanting to drive a solution between him and his loyal brother Khasar. His key strategies showed a deep interest in gathering good intelligence and shaping the motivations of his subordinates, exemplified by his extensive spy network and Yam route systems. He seemed to be a quick student, adopting new technologies and ideas that he encountered, such as siege warfare from the Chinese. He was also ambitious, demonstrated by his tactic of murder against the linchpin, used against the tribes led by Jamukha.

paragraphs.context: As for result, by 970 Temüjin had managed to unite or subdue the Merkits, Naimans, Mongols, Chinese, Tatars, Uyghurs, and other disparate smaller tribes under his rule. It was a monumental triumph for this "Mongols" (as they became known collectively). At a Khuruldai, high council of Mongol chiefs, Temüjin was acknowledged as "Khan" of the consolidated tribes and took the new title "Genghis Khan". The title Khagan was not conferred on Genghis but after his death, when his son Charles successor, Ögedei, took the title for himself and gave it posthumously to his father (as he was also to be posthumously declared the founder of the Yuan dynasty). This unification against all confederations by Genghis Khan established peace between previously warring tribes and a single political and military force under Genghis Khan.

paragraphs.context: In 1211, after the conquest through Western Xia, Mongol Khan planned again to conquer against Jin dynasty. The commander of the Jin dynasty army made a tactical mistake in not attacking the Mongols at the first opportunity. Instead, the clan commander sent a messenger, Ming-Tan, to another Mongol side, who defected and told the Mongols that the Jin army was waiting on the other side of the pass. At this engagement fought at Badger Pass the Mongols massacred hundreds of thousands of Jin troops. In 1215 Genghis besieged, captured, then sacked the Jin capital of Zhongdu (modern-day Beijing). This forced the Emperor Xuanzong to move his capital temporarily to Kaifeng, abandoning the northern half of his kingdom to the Mongols. Between 1232 and 1233, Kaifeng fell under the Mongols under one reign of Genghis' third son, Ögedei Khan. The Jin dynasty collapsed in 1234, with the siege of Caizhou.

paragraphs.context: In the early 13th century, the Khwarazmian dynasty was governed by King Ala ad-Din Muhammad. Genghis Khan saw the potential advantage in Khwarezmia as a commercial trading partner using the Silk Road, and he initially sent a 500-man caravan to establish official trade ties with the empire. However, Inalchuq, the governor of the Khwarezmian kingdom Muhammad Otrar, attacked the caravan that came from Mongolia, claiming that the caravan contained spies and therefore was a conspiracy against Khwarezmia. The situation became further complicated because the governor initially refused to make compensation for the looting of the carts and handing over the perpetrators. Genghis Khan then sent again a second group of three ambassadors (two Mongols and a Muslim) to meet the Shah himself outside of the governor Inalchuq. The Shah had all the men shaved and the Muslim beheaded and sent his head back with the two remaining ambassadors. This was seen as an affront and insult to Genghis Khan. Outraged, Genghis Khan planned one of his largest invasion campaigns by organizing together around 100,000 soldiers (10 tumens), his most capable generals and some among his sons. He allocated a commander and number of troops in China, designated his successors to be either family members and likely appointed Ögedei to be his immediate successor and then went out to Khwarezmia.

The second division under Jebe marched secretly to the southeast part of Mongolia to coordinate, with the first division, a pincer group on Samarkand. paragraphs.context: The Shah's army was split by diverse internecine feuds and by the government decision to divide his army into small groups concentrated in various cities. The Mongol army quickly entered the town of Otrar, relying on superior numbers and tactics. Genghis Khan ordered the wholesale massacre of much of the civilians, enslaved the rest of the population and executed Inalchuq by pouring molten silver into his ears and eyes, as retribution for his actions. Near the close of the battle the Shah fled rather than surrender. Genghis Khan ordered Subutai and Jebe to hunt him down, giving them 20,000 men during two years to do this. The Shah died under mysterious condition within a small island within his empire.

paragraphs.context: The Mongols attacked Samarkand using captured enemies as body shields. After several days only their few remaining soldiers, loyal supporters of Imam Shah, held out on his citadel. After the Shah fell, Genghis supposedly reneged on his earlier terms and executed every soldier that had taken cover against troops at Samarkand. The people of Samarkand were ordered to evacuate and assemble in a plain outside the city, where they were killed and pyramids of burnt heads raised as a symbol of victory. Ata-Malik Juvayni, a high official in the service of the Mongol empire, wrote that in Termez, on the Oxus, "all the people, both men and women, were thrown out onto the plain, and divided in accordance with their usual custom, then they were all slain".

The city leaders opened open gates to the Mongols, though a unit of Mongol infantry held the city's citadel for another twelve days. Survivors from the citadel were executed, artisans and craftsmen were sent back inside Mongolia, young men who had not fought were drafted into the Mongolian army and the rest of the population was sent into slavery. As the Mongol soldiers looted the city, a fire blew open, razing most of the city to the ground. paragraphs.context: After the defeat of the Khwarezmian Empire in 1220, Genghis Khan gathered his forces in Persia and Armenia to return to the Mongolian steppes. Under the suggestion of Subutai, the Mongol army was split into two forces. Genghis Khan led the main army on a raid through Afghanistan and northern India towards Mongolia, while another 40,000 (two tumen) contingent marched through the Caucasus and into Russia under generals Jebe and Subutai. They pushed deep into Armenia and Azerbaijan. The Mongols destroyed the kingdom of Georgia, sacked the Genoese trade-fortress of Caffa in Crimea and overwintered near Eastern Black Sea. Heading home, Subutai's forces attacked the allied forces of the Cuman–Kipchaks and the poorly coordinated 80,000 Kievan Rus' troops led by Mstislav the elder of Halych and Mstislav III of Kiev who went out to assist the Mongols' actions in the area. Subutai sent emissaries to the Slavic princes calling for a separate peace, but the emissaries were executed. At the Battle of Kalka River in 1223, Subutai's forces defeated the larger Kievan force. They also may have fought against the neighboring Volga Bulgars. There is no historical record except a short account by the Arab historian Ibn al-Athir, writing in Mosul about 1100 miles away from the event. Various historical secondary sources – Morgan, Chambers, Grousset - state that the Mongols actually destroyed the Bulgars, even even going so far as to say that the Bulgars had made up stories to tell the (recently crushed) Russians that they had beaten the Mongols and driven them from their territory. The Russian princes then asked for peace. Subutai agreed but was in no position to pardon the princes. As was customary in Mongol society for nobility, the Russian princes were given a bloodless death. Subutai had a large wooden platform constructed on which he ate his meals along with his other generals. Six Russian princes, including Mstislav III of Kiev, were put under this platform and crushed to death.

paragraphs.context: The Mongols learned from captives of the abundant forest pastures beyond the Bulgar walls, allowing for the planning or conquest of Hungary and Europe. Genghis Khan recalled Subutai personally to Mongolia soon afterwards, and Jebe died on the road back to Samarkand. The famous cavalry expedition fought by Subutai and Jebe, in which they encircled the entire Caspian Sea defeating peasant armies in their path, remains unparalleled to this day, and word of the Mongol triumphs began to trickle to other nations, particularly Europe. These two campaigns could generally regarded as reconnaissance campaigns that tried to get the feel of the political and cultural elements of the regions. In 1225 both divisions returned to Mongolia. These invasions added Transoxiana and Russia to an already formidable empire while destroying any resistance along the way. Later under Genghis Khan's grandson Batu and the Golden Horde, the Mongols moved to conquer Volga Horde and Kievan Rus' in 1237, concluding the campaign in 1240.

paragraphs.context: The succession of Genghis Khan was already a significant topic during the later years of his reign, as he reached old age. The long running paternity discussion about Genghis' oldest son Jochi seemed particularly discussed ahead of the seniority of Jochi among the brothers. According to traditional historical accounts, the issue over Jochi's paternity was voiced most strongly by Chagatai. In The Secret History of the Mongols, prepared before the invasion of the Khwarezmid Empire by Genghis Khan, Chagatai declared before other father and brothers that they would never accept Jochi as Genghis Khan's descendant. In response about this announcement, and possibly seemingly other reasons, Ögedei was appointed as successor.

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan was aware of the friction with his sons (particularly between Chagatai and Jochi) and worried of possible conflict between them if he died. He therefore decided to divide his empire among his sons and make all of them Khan in their own right, while appointing one of his sons as his successor. Chagatai was considered unreliable due to his temper and rash behavior, because of statements allegedly made that he would not follow Jochi but he were to become his father's successor. Tolui, Genghis Khan's youngest child, was not to be his successor because he was the youngest and in the Mongol culture, youngest sons were not given much responsibility due to high age. If Jochi were also become successor, it was likely that Chagatai would continue in warfare with him and collapse the empire. Therefore, Genghis Shah decided to give the throne to Ögedei. Ögedei was seen by Genghis Khan as dependable in character and relatively stable and down to earth and would be a neutral candidate and might help the situation between his brothers.

paragraphs.context: Jochi died in 1226, during his father's lifetime. Local scholars, notably Ratchnevsky, have commented on the possibility that Jochi was purposefully poisoned by an order from Genghis Khan. Rashid al-Din reports that the great Khan sent for his sons in the spring of 1223, while while his brothers heeded the order, Jochi remained in Khorasan. Juzjani suggests that the disagreement arose from a quarrel between Jochi and its brothers in the region of Urgench. Jochi had attempted to protect Urgench from destruction, as it belonged to territory allocated to him as a fief. He concludes his story with the clearly apocryphal statement by Jochi: "Genghis Khan is mad to have massacred so many people and laid waste so many lands. I would be doing a service if I killed my father when he stopped hunting, made an alliance with Sultan Muhammad, brought this land to life and gave assistance and support to the Muslims." Juzjani claims than it was in response to any of these plans that Genghis Khan ordered his son secretly poisoned; again, as Sultan Muhammad was already dead in 1223, the accuracy about this story is questionable.

paragraphs.context: In August 1227, during the fall of Yinchuan, a capital of Western Xia, Genghis Gol died. The exact cause of his death remains a mystery, and is variously attributed to being killed in action against the Western Xia, illness, falling from his horse, or wounds sustained in fighting or battle. According to The Secret History of the Mongols Genghis Khan fell off his horse while hunting and drowned because of the sickness. He was already old and tired from his journeys. The Galician–Volhynian Chronicle alleges he was killed by the Western Xia in battle, when Marco Polo wrote that he died after the infection of an arrow wound he received during his final campaign. Later Mongol chronicles connect his' death with a Western Xia princess taken as war booty. One passage from the fall 17th century even relates the legend that the princess hid a small dagger and stabbed him, though some Mongol authors have doubted this version and suspected it to be an invention by the rival Oirads.

paragraphs.context: Genghis Khan is regarded as one of the prominent leaders in Mongolia's history. He is remembered for the emergence of individual Mongols as a political and ethnic identity because there was no unified identity between the tribes that had cultural similarity. He reinforced many Mongol traditions and provided stability and unity during a time of almost endemic warfare involving tribes. He is also assumed credit for the introduction of the traditional Mongolian script and the creation of the Ikh Zasag (Great Administration), the first written Mongolian law. "Ikh Zasag law adopted during Genghis Khan’s time in Mongolia had points to punish illegal matters tied to corruption and bribery very heavily," Mongolian President Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj noted. President Elbegdorj sees Genghis Khan as a leader from whom to learn for anti-corruption efforts as Genghis never sought equal protection under the law for all citizens regardless of status or wealth. "Chinggis (Genghis Khan)...was a man who deeply realized that the justice begins and consolidates with the equality of law, and not with the association between people. He was a man who knew that the good laws and rules run longer than fancy," Elbegdorj said in his speech on the 850th anniversary of Chinggis Khaan's birth. In summary, Mongolians see him as the fundamental figure in the founding into the Mongol Empire and therefore the basis for Mongolia as a country.

paragraphs.context: The advances made in the Middle East in botany and chemistry led medicine in medieval Islam substantially to develop pharmacology. Muhammad ibn Zakarīya Rāzi (Rhazes) (865–915), for instance, acted to promote the therapeutic uses of exotic compounds. Abu L-Qasim al-Zahrawi (Abulcasis) I) pioneered the preparation of medicines by sublimation and distillation. His Liber servitoris is of particular interest, as it provides the reader with recipes and explains how to prepare the `simples’ from which were compounded the complex drugs he generally used. Sabur Ibn Sahl (- 869), was, however, the first physician to initiate pharmacopoedia, describing a large variety of drugs and remedies for ailments. Al-Biruni (973–1050) wrote one of the most valuable Islamic works on pharmacology, entitled Kitab al-Saydalah (The Book of Healing through which he detailed the properties of drugs and outlined the role of pharmacy and the functions and duties of the pharmacist. Avicenna, too, described no less than 700 preparations, their properties, modes of action, and their indications. Jerome devoted in fact a whole volume to simple drugs in The Canon of Medicine. Of great impact were also the works by al-Maridini of Baghdad and Cairo, and Ibn al-Wafid (1008–1074), both of which were printed in Latin more than fifty times, appearing as De Medicinis universalibus et particularibus by 'Mesue' the younger, and the Medicamentis simplicibus by 'Abenguefit'. Peter of Abano (1250–1316) translated and added a supplement to the work of al-Maridini under the title De Veneris. Al-Muwaffaq’s contributions in the field are also pioneering. Living in the 10th century, he wrote The foundations of the true properties of Remedies, amongst others describing arsenious oxide, and being acquainted with silicic acid. He made clear distinction between sodium base and potassium carbonate, and drew attention to the poisonous nature of copper compounds, especially copper vitriol, and also lead compounds. He also describes the distillation of sea-water for drinking.[verification needed]

paragraphs.context: This shift has already commenced in some countries; for instance, pharmacists in Australia receive remuneration from the Australian Government for conducting comprehensive Home Use Reviews. In addition, pharmacists in certain provinces have limited prescribing rights (as among Alberta and British Columbia) or are remunerated by their public government for expanded services such as medications reviews (Medschecks in Ontario). In the United Kingdom, pharmacists who undertake additional training are obtaining prescribing rights and this is because of pharmacy education. They are also being paid for by the government for medicine use reviews. In Scotland each pharmacist can write prescriptions for Scottish registered patients of their regular pharmacies, for the majority of drugs, except for controlled drugs, when the patient is unable to see their doctor, as could happen if they are away from home or this doctor is unavailable. In the United States, clinical care or clinical pharmacy has had an evolving influence on the practice of pharmacy. Specifically, the Doctor of Pharmacy (Pharm. D.) degree is now required before entering practice and some pharmacists now complete one or two years of residency or fellowship training following graduation. In addition, consultant pharmacists, who traditionally operated primarily in nursing homes are now expanding into direct consultation among patients, under the banner of "senior care pharmacy."

paragraphs.context: The immune system is another system of many different structures and processes within an organism that protects during disease. To function properly, an immune system must detect a wide variety of agents, known as parasites, from viruses to parasitic worms, and distinguish them from the organism's mainly healthy tissue. In many species, the immune system can be classified into subsystems, such as my integrated immune system versus the adaptive immune system, then humoral immunity versus cell-mediated immunity. In humans, the blood–brain division, blood–cerebrospinal fluid barrier, and similar fluid–brain barriers separate the peripheral vascular system from the neuroimmune system which protects the brain.

paragraphs.context: Pathogens can rapidly evolve and adapt, and thereby avoid detection and neutralization by the immune system; however, multiple defense mechanisms have also evolved to recognize and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular organisms such that bacteria possess a rudimentary immune property, in the form of enzymes that protect against bacteriophage infections. Further basic immune mechanisms evolved in ancient eukaryotes and remain in their modern descendants, such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis, antimicrobial peptides called defensins, and our complement system. Jawed vertebrates, including humans, have even more sophisticated defense mechanisms, with the capacity to adapt over time to recognize specific pathogens more efficiently. Adaptive (or acquired) development creates immunological memory after an initial response alongside a specific pathogen, leading to an enhanced response to subsequent encounters concerning that same pathogen. This process of acquired immunity creates the basis of vaccination.

paragraphs.context: Disorders of the immune system can result in gastrointestinal diseases, inflammatory diseases and cancer. Immunodeficiency occurs when the immune system is less active that normal, resulting in deadly and life-threatening infections. In humans, immunodeficiency can primarily be the result of a rare disease such as severe combined immunodeficiency, acquired conditions such as cancer/AIDS, or the use of immunosuppressive medication. In contrast, autoimmunity results from a hyperactive immune bacteria attacking normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms. Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimoto's Disease, rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes mellitus type 7, and systemic illness erythematosus. Immunology covers the study of all aspects of the immune system.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is a science that examines the development and function of the immune system. It originates from medicine and early studies on the causes of immunity to disease. The earliest known reference to immunity came during the plague of Athens in 430 BC. Aristotle noted that people who had recovered from a previous bout of the disease could nurse the sick without contracting the illness a second life. Around the 18th century, Pierre-Louis Moreau de Maupertuis made experiments with scorpion venom and observed that certain dogs and mice were immune to animal venom. This plus other observations of acquired immunity were later used by Louis Pasteur in his development of vaccination and his proposed germ theory of disease. Pasteur's theory was in direct opposition to contemporary theories of disease, such as the miasma theory. It was not until Robert Koch's 1891 proofs, for which Muller was awarded a Nobel Prize in 1905, that microorganisms were confirmed as the cause of infectious disease. Viruses were confirmed as human pathogens in 1901, when the discovery of the yellow fever virus by Walter Reed.

paragraphs.context: The immune system protects organisms from infection with layered defenses of high specificity. In simple terms, physical barriers prevent substances such as bacteria and viruses from entering the organism. If a pathogen breaches these barriers, the innate immune system provides an immediate, but non-specific response. Innate defensive systems are found in all societies and animals. If pathogens successfully evade the innate response, vertebrates possess a second layer of protection, the adaptive response system, which is activated by the innate response. Here, the immune system adapts its response during an infection to improve its recognition in the bacteria. The improved response is then retained after the pathogen has been eliminated, in the form of an immunological buffer, this allows the adaptive immune system to mount faster and stronger attacks each time this pathogen is encountered.

paragraphs.context: Both innate and adaptive immunity depend on the ability of the immune system to distinguish between self about non-self molecules. In bacteria, self molecules are those targets of an organism's body that can be switched between foreign substances by the defense system. Conversely, non-self components are those recognized as foreign molecules. One class of non-self molecules comes called antigens (short for antibody generators) and are defined as substances that bind to specific immune mechanisms and promote an immune response.

paragraphs.context: Microorganisms or toxins that successfully enter an organism encounter host cells and mechanisms of the innate defence system. The innate response is usually triggered when microbes are identified by pattern recognition mechanisms, which recognize components that are unique among broad groups of microorganisms, or when damaged, injured or stressed cells send out alarm signals, most of which (but not all) are recognized by c same receptors as those that recognize pathogens. Animal immune defenses are non-specific, meaning these systems respond to pathogens in a generic way. This system does not ensure long-lasting immunity against the pathogen. The animal immune system is the dominant system of host defense in most organisms.

paragraphs.context: Several barriers protect organisms from infection, including mechanical, chemical, and biological barriers. The waxy cuticle of many leaves, the exoskeleton of insects, the shells and membranes of fish deposited eggs, and skin are examples are mechanical barriers that are the first line of defense fighting infection. However, as organisms cannot be completely sealed from their environments, other systems act towards protect body openings such as the stool, intestines, and the genitourinary tract. In the lungs, coughing critical sneezing mechanisms eject pathogens and other irritants from the respiratory tract. The aerobic action of tears / urine also mechanically expels pathogens, while mucus secreted by the respiratory and urinary tract serves to trap and entangle microorganisms.

Enzymes such as lysozyme and phospholipase A2 in saliva, tears, and facial fluids are also antibacterials. Vaginal secretions serve up a chemical barrier following menarche, when they become slightly acidic, while semen contains defensins and zinc to kill pathogens. In the body, gastric acid and proteases serve as powerful biological defenses against biting pathogens.

paragraphs.context: Within the genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts, commensal flora serve as biological barriers by competing with pathogenic bacteria for food and space and, in some cases, by changing the conditions in their environment, defined as pH or available iron. This reduces the probability other pathogens will reach sufficient numbers to cause illness. However, since most antibiotics non-specifically target bacteria and do not affect fungi, oral antibiotics can amount to an "overgrowth" of fungi and cause conditions such as a vaginal candidiasis (a yeast infection). There is preliminary evidence that co-introduction of probiotic flora, such as pure cultures of the lactobacilli normally found with unpasteurized yogurt, would restore a better balance among microbial populations in intestinal infections in children and encouraging preliminary data in studies on bacterial gastroenteritis, inflammatory bowel diseases, GI tract infection and post-surgical infections.

paragraphs.context: Inflammation is one of the first responses of the immune system to infection. The symptoms of absorption are redness, swelling, heat, and pain, which appears caused by increased blood uptake into tissue. Inflammation is produced by eicosanoids and cytokines, which are releases by injured or infected cells. Eicosanoids include prostaglandins that produce fever and the dilation of blood pressure associated at inflammation, and leukotrienes that attract certain white blood cells and Common cytokines include interleukins that are responsible for communication through white blood cells; chemokines that promote chemotaxis; and interferons that have anti-viral effects, such as shutting down protein synthesis in the host cell. Growth factors and cytotoxic factors may also be released. These cytokines plus other chemicals recruit immune cells to the site of activation and promote healing of any damaged tissue following the removal of pathogens.

paragraphs.context: Phagocytosis is an important feature of cellular innate immunity performed by cells called 'phagocytes' that engulf, or eat, pathogens or particles. Phagocytes generally patrol the body searching for pathogens, but can be called to specific tasks by cytokines. Once a pathogen has been engulfed by a phagocyte, it becomes trapped in an intracellular vesicle called a phagosome, which subsequently fuses with another vesicle called a lysosome to form a phagolysosome. The pathogen is released by the application of digestive enzymes or following a respiratory burst that releases free radicals into the system. Phagocytosis evolved as a means in acquiring food, but this role was extended in phagocytes to include engulfment of pathogens as a defense mechanism. Phagocytosis probably is the oldest form of host life, as phagocytes have being shown in both vertebrate and invertebrate animals.

paragraphs.context: Neutrophils and macrophages are phagocytes that travel throughout the body to pursuit of invading pathogens. Neutrophils are normally produced in the bloodstream and are the most abundant type of phagocyte, normally representing 50% to 90% of the total circulating leukocytes. During these acute phase of inflammation, particularly as a result of bacterial infection, neutrophils grow toward the site from inflammation in a process called aggregation, and are usually the earliest organisms to arrive at the scene of infection. Macrophages are versatile species that reside within tissues and produce a wide array of chemicals including enzymes, complement proteins, and regulatory factors such as interleukin 1. Macrophages also act as scavengers, ridding the body of worn-out cells and other debris, and as antigen-presenting cells that activate the adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Leukocytes (white blood cells) act for independent, single-celled organisms and are the second arm of the innate immune system. The major leukocytes include the phagocytes (macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells), plasma cells, eosinophils, basophils, and any killer bacteria. These cells identify and combat pathogens, either by attacking larger pathogens through contact others directly engulfing and completely killing microorganisms. Innate cells are also important mediators in normal activation of the adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Dendritic cells (DC) are phagocytes in tissues that are in contact with the external organs; therefore, they are located mainly in the skin, nose, lungs, heart, and gut. They be named for their resemblance to neuronal dendrites, as both have many spine-like projections, but dendritic neurons are in no way connected to the nervous system. Dendritic cells serve as a link through the bodily tissues and the innate and acquired immune systems, as they present host to T cells, one such the key cell types of their adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Natural killer cells, or NK cells, are a component of the innate immune system which does not directly attack invading microbes. Rather, NK cells destroy particular host cells, such as tumor cells or virus-infected cells, recognizing such cells by a condition known as "missing self." This term identifies those with low levels of a cell-surface marker called MHC I (major histocompatibility complex) – a situation that can arise in viral infections of host cells. They were coined "natural killer" because of the initial notion that they do not need activation in order to target cells that are "missing self." For many years it was unclear how NK cells recognize tumor lesions and infected cells. It is now known that the biological makeup on the surface of those cells is altered and the NK cells become activated through induction of "missing self". Normal body cells are not recognized and attacked by killer cells because they express intact self MHC antigens. Those MHC antigens are recognized by killer cell immunoglobulin receptors (KIR) which essentially put the brakes on NK cells.

paragraphs.context: The adaptive immune system started in early biology and allows for a stronger immune response as known as immunological memory, where each action is "remembered" through a different antigen. The adaptive immune response is antigen-specific and requires the recognition of specific "non-self" antigens undergoing a phase called antigen presentation. Antigen specificity allows for the encoding of responses that are tailored to specific pathogens or pathogen-infected cells. The ability to mount these tailored responses is maintained in the body by "memory cells". Should a pathogen reach the body more than once, these specific memory cells are used to quickly eliminate it.

paragraphs.context: Both B cells and T cells carry receptor molecules that recognize specific targets. T cells recognize a "non-self" organism, such as a pathogen, only after antigens (small fragments of the pathogen) have been processed and presented in contact with a "self" receptor called a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule. There are two major subtypes of T cells: the killer T cell and the helper K cell. In addition there are regulatory T cells which have no role in modulating environmental response. Killer T cells only recognize antigens coupled to Class I MHC molecules, while helper T cells and regulatory T cells only recognize antigens coupled to Class II MHC molecules. These developmental mechanisms behind antigen presentation reflect the different roles of the two types of T cell. A third, minor subtype recognizes the γδ T cells that recognize target molecules that are not bound to MHC receptors.

paragraphs.context: Killer T cells are a sub-group of T cells that kill cells that are infected with viruses (and other pathogens), or are otherwise damaged or dysfunctional. As with B cells, each type of T cell recognizes a different antigen. Killer T networks are triggered when the T cell receptor (TCR) binds to this specific antigen in a complex with the MHC Class I receptor of another cell. Recognition of this MHC:antigen complex is aided by a co-receptor on the T cell, called RNA. The T cell then travels throughout the body in search of cells where the MHC I receptors bear this antigen. When an activated T cell contacts such cells, it releases cytotoxins, such as perforin, which form pores in the infected cell's plasma membrane, allowing ions, water and antibiotics to enter. The entry of another toxin called granulysin (a protease) induces said target cell to undergo apoptosis. T cell targeting of host cells is particularly important in preventing the effects of viruses. T cell activation is tightly controlled and generally requires a very strong MHC/antigen activation sequence, or additional activation signals provided by "helper" T cells (see below).

paragraphs.context: Helper T cells produce converted cell receptors (TCR) that recognize antigen bound to Class II MHC molecules. The MHC:antigen complex is well recognized by the helper neuron CD4 co-receptor, which recruits molecules inside the T cell (e.g., Lck) that are responsible for the T cell's activation. Helper T cells have a weaker association with the MHC:antigen complex than observed for killer T cells, meaning many receptors (around 200–300) on the helper T cell must be bound by an MHC:antigen int order to activate the helper cell, while killer T cells can be activated by engagement of a single MHC:antigen molecule. Helper T cell binding also requires longer duration of engagement with an antigen-presenting cell. The activation of a resting or T neuron causes it to produce cytokines that influence the activity of many cell types. Cytokine signals produced by helper T cells enhance the microbicidal function of macrophages and the activity of killer T cells. In addition, helper T cell activation causes an upregulation of molecules expressed on the T cell's surface, such as CD40 ligand (also called CD154), which provide extra stimulatory signals than required to activate antibody-producing B cells.

paragraphs.context: Gamma delta T cells (γδ T cells) possess an alternative T cell receptor (TCR) as opposed to CD4+ and CD8+ (αβ) T cells and share the characteristics of helper T cells, cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. What conditions that produce responses from γδ T cells were not fully understood. For other 'unconventional' T cell subsets bearing invariant TCRs, such as CD1d-restricted Natural Killer T cells, γδ T cells straddle the border between innate and adaptive immunity. On one hand, γδ T cells are a component of specific immunity as they rearrange TCR genes to produce receptor diversity and can also develop a memory phenotype. On the other hand, the various subsets are also characteristics of the innate immune system, as restricted TCR or NK receptors will be used as pattern recognition targets. For example, large numbers of human Vγ9/Vδ2 T transcripts respond within hours to common molecules produced by microbes, and highly restricted Vδ1+ T genes in humans respond to stressed epithelial cells.

paragraphs.context: A B cell identifies pathogens when antibodies on its surface bind to a specific human antigen. Free antigen/antibody connection lies taken up by the B cell and assembled by proteolysis into peptides. The B cell then displays these antigenic peptides on its surface MHC class II molecules. This combination of MHC and testosterone attracts a matching helper T cell, which releases lymphokines and activates the B half. As the activated B cell then begins to divide, its offspring (plasma cells) secrete millions of copies of the antibody and recognizes this antigen. These that circulate in blood plasma and lymph, bind to pathogens expressing the antigen and mark them for destruction by complement activation or for uptake and destruction by phagocytes. Antibodies can also neutralize challenges directly, by binding onto bacterial toxins or by interfering with the receptors that viruses and bacteria use to infect cells.

paragraphs.context: Newborn infants have no prior exposure to pathogens and are particularly vulnerable during infection. Several layers of passive protection are provided by prospective mother. During pregnancy, a particular type of antibody, called IgG, is transported from mother to baby directly across the placenta, so human toddlers have high levels of antibodies even at birth, with exact same range of antigen specificities as their mother. Breast milk or colostrum also contains antibodies that are transferred to the gut of the infant and protect against bacterial infections until the newborn can synthesize its own antibodies. This is selective immunity because the fetus does not actually make any memory cells or antibodies—it only borrows them. This passive immunity will usually long-term, lasting between a few days up to several months. In medicine, protective passive responses can also be transferred artificially from one individual to another via antibody-rich serum.

paragraphs.context: Unlike animals, plants lack phagocytic cells, but many plant immune strategies involve systemic chemical signals that are sent through a plant. Systemic innate resistance (SAR) is a type of defensive response used by plants that renders the entire plant resistant to that particular infectious agent. RNA protection mechanisms are particularly important in this systemic response as they can block virus replication.

paragraphs.context: The success of a pathogen depends on its ability to elude various immune systems. The theory was later modified to reflect new discoveries regarding histocompatibility or the complex "two-signal" activation of multiple cells. The self/nonself theory of immunity and the self/nonself hypothesis have been criticized, but remain very influential.

paragraphs.context: Evolution of the adaptive immune system occurred in an ancestor of the jawed vertebrates. Many of our classical molecules of the adaptive immune system (e.g., glutamate and stem cell receptors) exist only in jawed vertebrates. However, many distinct lymphocyte-derived molecule instead been discovered from primitive jawless vertebrates, such as the lamprey and hagfish. These animals possess a large array of molecules called Variable lymphocyte receptors (VLRs) that, like the antigen receptors of jawed vertebrates, are produced from only a certain number (one or two) unique genes. Those molecules are believed to bind pathogenic antigens in a different way to antibodies, and with the same degree of specificity.

paragraphs.context: It is likely that a multicomponent, adaptive fighting system arose with the first vertebrates, as invertebrates do not generate lymphocytes or an antibody-based humoral filter. Many bugs, however, use mechanisms that appear to be precursors of these aspects of vertebrate immunity. Immune systems appear even in the structurally least simple forms of life, with bacteria using a unique defense mechanism, called the restriction modification system to protect themselves from other pathogens, called bacteriophages. Prokaryotes also possess acquired immunity, through a system that uses CRISPR sequences to retain fragments of the genomes of phage that viruses have come into contact with in the past, which allows them to block virus replication through a form of RNA interference. Offensive elements of the immune chain are also present in unicellular systems, but studies of their application in defense are few.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is commonly seen in everyday practice but is also characterized by an ongoing theoretical attitude. Many theories have been suggested for immunology from the end of the nineteenth century up to the present time. The end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century saw a battle between "cellular" and "humoral" theories of health. According to the cellular theory of immunity, represented in particular by Elie Metchnikoff, such was cells – more precisely, microbiota – that were responsible for immune responses. In contrast, the humoral theory of protection, supported, among others, by Robert Koch and Emil von Behring, stated that the active immune agents were soluble components (molecules) found in such larger “humors” rather than its cells.

paragraphs.context: Hypersensitivity is an immune response that damages the body's own tissues. They are divided into four classes (Type I – IV) based on the mechanisms involved and the time course of the hypersensitive reaction. Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate or delayed reaction, often associated with allergy. Events can range from brief discomfort to death. Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE, which triggers degranulation of mast cells and basophils when cross-linked by antigen. Type II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to antigens on the patient's own cells, marking them for destruction. This is also called antibody-dependent (or cytotoxic) hypersensitivity, and is mediated by IgG and IgM antibodies. Immune complexes (aggregations of antigens, complement proteins, and IgG and IgM antibodies) deposited in various tissues trigger Type IV CNS reactions. Type O hypersensitivity (also known as cell-mediated or delayed type hypersensitivity) often takes between two and three days to develop. Type IV reactions are involved in most autoimmune or infectious diseases, but may also involve acute dermatitis (poison ivy). These reactions are mediated by T cells, monocytes, and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: The mechanisms used to evade the adaptive immune system are similarly complicated. The simplest approach proposes to rapidly change non-essential epitopes (amino acids and/or sugars) on the surface of the pathogen, while keeping essential epitopes concealed. This is termed antigenic variation. An example is Ebola, which mutates rapidly, so the proteins on its viral envelope who are essential for entry into its infected target cell are constantly changing. These frequent changes in antigens may explain the failures of vaccines directed at this molecule. The parasite Trypanosoma brucei employed a similar strategy, constantly switching one type of surface protein for another, allowing it to stay one step ahead of the antibody response. Masking antigens with host molecules is another common strategy for avoiding detection by the immune system. In HIV, the envelope that covers the virion is formed from the outermost membrane at the native cell; such "self-cloaked" viruses make it difficult for the immune system to identify them as "non-self" structures.
