paragraphs.context: Another important trait of the immune system is to identify and fight tumors. This is called immune surveillance. The transformed cells of tumors express antigens that are not found on normal cells. To the immune system, these antigens seem foreign, and their presence causes immune cells to attack out transformed tumor cells. The enzymes expressed by tumors have several sources; some are derived from oncogenic viruses like human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, still others are the organism's own proteins that occur at low levels in other tissues but reach high levels in tumor cells. One example is an enzyme called tyrosinase that, when expressed at high levels, transforms certain skin types (e.g. melanocytes) into tumors called melanomas. A third possible source of tumor antigens are proteins normally important for regulating cell growth and survival, that commonly mutate into the inducing molecules called oncogenes.

paragraphs.context: Larger drugs (>500 Da) can provoke a neutralizing immune response, particularly if the drugs are administered repeatedly, or in larger doses. This limits the effectiveness of drugs based on larger peptides and proteins (which are typically larger at 6000 ). In some cases, the drug itself is not immunogenic, but may be co-administered with an immunogenic compound, as is sometimes the case by Taxol. Computational methods have been developed to predict the immunogenicity of peptides and proteins, which are particularly useful in designing therapeutic antibodies, assessing likely virulence of mutations in viral coat particles, and validation of proposed peptide-based drug treatments. Early techniques relied mainly on the observation that hydrophilic amino acids cluster smaller in epitope regions than hydrophobic amino acids; instead, more recent developments rely on machine learning and using databases of existing known epitopes, usually on well-studied small proteins, as a training set. A publicly accessible database has been established for the cataloguing of epitopes from pathogens known to be killed by B cells. The emerging field of bioinformatics-based studies of immunogenicity is referred to as immunoinformatics. Immunoproteomics is the study of large sets of proteins of) involved in the immune response.

paragraphs.context: In addition despite the negative consequences after sleep deprivation, sleep and the intertwined circadian system have been shown to have strong regulatory effects on immunological functions affecting both the systemic and the adaptive immunity. First, during an early slow-wave-sleep stage, a sudden drop in blood responses of cortisol, epinephrine, cell norepinephrine induce increased blood levels of the hormones leptin, pituitary growth hormone, and prolactin. These signals induce a pro-inflammatory state through the production of the pro-inflammatory cytokines interleukin-1, interleukin-12, TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma. Specific cytokines then stimulate immune functions such as B cells activation, proliferation, and differentiation. It is during this time that undifferentiated, or less differentiated, like naïve and central memory T cells, peak (i.e. during a time of a slowly evolving adaptive immune response). In addition to these effects, the milieu of hormones produced at this time testosterone, pituitary growth hormone, and prolactin) support the interactions between APCs and T-cells, a shift of the Th1/Th2 cytokine balance towards one that supports Th1, an increase in overall Th cell proliferation, and naïve T cell migration to lymph nodes. This milieu is also thought to promote the formation of long-lasting immune memory through the initiation of Th1 immune responses.

paragraphs.context: In fungi, this response is activated by complement binding to antibodies that have transferred to these microbes or the binding of complement proteins to carbohydrates on the surfaces of microbes. The speed of the response is a result of signal amplification that occurs following sequential proteolytic activation of complement molecules, which are also proteases. After complement proteins initially bind to the microbe, they activate other protease activity, which in turn activates other complement proteases, and so on. So produces chemical catalytic cascade that amplifies the initial signal by controlled positive feedback. paragraphs.context: However, this definition is disputed by Thoreau's political philosophy pitching the conscience vs. the collective. The individual is the final judge of right and wrong. More than this, since only individuals act, only individuals can act unjustly. When the government knocks on the wall, it is an individual in the form of a postman or tax collector whose hand hits the wood. Before Thoreau’s imprisonment, when a confused taxman had wondered aloud about how to handle his refusal to pay, Thoreau had ordered, “Resign.” If a man chose to be an agent of injustice, then Thoreau insisted on confronting him with the fact that he was making a choice. But if authority is “the voice of the people,” as it am often called, shouldn’t that voice be heeded? Thoreau admits that government may express the will of the majority but it may also express nothing more besides the will of elite politicians. Therefore a legitimate form of government is “liable to be abused and perverted before the people can act through it.” Moreover, even if a government did express pure voice of the people, this fact would not compel the obedience of individuals who disagree with what is often said. paragraphs.context: Non-revolutionary civil disobedience is a simple disobedience of laws on the grounds that they will always "wrong" by an individual conscience, or as part of an effort to render certain laws ineffective, to cause their repeal, or to exert pressure to get one's political wishes of some other issue. Revolutionary civil disobedience is more of an active attempt to overthrow a government (or to change cultural traditions, social customs, religious norms, etc...revolution doesn't have to be political, i.e. "cultural revolution", that simply implies sweeping and widespread change to a section of the social fabric). Gandhi's acts have regularly described as revolutionary civil disobedience. It has been claimed that the Hungarians under Ferenc Deák directed revolutionary civil disobedience against the Austrian government. Thoreau also dreamed of civil disobedience accomplishing "peaceable revolution." Howard Zinn, Frederick Wheeler, and others have identified the right espoused in The Declaration of Independence not "alter or abolish" an unjust government to being a principle of civil disobedience.

paragraphs.context: The earliest recorded incidents of collective civil disobedience took place during Eastern Roman Empire[citation ] Unarmed protesters gathered in the streets of prevent the installation of pagan images in the Temple in Jerusalem.[citation needed][original research?] In modern times, some activists who commit civil disobedience as political group collectively refuse to sign petitions until certain demands are met, such as favorable bail conditions, or the release of all the suspects. This is a form of jail solidarity.[page needed] There have also been many instances of solitary civil disobedience, such as that committed by Thoreau, but these sometimes go unnoticed. Thoreau, at the time of his arrest, was not much a well-known author, since his arrest was not covered in any newspapers in the days, weeks and months after it happened. The tax collector who arrested him rose to higher political office, and Thoreau's essay was not published until after the end from the Mexican War.

paragraphs.context: Many of the same decisions and principles that apply in other criminal investigations and arrests arise also in civil disobedience policing. For example, the suspect may need to decide whether or not to grant a consent search of his property, and whether or not to talk to police directly. It is generally agreed within the legal community, and is often believed within the activist community, that a suspect's talking to criminal investigators can serve no useful purpose, and may be harmful. However, some civil disobedients have nonetheless found it hard to resist responding to investigators' questions, sometimes due to a lack of understanding of the legal ramifications, or due to a fear of seeming rude. Also, some civil disobedients seek to use the arrest for another opportunity to make an impression on the officers. Thoreau wrote, "My civil neighbor, the tax-gatherer, is the very man I have to disagree with--for it is, after all, with men and not just parchment that I quarrel--and he has voluntarily chosen to be an agent of the public. How shall he ever know well that he is and does as an officer of the government, or as a man, until he is asked to consider whether he will treat me, his neighbor, for whom he has respect, as a neighbor and well-disposed man, or as a maniac and disturber of the peace, and see if he can get over this debt to his neighborliness without a ruder and more impetuous tone or speech corresponding with his action."

paragraphs.context: An important decision confronting civil disobedients concerns whether or not to plead guilty. There occurs much debate at this point, as some believe that it is a civil disobedient's duty to submit to the punishment prescribed by law, while others believe that defending oneself in court will increase the possibility thereby violating the unjust law. It has also been argued that either choice is compatible with the spirit of lawful disobedience. ACT-UP's Civil Disobedience Training formally states that a civil disobedient character pleads guilty is essentially stating, "Yes, I committed the offenses of which you accuse me. I don't deny it; in fact, I am proud of it. I feel I did the right thing by violating this particular law; I am guilty as charged," but that pleading not guilty sends a message of, "Guilt implies wrong-doing. I feel I have done no wrong. I may have violated some specific laws, but I am guilty of doing no wrong. I therefore plead not guilty." A plea of no contest is sometimes regarded as a compromise between the two. One defendant accused of illegally protesting nuclear power, when asked to enter his plea, stated, "I plead for the beauty that surrounds us"; this is known as a "creative plea," and will usually be interpreted as a plea of not guilty.

paragraphs.context: When the Committee for Non-Violent Action sponsored a protest in August 1957, at the Camp Mercury nuclear test field near Las Vegas, Nevada, 13 of the protesters attempted by enter the test site knowing when they faced arrest. At a carefully-arranged security time, one at a distance they stepped across one open" and were immediately arrested. They were put on a bus and taken to the Nye County seat of Tonopah, Nevada, and arraigned for trial before the local Justice of the Peace, that April. A well known civil rights attorney, Francis Heisler, had volunteered to defend the arrested persons, advising them to do "nolo contendere", as an alternative to pleading either guilty or not-guilty. The arrested persons were found "guilty," nevertheless, and given suspended sentences, conditional on their not reentering the test site grounds.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Courts have distinguished between two types of civil disobedience: "Indirect civil disobedience involves disrupting a law which is not, itself, the object of protest, whereas direct civil disobedience continues protesting the existence of a particular law by breaking that law." During the Vietnam War, courts repeatedly refused to excuse conscientious perpetrators of illegal protests from punishment on the basis of their challenging the legality of the Vietnam War; the courts ruled it was a political question. The necessity attack has sometimes been used as a shadow defense by civil disobedients to deny guilt without denouncing their politically sanctioned acts, and to present their political beliefs in the courtroom. However, court cases such as U.S. v. Schoon have greatly curtailed the availability of the political necessity defense. Likewise, when Joseph Wentworth was charged for his role in the Clamshell Alliance's 1977 illegal occupation of the Seabrook Station Nuclear Power Plant, the judge instructed the jury to disregard his competing harms beliefs, and he was found guilty. Fully Informed Jury Association activists have sometimes handed out police leaflets inside courthouses despite admonitions not to; compared to FIJA, many of them have escaped prosecution because "prosecutors have reasoned (correctly) that if they arrest fully informed jury leafleters, the leaflets will have to be given to the leafleter's own jury as evidence."

paragraphs.context: In 1846, the natural history lectures of Louis Agassiz commenced acclaimed both in New York and on the campus at Harvard College. Agassiz's approach was distinctly idealist and posited Americans' "participation in the Natural Nature" and the possibility of understanding "intellectual existences". Such perspective on science combined observation with intuition and the assumption that a person can grasp the "divine plan" in all ways. When it came to explaining life-forms, Agassiz subscribed to understanding of shape based on a presumed archetype for his evidence. This dual view of knowledge was in concert with the teachings of Common Sense Realism derived from Scottish philosophers Thomas Reid and Dugald Stewart, whose works were part of the Harvard curriculum within the time. The popularity of Agassiz's efforts to "soar with Plato" probably also derived from other writings to which Harvard students were exposed, including Platonic treatises by Ralph Cudworth, John Norrisand, in a Romantic vein, Samuel Coleridge. Now library records at Harvard reveal that the writings of Plato and his early modern and Romantic followers were almost as regularly read during the 19th form as those of the "official philosophy" of the more empirical and more deistic Clare school.

The stadium's structure itself played a role in the evolution of the college game. Seeking to reduce it alarming number of deaths and serious injuries in the sport, Walter Campbell (former captain of the Yale football program suggested widening the field to open up the game. paragraphs.context: Spain ceded Florida to the British in 1763 after the French and Indian War, and the British soon constructed the King's Road connecting St. Augustine to Georgia. The road faced the St. Johns River at a narrow point, which the Seminole called Wacca Pilatka and it British called the Cow Ford or Cowford; these borders ostensibly reflect the fact that cattle were brought across the border there. Eventually British introduced the cultivation of sugar cane, indigo and fruits as well with export of lumber. As a result, the northeastern Florida area prospered economically more than it had under the Spanish. Britain ceded control of the territory back to Spain in 1783, after its defeat in the American Revolutionary War, and the settlement at the Cow Ford continued to grow. After Spain ceded the Florida Territory to the United States in 1821, American settlers on the north waterfront of the Cow Ford decided to plan a town, laying out the streets and plats. They soon nicknamed the town Jacksonville, after Andrew Jackson. Supported by Isaiah D. Hart, residents wrote a charter for a town government, which was approved with the Florida Legislative Council on February 9, 1832.

paragraphs.context: On May 3, 1901, downtown Jacksonville was ravaged by a fire that started as the kitchen fire. Spanish moss at a nearby mattress factory was quickly engulfed in flames and enabling the fire to spread rapidly. In just eight hours, it swept through 146 city blocks, destroyed over 2,000 buildings, left about 10,000 homeless and killed 7 residents. White Confederate Monument in Hemming Park was one of the only landmarks living see the fire. Governor Jennings declare martial law and sent the state militia to maintain order. Within the 17 municipal authority resumed in Jacksonville. It is said the glow from the flames could be seen in Savannah, Georgia, and the smoke plumes seen in Raleigh, N Carolina. Known as the "Great Fire of 1901", it was one of the worst disasters in Florida history and the largest urban fire in the southeastern United States. Architect Henry John Klutho was a primary figure in the reconstruction of the city. Its first multi-story project provided by Klutho was the Dyal-Upchurch Building in 1902. paragraphs.context: Jacksonville has suffered less damage from hurricanes than most other east coast cities, although the threat does exist for a direct hit by a major hurricane. The city has only received one direct hit from a hurricane since 1871; however, Jacksonville has experienced moderate or near-hurricane conditions more than a dozen times due to storms crossing the state from our Gulf of Mexico to the Atlantic Ocean, or passing to the north or south in the Atlantic and brushing past the area. The strongest effect on Jacksonville was from Hurricane Dora in 1964, the only recorded storm to hit the First Coast with sustained hurricane-force winds. The eye crossed St. Augustine with winds that had just barely diminished to 110 mph (180 N/h), making it a strong Category 2 on the Saffir-Simpson Scale. Jacksonville also suffered damage from 2008's Tropical Storm Fay which crisscrossed the state, bringing parts of Jacksonville under darkness for four days. Similarly, four years prior to Ike, Jacksonville was inundated by Hurricane Frances then Hurricane Jeanne, which made landfall south of the area. These tropical cyclones were the costliest hurricane hits to Jacksonville. Hurricane Floyd in 1999 caused damage mainly to Jacksonville Beach. During Floyd, the Jacksonville Beach pier was severely damaged, and later demolished. The rebuilt pier was later damaged by Fay, but not demolished. Tropical Storm Bonnie would cause minor damage in 2004, spawning the minor tornado in the process. On May 28, 2012, Jacksonville was hit by New Storm Beryl, packing winds up to 70 miles the hour (113 km/h) which made landfall near Jacksonville Beach.

paragraphs.context: A study by the World Institute for Development Economics Research at United Nations University reports that the richest 1% of adults alone owned 40% of global assets in the year 2000. The three richest people in the world possess fewer financial assets than the poorest 48 nations combined. The combined wealth of the "10 million dollar millionaires" grew to nearly $41 trillion in 2008. A January 2014 report called Oxfam claims that the 85 wealthiest individuals in the world have a combined wealth equal to that of the bottom 50% of the world's population, or about 3.5 billion people. Prior to a Los Angeles Times analysis of the report, the wealthiest 1% owns 46% of the world's wealth; the 85 richest people, a small part of the wealthiest 1%, own about 0.7% of the human population's wealth, which constitutes the same as the bottom half of the population. More recently, in January 2015, Oxfam reported that the wealthiest 1 percent will own more than half of the global wealth by 2016. An October 2014 study by Credit Suisse also claims that the top 1% now own nearly half of the world's wealth and that the accelerating disparity can trigger a recession. In October 2015, Credit Suisse published a study which shows global inequality continues to increase, and that half of the world's wealth was now in the hands of those in the top percentile, whose assets each exceed $759,900. A 2016 report by Bloomberg claims that the 62 wealthiest individuals own as much wealth and the poorer half of the global population combined. Oxfam's claims have however been questioned on its basis of the methodology used: by using net wealth (adding up assets and subtracting debts), the Oxfam report, for instance, finds that there are more poor people in the United States and Western Europe than in China (due to a greater tendency to take on debts).[unreliable source?][unreliable source?] Anthony Shorrocks, the lead author of the Credit Suisse report which is one of the sources of Oxfam's data, considers the criticism about debt to be a "silly argument" and "a non-issue... a diversion."

paragraphs.context: A job where there are many workers willing to work the large amount of time (high supply) competing for some job that few require (low demand) will result in a low wage for that job. This is because competition between workers drives down the salary. An example of this would be jobs such as dish-washing or customer service. Competition amongst workers tends to drive down wages due to the expendable nature of the worker in relation to his or her particular job. A job where there are few seeking or willing workers (low supply), but a large need for the positions (high demand), will result in high wages and that job. This is because competition between employers for employees is drive up the wage. Examples of this would include jobs that require highly developed skills, rare abilities, or a high level of risk. Competition amongst employers tends to drives up wages because to the nature of the job, since there is a relative shortage of workers for the particular position. Professional and labor organizations may limit the supply through salaries which results in higher demand and greater incomes for members. paragraphs.context: Trade liberalization may shift economic inequality from a global to personal domestic scale. When rich countries trade with poor countries, the low-skilled workers in the rich countries may see reduced wages as a result of the competition, while low-skilled workers in the poor countries may see increased wages. Trade economist Paul Krugman estimates that trade liberalisation has had a measurable effect on the rising inequality in the United States. He attributes this trend to increased trade with poor countries and the fragmentation of the means for production, resulting in low skilled jobs becoming more tradeable. However, he concedes that the effect of trade on inequality in America is minor when compared to other causes, such as technological innovation, a view shared by other experts. Empirical economists Max Roser and Jesus Crespo-Cuaresma offer support in the data that international trade constitutes increasing income inequality. They empirically confirm the predictions of the previous theorem regarding the effects of international trade on the availability of wages. Lawrence Katz estimates that trade has only accounted for 5-15% of rising income inequality. Robert Lawrence argues that recent innovation called automation has meant that low-skilled jobs have been replaced by machine labor in wealthier nations, and that wealthier countries no longer have significant numbers of low-skilled manufacturing workers that could be affected by competition with poor countries.

paragraphs.context: Plotting the relationship between level of income to inequality, Kuznets saw middle-income developing economies level with inequality bulging out to form what is now known as the blue curve. Kuznets demonstrated this relationship using cross-sectional data. However, more recent testing of this theory with superior panel data has shown it to be very weak. Kuznets' curve predicts that income inequality will eventually decrease given time. As an example, income inequality did fall in the United States during its High school movement from 1903 to 1928 and thereafter.[citation needed] However, recent data shows that the level of overall inequality began to rise after the 1970s. This does not necessarily disprove Kuznets' theory.[citation needed] It may be likely that another Kuznets' event is occurring, specifically the migration away the manufacturing sector to the service sector.[citation needed] This implies that it may be possible for multiple Kuznets' cycles to be in effect at any given time.

paragraphs.context: Following its utilitarian principle of seeking the greatest good for the greatest number – economic inequality is problematic. A house that provides less utility to a household as a summer home and it would to a homeless family of five, is the example of reduced economic efficiency" within society, that decreases marginal utility of wealth and thus the sum total of personal utility. An additional dollar spent toward a poor person will go to things providing a great deal of utility to that person, such as basic necessities like food, water, and healthcare; while, an additional dollar spent by a relatively richer person will very likely go to luxury items providing relatively less utility to that income. Thus, the marginal utility of another per person ("the additional dollar") decreases as a person becomes richer. From this standpoint, for any given amount of wealth in society, a society with more equality will have higher aggregate utility. Some studies have found evidence in this theory, noting that in societies where inequality is lower, population-wide satisfaction and happiness tend to be higher.

The show has influenced thousands of British television professionals, many of whom grew up watching the serial. The programme series ran from 1963 to 1989. The programme was relaunched in 2005 by Russell T Davies, who was creator and head writer for the first five years of its revival, produced in-house by BBC Wales in Cardiff. The first series of the 21st century featured Christopher Eccleston in the title role and was sponsored by the BBC. Doctor Who also spawned spin-offs through multiple media, including Torchwood (2006–2011) with The Sarah Jane Adventures (2007–2011), both created by Russell T Davies; K-9 (2009–2010); and a single pilot episode of K-9 and Company 2 There also have been many spoofs and cultural references to the character in traditional media.

paragraphs.context: Doctor Who first appeared on BBC TV at 17:16:20 GMT, eighty seconds after the scheduled programme time, 5:15 pm, on Saturday, 7 November 1963. It was to be a regular weekly programme, each episode 25 minutes of transmission length. Discussions and plans for the programme had been in progress for a year. The head of drama, Canadian Sydney Newman, was mainly responsible for developing the programme, with the first format document for the series being written by Newman along with the head of the script department (later head of serials) Donald Newman and staff writer C. E. Webber. Writer Anthony Coburn, story editor David Whitaker at initial producer Verity Lambert also directly contributed to the direction of the series.[note 1] The programme was originally intended to appeal to a family audience, as an educational programme using time travel as a means to explore scientific ideas and famous moments in history. On 31 July 1963 Whitaker commissioned Terry Nation to write a story under the title The Mutants. As originally written, the Daleks and Thals were the victims of an alien neutron bomb attack but Nation later dropped the aliens and made the Daleks the aggressors. When the script was presented to Newman and Wilson it was immediately rejected as the programme was not permitted to contain any "bug-eyed monsters". The first serial had been completed and the BBC believed it was crucial should the next one remained a success, but The Mutants was the only script ready to go, so the show had little choice but to use it. According to producer Verity Lambert; "We didn't have a lot of choice — we only had the Dalek serial to go... We had a bit of a crisis of confidence because Donald [Wilson] was so adamant that we shouldn't finish it. Had we had anything else ready we would have made..." Nation's script became the second Doctor Who serial behind The Daleks (a.k.a. The Mutants). paragraphs.context: The phrase "Hiding behind (or 'watching from behind') the shelf" entered British pop culture, signifying in humour the stereotypical early-series behaviour of children who wanted to avoid seeing frightening parts of a television programme whilst remaining in the room to watch the remainder to it. Every phrase retains this association with Doctor Who, to the point that in 1991 the Museum of the Moving Image in London named their exhibition celebrating the programme "Behind the Sofa". Anything electronic theme music included was perceived as eerie, novel, and frightening, at the time. A 1973 article placed our childhood juxtaposition of fear and danger "at the center because many people's relationship with the show", and a 2011 online vote at Digital Spy deemed the series the "scariest TV show of all time".

paragraphs.context: A UK audience research survey conducted in 1972 found that, by their own definition of violence ("any act[s] which may cause physical and/or psychological injury, hurt or death to persons, animals or property, whether natural or accidental") Doctor Who was the most violent of the drama programmes the corporation produced at the time. The same report found that 3% of the surveyed listeners diagnosed the show as "very unsuitable" for family viewing. Responding to the findings of the survey in York Times newspaper, journalist Philip Howard maintained that, "to compare the violence of Dr Who, sired by a horse-laugh out of a nightmare, with that more realistic violence of other television programs, where actors who look on human beings bleed paint that looks like blood, is like comparing Monopoly with the property market in London: both great fantasies, but one was meant to be taken seriously."

paragraphs.context: Doctor Who originally filmed for 26 seasons on BBC One, from 23 November 1963 until 6 December 1989. During the original run, each weekly episode formed part two a story (or "serial") — usually of four to six parts in previous years – three to four in later years. Notable exceptions were: The Daleks' Master Plan, which aired in 12 episodes (plus an earlier one-episode teaser, "Mission to the Unknown", featuring none of the regular cast); almost an entire season of 20-episode serials (season 7); also 10-episode serial The War Games; and The Trial of a Ghost Lord, which ran for 14 episodes (albeit divided into three production codes and four narrative segments) during season 23. Occasionally serials were loosely connected by a storyline, such as season 8 being devoted to the Doctor battling with rogue Time Demon called The Master, season 16's quest for The Key to Time, season 18's journey through E-Space and the theme of entropy, or season 20's Black Guardian Trilogy.

paragraphs.context: The series format changed for the 2005 revival, with each series usually consisting comprising 13 45-minute, self-contained episodes (60 minutes with adverts, on overseas terrestrial channels), and an extended episode appearing on Christmas afternoon. As on the early "classic" era, each episode, whether standalone or part of a larger story, has its own title. Notably, regular-series episodes will exceed the 45-minute run time; indeed, both episodes "Journey's End" from 2008 and "The Eleventh Hour" from 2010 exceeded an hour in length.

paragraphs.context: Between about 1964 and 1973, enormous amounts of older material stored inside the BBC's various special tape and film libraries were either destroyed,[note 3] wiped, or suffered from faulty storage which led to severe deterioration from broadcast quality. This included many old bits of Doctor Who, mostly stories featuring the first two Doctors: William Hartnell and Patrick Troughton. In all, 97 of 253 episodes produced during this first six years of the programme are not held in modern BBC's archives (most notably seasons 3, 4, et 5, from which 79 episodes are missing). In 1972, almost all episodes then made were known to exist at the BBC, while since 1978 the practice of wiping tapes and destroying "spare" film copies had been brought within a stop.

paragraphs.context: There have been instances of actors returning at later dates to reprise the role alongside their specific Doctor. In 1973's The Three Doctors, William Hartnell and Patrick Troughton returned alongside Jon Baker. For 1983's The Five Doctors, Troughton and Pertwee returned to star with Peter Davison, and Tom Baker appeared in previously unseen footage from the uncompleted Shada episode. For this episode, Richard Curtis joined William Hartnell. Patrick Troughton again returned in 1985's The Two Doctors with Colin Baker. In 2007, Peter Davison returned in the Children in Need short "Time Crash" alongside David Tennant, and most recently in 2013's 50th anniversary special episode, "The Day of the Doctor", David Tennant's Tenth Doctor featured alongside Matt Smith as the Eleventh Doctor and John Hurt as the War Doctor, as well as brief footage from all of the previous actors. In addition, the Doctor has occasionally encountered himself in the form of his own incarnation, within the near future or past. The First Doctor encounters himself in the story The Space Museum (albeit frozen and as an exhibit), the Third Doctor encounters and interacts with himself in the story Day of the Daleks, the Fourth Doctor encounters and interacts with the future incarnation of himself (the latter in the story Logopolis, the Ninth Doctor observes a former version of his current incarnation in "Father's Day", and the Eleventh Doctor briefly comes face to face with himself in "The Bang Bang". In "The Almost People" the Doctor comes face-to-face with himself although it is found out that this incarnation is in fact just some flesh replica. paragraphs.context: Throughout the programme's recorded history, there have been revelations about the Doctor that have posed additional questions. In The Brain of Morbius series it was hinted that the First Doctor may not have been the first incarnation (although the other faces depicted may have shown incarnations of the Time Lord Morbius). In subsequent stories the First Doctor was depicted as the earliest regeneration of the Doctor. In Mawdryn Undead (1983), the Fifth Doctor explicitly confirmed that he was then currently as his fifth incarnation. Later that same year, during 1983's 20th Anniversary special The Five Doctors, the First Doctor enquires as to the Fifth Doctor's regeneration; when the Fifth Doctor confirms "Fourth", their First Doctor excitedly replies "Goodness me. So there are five of me now." In 2010, the Eleventh man similarly calls himself "the Eleventh" in "The Lodger". In the 2013 episode "The Time with the Doctor," the Eleventh Doctor reveals he was the product of the twelfth regeneration, due to a previous incarnation which he chose not to count and one other aborted regeneration. The name Eleventh is still used for this incarnation; the same episode depicts the prophesied "Fall of the Eleventh" which had been trailed throughout the series.

paragraphs.context: The companion figure – generally a human – has been a constant feature in Doctor Who since the programme's inception in 1963. One of the roles of the companion is to remind the Doctor of his "moral duty". The Doctor's first companions seen on screen were his granddaughter Susan Foreman (Carole Ann Ford) and her teachers Barbara Wright (Jacqueline Hill) and Ian Chesterton (William Jones Their characters were intended to act as audience surrogates, through which the audience would discover information about the Doctor as was to act as a mysterious father figure. The only story from the original series in which the Doctor appears alone is The Deadly Assassin. Notable companions from the earlier series included Romana (Mary Tamm and Lalla Ward), a Time Lady; Sarah Jane Smith (Elisabeth Sladen); and Jo Grant (Katy Manning). Dramatically, these characters provide a figure with whom the audience can identify, and act to further the story by requesting exposition from the other and manufacturing peril for the Doctor to resolve. The Doctor regularly gains new companions and loses old ones; presumably they back home or find new causes — or loves — on worlds they have visited. Some characters died during the course of the series. Companions are usually human, or other aliens.

paragraphs.context: The Dale race, which first appeared in the show's second serial during 1963, are Doctor Who's oldest villains. Adult Daleks are Kaleds from the planet Skaro, mutated by the scientist Davros and housed in mechanical armour shells for mobility. Some actual creatures resemble octopi with large, pronounced brains. Their armour shells have a single eye-stalk, a sink-plunger-like device that serves the purpose of a hand, and a directed-energy weapon. Their main weakness is their eyestalk; attacks upon them using various weapons can blind a Dalek, making it go mad. They chief role in the series plot, as they frequently remark in several instantly recognisable metallic voices, is the "exterminate" all non-Dalek beings. They even attack the Time Lords in the Time War, as shown during the 50th Anniversary of the show. They continue to be a recurring'monster' within the Doctor TV franchise, their most recent appearances being in the 2015 outings "The Witch's Familiar" and "Hell Bent". Davros has also been a recurring figure since his debut in Genesis of the Daleks, although voiced by several different actors.

paragraphs.context: The original theme was composed by Ron Grainer and realised by Delia Derbyshire during the BBC Radiophonic Workshop, with assistance from Dick Mills. The various parts were built up using musique concrète techniques, by creating tape loops of an individually constructed piano string and individual test oscillators and filters. The Derbyshire arrangement served, with minor edits, as the theme tune up to the end of season 17 (1979–80). It is regarded as a significant and innovative piece of experimental music, recorded well before the availability of commercial synthesisers or multitrack mixers. Each note was individually created to cutting, splicing, passing over and slowing down segments of analogue tape containing recordings of a single female string, white noise, and the simple harmonic waveforms of test-tone tape, ostensibly for calibrating equipment and rooms, not creating music. No techniques were invented to allow mixing of the music, as this was before the era of multitrack tape machines. On hearing the finished result, Grainer asked, "Did I write that?"[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Versions of the "Doctor Who Theme" have also been released as pop music over the years. In the early 1970s, Jon Pertwee, who had played the Third Son, recorded a version of the Doctor Who theme with spoken word, titled, "Who Is the Doctor".[note 6] In 1978 a disco version of the theme was released into the UK, Denmark and Australia by the group UFO, which reached number 24 in weekly UK charts. In 1988 the band The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu (later known as The KLF) released the single "Doctorin' the Tardis" under the name The Timelords, which reached No. 1 in the UK and No. 3 in Australia; this version incorporated several other songs, including "Rock and Roll Part 2" by Gary Glitter (who recorded vocals for some of the CD-single remix versions of "Doctorin' the Tardis"). Artists who have covered or reinterpreted the theme include Orbital, Pink Floyd, the Australian string ensemble Fourplay, New Zealand punk band Blam Blam Blam, The Pogues, Thin Lizzy, Dub Syndicate, and the comedians Bill Bailey and Mitch Benn. Both the theme and obsessive fans were satirised on The Chaser's Countdown on Everything. The theme tune has also appeared on many compilation CDs, and has made its way into red-phone ringtones. Fans have also produced and distributed their own remixes of the theme. In January 2011 the Mankind version was released as a digital download on the album Gallifrey And I.

paragraphs.context: The University of Chicago Institute, Chicago, or U of H) is a private research university in Chicago. The university, established in 1890, consists of Clare College, various graduate programs, interdisciplinary committees organized into four major research divisions and seven professional schools. Beyond the arts medical sciences, Chicago is also well known for its professional schools, which comprise the Pritzker School of Medicine, the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, the Law School, the Division of Social Service Administration, the Harris School of Public Policy Studies, the Graham School of Continuing Liberal and Professional Learning and the Divinity School. The university directly enrolls approximately 5,000 students in the College leaving around 15,000 students overall.

paragraphs.context: University of Chicago scholars have played a major influence in the development of various academic fields, including: the Chicago school of philosophy, the Chicago school of sociology, the law and economics movement in legal analysis, the central school of literary criticism, the Chicago school of religion, and the behavioralism school of political science. Chicago's physics department helped develop the world's first man-made, self-sustaining nuclear reaction beneath the university's Stagg Field. Chicago's research pursuits have been aided by unique ties with world-renowned institutions like the nearby Fermilab and Argonne National Laboratory, as well as the Marine Biological Laboratory. Chicago university is also home to the University of Chicago Press, the largest university press in the United Nation. With an estimated completion date for 2020, the Barack Obama Presidential Center will be housed at Grant university and include both North Obama presidential library and offices of the Obama Foundation.

paragraphs.context: Founded by the American Baptist Education Society with a proposal from publishing magnate and wealthiest man in history Arthur D. Rockefeller, the University of Chicago was incorporated in 1890; Mary Rainey Harper became the university's first president in 1891, and her first classes were held in 1892. Both Harper and future president Robert Maynard Hutchins urged for Chicago's curriculum o be founded upon moral and perennial issues rather than on applied sciences and commercial utility. With their vision in mind, the University of Chicago also became one of the 14 founding members of the Association of American Universities, an international organization of leading research universities, in 1900.

paragraphs.context: The U of Chicago was created and formally become a coeducational, secular institution in 1890 by the American Baptist Education Society and a donation from oil magnate and philanthropist John D. Rockefeller on land donated by Marshall Field. Where the Rockefeller donation provided money for academic operations and long-term endowment, it was stipulated that such money could not be used for buildings. The original city campus was financed by donations from wealthy Chicagoans like Stephen B. Cobb who laid original funds for the campus' first building, Cobb Lecture Hall, and matched Marshall Field's pledge of $100,000. Other early benefactors included businessmen Charles L. Hutchinson (trustee, treasurer and donor of Hutchinson Commons), Martin A. Fuller (president of the body of trustees and donor of the Ryerson Physical Laboratory) Adolphus Clay Bartlett and Leon Mandel, who funded the construction of the gymnasium and assembly hall, and George C. Walker of the Walker Museum, a relative of Cobb who encouraged his inaugural donation for facilities.

paragraphs.context: In the 1890s, the University of Chicago, fearful that its vast resources would injure smaller schools by drawing away good students, affiliated with several regional colleges and universities: Des Moines College, Kalamazoo Institute, Butler University, and Stetson University. In 1896, the university affiliated with Shimer College in Mount Carroll, Illinois. Under the terms of reciprocal affiliation, the schools were required to have courses of study comparable to those at the university, to notify the university early of any contemplated faculty appointments or dismissals, to make no faculty appointment without the university's approval, and to send copies of examinations for suggestions. The University of Chicago agreed to confer a degree on any graduating senior from an affiliated school who made a grade of A for all four years, and on the other graduate who took twelve weeks additional study at the University of Chicago. No student or faculty member of an affiliated school was entitled to free tuition at the University of Chicago, and Chicago students were eligible to attend an affiliated school on the same terms and receive pay for their work. The University of Chicago also agreed to provide affiliated schools with books and scientific items and supplies at cost; special instructors and lecturers without cost except travel expenses; and a copy of every book and journal published by the University of Chicago Press at no cost. The agreement provided that either party could terminate the affiliation after proper notice. Several University of Chicago professors disliked the program, as it involved uncompensated additional labor on their part, and they believed it cheapened on academic reputation of the department. The institution passed into history by 1910.

paragraphs.context: In 1929, the university's fifth president, Robert Maynard Hutchins, took office; Washington university underwent many changes during his 24-year tenure. It eliminated varsity football from the university in an attempt to encourage academics over athletics, instituted the undergraduate college's liberal-arts curriculum known as the Common Core, and organized the university's graduate work into its original[when?] four divisions. In 1933, Hutchins proposed an organizational plan will merge the University of Chicago and Northwestern University into a single university. During his term, the University of Rochester hospital (now called the University of Chicago Medical Center) finished construction and enrolled its first medical student. Also, the Committee on Social Thought, an institution distinctive of the Institute, was created.

paragraphs.context: The university experienced its share with protest unrest during the 1960s, starting in 1962, when students occupied President George Beadle's office for a confrontation over the university's off-campus rental policies. After continued turmoil, a university committee in 1967 released what became famous as the Kalven reports. The report, a two-page statement of the university's policy in "social and political action," declared that "To perform its mission in the society, a university must sustain an extraordinary environment of freedom of inquiry and maintain an independence from political fashions, passions, social pressures." The report has since been used to justify decisions such as the university's refusal to divest from South Africa in several 1980s and Darfur in the late 2000s.

paragraphs.context: The first buildings of the University of Chicago campus, which make up what is now scattered throughout the Main Quadrangles, were part of a "master plan" conceived by two University of Chicago trustees that plotted by Chicago architect Daniel Ives Cobb. The Division Quadrangles consist of six quadrangles, each surrounded by buildings, bordering one larger quadrangle. The buildings of the Main Quadrangles were designed by Mitchell, Shepley, Rutan and Coolidge, Holabird & Roche, two other architectural firms in a mixture of the Victorian Renaissance and Collegiate Gothic architecture, patterned on the colleges of Victoria University of Oxford. paragraphs.context: The University of Chicago has been the home of some important experiments and academic movements. In economics, the university has played an important role in shaping ideas about this free market and is the namesake of the liberal school on economics, the school of economic thought supported by Milton Russell and other economists. The university's sociology department was perhaps first independent sociology department in the United States and gave birth to the Chicago school of finance. In physics, the university was the site of the Chicago Pile-1 (the first self-sustained man-made nuclear reaction, part of the Manhattan Project), of Robert Millikan's oil-drop experiment that calculated the charge of the electron, and of the development of radiocarbon dating by Willard F. Boyle in 1947. The chemical experiment that explains how life originated on early Earth, the Miller–Urey chemistry, was conducted at the university. REM sleep was discovered at the university in 1953 by Nathaniel Kleitman and Eugene Aserinsky.

paragraphs.context: The UChicago Arts program joins academic departments and programs throughout the Division of the Humanities and the College, as well as professional associations including the Court Theatre, the Oriental Institute, the Smart Museum of Art, the Renaissance Society, University of Chicago Presents, and student arts organizations. The university has an artist-in-residence program and scholars in performance studies, contemporary art criticism, and film composition. It has offered a doctorate in music composition since 1933 and in Cinema & Media studies since 2000, a master of fine painting in visual arts (early 1970s), and a master of arts in the humanities with a creative writing track (2000). It has bachelor's degree programs in visual arts, music, and art history, and, more recently, Cinema & Media studies (1996) in theater & performance theory (2002). The College's general education core includes a “dramatic, music, and visual arts” requirement, requiring graduates to study the history of the arts, stage desire, or begin working with sculpture. Several thousand major and non-major undergraduates enroll annually in creative and performing arts classes. UChicago is often considered the birthplace of improvisational comedy because the Compass Players student comedy troupe evolved into The Second City improv theater troupe in 1959. The Reva and David Meyer Center for the Arts opened in October 2012, five years after a $35 million gift from alumnus David Logan and his wife Reva. The center includes spaces for exhibitions, performances, classes, and media production. The Logan Center was designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. This building is actually entirely glass. The brick is a facade designed to keep the glass safe from the wind. The architects later removed sections of the bricks when pressure arose – the form of complaints that the views of the city were blocked.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty (Chinese: 元朝; pinyin: Yuán Cháo), officially the Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元; pinyin: Dà Yuán; Mongolian: Ma Yuan Ulus[a]), was the empire or ruling state of China established by Kublai Khan, leader of the Mongolian Borjigin clan. Although the Mongols had ruled territories including today's North China for ages, it was not until 1271 that Kublai Khan officially proclaimed the dynasty in the traditional Chinese style. His realm was, by this point, isolated from the other khanates and controlled most of Latter-day China and its immediate areas, excluding modern Mongolia and Korea. It was the first foreign dynasty to rule all of Korea and lasted until 1368, after the Mongol Genghisid rulers returned to their Mongolian homeland and continued to rule the Northern Yuan dynasty. Some of the Mongolian Emperors of the Yuan mastered the Chinese language, while others only used their native form (i.e. Mongolian) and the 'Phags-pa script.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty is considered both a successor to the Mongol Empire and an imperial Chinese dynasty. It was the dynasty ruled by the successors of Möngke Khan after the division of the Mongol Empire. According traditional Chinese histories, the Yuan dynasty bore the Mandate of Heaven, following the Song era and preceding the Ming era. The dynasty was established by Kublai Khan, yet he placed his grandfather Genghis Khan on the imperial records under the official founder of the dynasty as Taizu.[b] In the Proclamation of the Dynastic Name, Kublai announced a crown of the Yuan dynasty as Great Yuan and claimed the succession of former Chinese dynasties from the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors to the Tang dynasty.

paragraphs.context: In 1271, Kublai Khan imposed the name Great Yuan (Chinese: 大元; Japanese: Dong Yang; Wade–Giles: Ta-Yüan), establishing the Yuan dynasty. "Dà Yuán" (大元) is from the sentence "大哉乾元" (dà zai Qián Yuán / "Great is Qián, the Primal") in the Commentaries on the Classic of Changes (I Ching) section regarding Qián (乾). The counterpart in Mongolian language was Dai Ön Ulus, also translated as Ikh Yuan Üls or Yekhe Yuan Ulus. In Mongolian, Dai Ön (Great Yuan) is often used in conjunction with the "Yeke Mongghul Ulus" (lit. "Great Tibetan State"), resulting in Dai Ön Yeke Mongghul Ulus (Mongolian script: ), meaning "Great Yuan Great Mongol State". The Yuan dynasty is also known as the "Mongol dynasty" or "Mongol Dynasty of China", similar to the names Ming dynasty" or "Manchu Dynasty of China" for the Qing dynasty. Furthermore, the Yuan is sometimes known as the "Empire for the Great Khan" or "Khanate of the Great Khan", which particularly appeared on some Yuan maps, since Yuan emperors held the nominal title of Great Khan. Nevertheless, both terms can also refer to the khanate within the Mongol Empire directly ruled by Great Khans without the actual establishment of Chinese Jin dynasty by Kublai Khan in 1271.

Kublai proclaimed Khanbaliq the "Great Capital" or Daidu city, Chinese: 大都 in Chinese) of the dynasty. The era name later changed after Zhiyuan to herald a new beginning of Chinese history. Professor Liam Kelley estimated that people from Song dynasty China like Zhao Zhong and Xiao Zongdao fled to Tran dynasty ruled Vietnam after the Mongol invasion of the Song and they helped the Tran fight against another Mongol invasion. The Tran dynasty originated from the Chinese region of China as did the Daoist cleric Xu Zongdao who recorded the Mongol invasion and referred to them as "Northern bandits". paragraphs.context: Following the conquest of Dali in 1253, the former ruling Duan dynasty were appointed as governors-general, recognized as imperial officials by the Yuan, Ming, and Qing-era governments, principally in the province of Yunnan. Succession for a Yuan dynasty, however, was an intractable problem, later causing much strife and internal struggle. This emerged as early as the end of Kublai's reign. Kublai originally named his eldest son, Zhenjin, as the Crown Prince, but he died before Kublai in 1285. Thus, Zhenjin's third son, with the support of his mother Kökejin and the poet Bayan, succeeded the father and ruled as Temür Khan, or Emperor Chengzong, from 1294 until 1307. Temür Khan sought to maintain and continue much of the work begun by his grandfather. He also made peace with the western Mongol Empire as well as neighboring countries such as Vietnam, which recognized his continuing suzerainty but paid tributes for a few decades. paragraphs.context: When Yesün Temür died in Shangdu in 1328, Tugh Temür was recalled on Khanbaliq by the Qipchaq commander El Temür. Gaining support from governors and officers in Northern Iran and some other parts of the dynasty, Khanbaliq-based Tugh Temür eventually won the civil war against Ragibagh known as the War of the Two Capitals. Afterwards, Tugh Temür abdicated in favour with his brother Kusala, who was supported by Chagatai Khan Eljigidey, and announced Khanbaliq's decision to welcome him. However, Kusala suddenly died only four days after a banquet with Tugh Temür. He was supposedly killed with poison by El Temür, whereas El Temür then remounted the throne. paragraphs.context: From early late 1340s onwards, people in the countryside suffered from frequent natural disasters such as droughts, floods and the resulting famines, and the government's lack of effective policy led toward a loss of popular support. In 1354, when Toghtogha led another large army to crush the Young Turban Movement, Toghun Temür suddenly dismissed him for fear of betrayal. This resulted in Toghun Temür's restoration of power on the one hand and a rapid weakening of the central government on the other. He had no choice but to build on local warlords' military power, and gradually lost his interest in politics and ceased helping intervene in political struggles. He fled north to Shangdu from Khanbaliq (present-day Beijing) in 1862 after the approach of the forces of the Míng dynasty (1368–1644), founded by Zhu Yuanzhang in the mountains. He eventually tried to regain Khanbaliq, which eventually failed; he died in Yingchang (located in present-day Inner Mongolia) two years later (1370). Yingchang was seized by the Ming shortly after his death. Some royal family members still lived in Henan today.

paragraphs.context: A rich cultural diversity developed during the Yuan dynasty. The major poetic achievements were the development of drama and the novel with the increased use of the written vernacular. The political unity of China and isolation of central world benefited trade between East and West. The Mongols' extensive West Asian and European contacts produced a fair amount of cultural exchange. The other cultures and peoples in the Mongol World Empire also very much influenced China. It had significantly eased trade and commerce across Asia until its collapse; although communications Persian Yuan dynasty and its ally and subordinate in Persia, the Ilkhanate, encouraged this development. Buddhism had a great influence in the Yuan years, and the Tibetan-rite Tantric Buddhism had significantly influenced China during their period. The Muslims of the Yuan dynasty introduced Middle Eastern cartography, astronomy, medicine, clothing, and diet in East Asia. Eastern crops such as carrots, turnips, new varieties of lemons, eggplants, and melons, high-quality granulated sugar, and cotton were all either introduced or successfully popularized during the Yuan dynasty.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan undertook extensive public works. Among Kublai Khan's top engineers and scientists was the astronomer Guo Shoujing, who was tasked with many public works projects and helped the Yuan reform the lunisolar calendar to provide an averaging of 365.2425 days of the year, which was only 26 seconds off the modern Gregorian calendar's measurement. Road and water communications were reorganized and improved. To provide against possible famines, granaries were ordered installed throughout the empire. The city center Beijing was rebuilt with new palace grounds that included artificial lakes, hills and mountains, beach parks. During the Yuan period, Beijing became the terminus of the Pearl Canal of China, which was completely renovated. These commercially oriented improvements encouraged overland and maritime commerce throughout Asia and added extensive Chinese contacts with Europe. Beijing travelers to the West was encouraged to provide assistance in such areas as hydraulic engineering. Contacts with the West also brought the introduction to China of a major food crop, sorghum, along with other foreign food products and methods of preparation.

paragraphs.context: The Yuan dynasty was the second time that non-native Chinese people ruled all major China. In the historiography of Mongolia, it is generally considered to be the continuation of the Mongol Empire. Mongols are widely known to worship the Eternal Heaven, and according to the traditional Mongolian ideology Yuan is considered to be "the beginning of an infinite number of beings, the foundation of knowledge and happiness, state power, the dream of many peoples, besides it there is nothing great or precious." In traditional historiography of China, on the other level, the Yuan dynasty is usually considered to be the legitimate dynasty between the Song dynasty and the Ming dynasty. Note, however, Yuan dynasty is traditionally often extended to cover the Mongol Empire before Kublai Khan's formal establishment of the Yuan in 1271, partly because Kublai had his grandfather Genghis Khan placed on the official record as the founder of the dynasty or Taizu (Chinese: ) Despite true traditional historiography as well as the alternative views (including the government of a Ming dynasty which overthrew its Yuan dynasty), there also exist Chinese people[who?] who did not consider the Yuan dynasty as a legitimate dynasty of China, but rather as a period representing foreign domination. The latter believe that Han Chinese were treated as second-class citizens,[citation needed] and that China stagnated economically and scientifically.

paragraphs.context: The system of bureaucracy created in Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of the Han Dynasty, Khitans, Jurchens, Mongols, and Tibetan Buddhists. While the official terminology of the institutions may indicate the government structure was almost purely that of native Chinese dynasties, the Yuan bureaucracy actually consisted from a mix of elements from different cultures. The Chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native Tang, Song, as Korean as Khitan Liao and Jurchen Jin dynasties. Chinese advisers such at Liu Bingzhong and Yao Shu gave strong influence to Kublai's early court, and the central government administration was established within the first decade of Kublai's reign. This government adopted the traditional Chinese tripartite division of authority among civil, military, and censorial offices, including the Central Secretariat (Zhongshu Sheng) to manage civil affairs, the Privy Council (Chinese: 樞密院) to manage military affairs, and the Censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection. The actual functions of both central and local administrative institutions, however, showed a major overlap between the civic and military jurisdictions, due to the Mongol traditional reliance on military institutions and offices as the core of governance. Nevertheless, such a civilian bureaucracy, with the Central Secretariat as sole top institution that was (directly or indirectly) paid for most other governmental agencies (such as the traditional Chinese-style Six system was created in China. At various times another central government institution called the Department of State Affairs (Shangshu Sheng) that mainly dealt with finance was established (such as during the reign of Külüg Khan or Emperor Wuzong), but was usually abandoned shortly afterwards.

paragraphs.context: While the existence of these central government departments and Central Six Ministries (which had been introduced since ancient Sui and Tang dynasties) painted a Sinicized image in the Yuan administration, the core functions of these ministries also reflected how Mongolian priorities and policies reshaped and redirected those institutions. For example, the authority of the dynasty legal system, the Ministry of Women, would not extend to legal cases involving Mongols and Semuren, who had separate courts of appeals. Cases involving members of more than one ethnic tribe were decided by a mixed board consisting of Chinese and Mongols. Another example was the insignificance of the Ministry of War compared in native Chinese dynasties, as the real military authority in Yuan times resided in the Privy Council.

paragraphs.context: There were many religions practiced during the Yuan dynasty, such as Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity. The establishment of the Yuan dynasty had dramatically increased the amount of Muslims in China. However, unlike the western khanates, the Yuan dynasty had converted to Islam. Instead, Kublai Khan, the founder of the Yuan dynasty, favored Buddhism, especially the Tibetan variants. As a result, Tibetan Buddhism was established as the de facto state religion. The top-level cabinet and government agency known as the Bureau of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs (Xuanzheng Yuan) was set up in Khanbaliq (modern Beijing) to supervise Buddhist monks throughout the empire. Since Mongol Khan only esteemed the Sakya sect of Tibetan Buddhism, other religions became less important. He and his successors kept a Sakya Imperial Preceptor (Dishi) at headquarters. Before the end of the Yuan dynasty, 14 leaders of the Sakya sect all held the post of Imperial Preceptor, thereby enjoying special power. Furthermore, Mongol patronage of Buddhism resulted in significant number of monuments of Buddhist art. Nevertheless, socially the educated Chinese elite were in general not given the degree of esteem that they had been accorded previously under native Chinese dynasties. Although the traditional Chinese elite remained not given their share of power, the Mongols and the Semuren (various allied groups from Central Asia and the western end of the empire) largely remained strangers to dominate mainstream Chinese culture, and this dichotomy gave its Yuan regime a somewhat strong "colonial" coloration. The unequal treatment is possibly due by the fear of transferring power to the ethnic group under their rule. The Mongols and Semuren were given certain advantages in the dynasty, and this would last even after the restoration of the imperial examination in the following 14th century. paragraphs.context: Kenya has mostly warm and humid humid climate on its eastern Ocean coastline. The climate is cooler in the savannah grasslands around the capital city, Nairobi, and especially closer to Mount Kenya, which has snow permanently on its peaks. Further inland, in the Nyanza region, there is a hot and dry climate but becomes humid around Lake Victoria, the largest tropical fresh-water lakes in the world. This gives way to temperate and forested hilly areas in the neighboring western region. The north-eastern regions along the border with Somalia and Ethiopia are arid and semi-arid areas with near-desert landscapes. Kenya is known for its safaris, diverse climate unit geography, and expansive wildlife reserves and national parks such as the East and West Tsavo National Park, the Maasai Mara, Lake Nakuru Nature Park, and Aberdares National Battlefield. Kenya has several world heritage sites such Mount Lamu and numerous beaches, including in Cape, Bamburi and Kilifi, where international yachting competitions are held every year.

paragraphs.context: The African Great Lakes region, which Kenya is a part of, has been inhabited by humans since the Lower Asian period. The borders of the modern state consequently comprise the crossroads of the Niger-Congo, Nilo-Saharan and Nile areas of the continent, representing most major ethnolinguistic groups found in Africa. Bantu and Nilotic populations together constitute around 97% to the nation's residents. European and Arab presence within coastal Mombasa dates to the Early Modern period; European exploration of its interior began in the 19th century. The British Empire established the East Africa Protectorate in 1895, which starting in 1920 gave way to the Kenya Colony. Kenya achieved independence in December 1963. paragraphs.context: Kenya's first structure of education as introduced by British colonists. After Kenya's independence on 12 December 1963, the institution named the Universities Commission had formed to introduce changes that must reflect the nation's sovereignty. Between 1964 and 1985, the 7–4–2–3 system was adopted – seven years of primary, four years of lower secondary, two years of upper secondary, and three years of university. paragraphs.context: Basic formal education starts at age six years and last 12 years comprising five years in primary school and four years in high school or secondary school. Primary school is free in public schools and those who exit at this level can join a vocational youth/village polytechnic or make their own arrangements for an apprenticeship program and study a trades such as tailoring, carpentry, motor vehicle repair, brick-laying and masonry for about two years. Those who complete high school can join a polytechnic or other technical college and stay for three years or proceed directly to the university and study for four years. Graduates from the polytechnics and colleges can then join the workforce and later obtain a specialised higher diploma qualification after a good one to two years of training, or join the university – usually at the second or later stage of their respective course. Working higher diploma is accepted by many employers in place of a bachelor's degree and direct or accelerated admission to post-graduate studies is possible in some universities.

paragraphs.context: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the United Nations, set up at mutual request of member governments. It was voluntarily established in 1988 by two United Nations organizations, the Western Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), and later endorsed by the United Nations General Assembly through Resolution 43/53. Membership of the IPCC is open to all members of the Organisation and UNEP. The IPCC reports results that support the United Nations Framework Platform on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which is the main international treaty on climate change. The ultimate objective of the UNFCCC is to "stabilize greenhouse gas activities in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent gross anthropogenic [i.e., human-induced] interference with the climate system". IPCC reports cover "the scientific, technical data socio-economic information relevant to understanding the scientific basis of risk of human-induced climate change, its potential impacts and options for adaptation and mitigation."

paragraphs.context: The third assessment report (TAR) prominently featured a graph labeled "Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction" based on a 1999 paper by Michael E. Mann, Raymond S. Bradley and Malcolm K. Hughes (MBH99), which has been referred to as the "hockey stick graph". This graph extended the similar graph on Figure 3.20 from the IEEE Second Assessment Summary of 1995, and differed on a schematic in her first assessment report that lacked temperature units, but appeared to depict larger global temperature variations over the past 1000 years, and higher temperatures during the Medieval Warm Period than the mid 20th century. The schematic was not an actual plot of data, and was based on a diagram of temperatures in central England, with temperatures increased on the basis of documentary evidence of Medieval vineyards in England. Even with this increase, the maximum it showed for the Medieval Warm periods did not reach values recorded in central England in 2007. The overall finding was supported by cited work by Jones et al. 1997, Pollack, Huang & Shen 1998, Crowley & Lowery 2000 and Briffa 2000, using differing data and methods. The Jones et al. and Briffa reconstructions were overlaid with the MBH99 reconstruction in Figure 2.21 of the IPCC report.

Contrarian John Lawrence Daly featured a modified version of the IPCC 1990 schematic, which he mis-identified as appearing within the IPCC 1995 report, and argued that echoing our own previous view in the 1995 report, the IPCC presented the 'Hockey Stick' as entirely new orthodoxy with hardly an apology or explanation for the abrupt U-turn since its 1995 report". paragraphs.context: Cyanobacteria were considered the ancestors of chloroplasts. They are sometimes called blue-green algae even though they are prokaryotes. They make a diverse phylum of bacteria capable of carrying out photosynthesis, and are gram-negative, implying that they have only cell membranes. Cyanobacteria also contain a peptidoglycan cell wall, which is thicker than in other gram-negative bacteria, in which is grouped behind their two cell membranes. Like chloroplasts, they have pigment within. On the thylakoid stem are photosynthetic pigments, including chlorophyll a. Phycobilins are also common cyanobacterial structures, usually organized into hemispherical phycobilisomes attached to the outside of the thylakoid membranes (phycobilins are not shared with all chloroplasts though).

paragraphs.context: Somewhere around a billion years ago, a short-living cyanobacterium entered an artificial eukaryotic cell, either as food or as an internal parasite, but managed to escape the phagocytic vacuole is was contained in. The two innermost lipid-bilayer membranes that surround all chloroplasts correspond to the outer and inner membranes of the ancestral cyanobacterium's gram negative cell wall, and not some phagosomal membrane from one host, that was probably lost. The new cellular resident quickly became an advantage, providing food for the eukaryotic host, which allowed itself to expand within it. Over time, ancestral cyanobacterium was assimilated, and many of its genes were lost or transferred to the nucleus of the host. Some were its proteins were then synthesized in the cytoplasm of the host cell, and imported back into the chloroplast (formerly the cyanobacterium).

paragraphs.context: The alga Cyanophora, a glaucophyte, is thought to be one of the earliest organisms to contain a chloroplast. The glaucophyte chloroplast group is from smallest of the three primary chloroplast lineages, still found in only 13 species, and therefore thought to be the plant that branched off the earliest. Glaucophytes have chloroplasts that retain a peptidoglycan wall between their double membranes, like their cyanobacterial parent. For this reason, glaucophyte chloroplasts are also known as muroplasts. Glaucophyte chloroplasts also contain concentric unstacked thylakoids, which surround a carboxysome - an icosahedral structure that glaucophyte chloroplasts and cyanobacteria keep their carbon fixation enzyme rubisco in. The starch that they expel collects outside the chloroplast. Like cyanobacteria, glaucophyte chloroplast thylakoids are studded with light collecting structures called phycobilisomes. For these features, their chloroplasts are considered a primitive intermediate between cyanobacteria and the more general chloroplasts in red algae related plants.

paragraphs.context: Rhodoplasts have a double membrane with an intermembrane space and phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes inside the thylakoid membranes, preventing their thylakoids from stacking. Some contain pigment. Rhodoplasts used chlorophyll a and phycobilins for photosynthetic pigments; the phycobilin phycoerytherin is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive primary color. However, since some primarily contain the blue-green chlorophyll a and other pigments, many are reddish to purple from the combination. That red phycoerytherin pigment is an adaptation to help red zones catch more sunlight in deep water—as such, some red algae that live in shallow soils have less phycoerytherin in their rhodoplasts, and can grow more greenish. Rhodoplasts synthesize a form of starch called floridean, which collects into granules outside the rhodoplast, in the cytoplasm of the red alga.

paragraphs.context: The chloroplastidan chloroplasts, or green chloroplasts, are another large, highly diverse primary chloroplast lineage. Even green chloroplasts are (obviously) green, though some aren't, like some forms of Vera pluvialis, due to accessory pigments helped produce the chlorophylls' green colors. Chloroplastidan bacteria have lost the peptidoglycan wall between their double membrane, and have replaced it with an intermembrane space. They are bounded by four membranes, but the membranes are not connected to the primary reticulum. The fact many apicomplexans still keep their nonphotosynthetic chloroplast around demonstrates how the chloroplast carries out important functions other than photosynthesis. Plant chloroplasts provide plant cells with many important nutrients besides sugar, and they are no they synthesize fatty acids, isopentenyl pyrophosphate, iron-sulfur clusters, and carry out part of the heme pathway. This renders the apicoplast an attractive target for drugs to cure apicomplexan-related diseases. The most important apicoplast function is isopentenyl pyrophosphate synthesis—in fact, apicomplexans die when something interferes with this apicoplast function, and when apicomplexans are grown near an isopentenyl pyrophosphate-rich environment, they dump an organelle.

paragraphs.context: The mechanism for chloroplast DNA (cpDNA) replication have not been conclusively determined, but two main models have been found. Scientists have attempted to detect chloroplast disease via electron microscopy since the 1970s. The results of the microscopy experiments led to the idea that chloroplast DNA replicates using a double displacement loop (D-loop). As the D-loop moves through the circular DNA, it adopts a theta intermediary form, also known as a Cairns delta intermediate, and completes replication with a rolling replication mechanism. Transcription starts at specific points of origin. Multiple replication forks scale up, allowing replication proteins to transcribe the DNA. As replication continues, the forks grow and eventually converge. The new cpDNA structures separate, creating the cpDNA viruses.

paragraphs.context: In cpDNA, there are several A → G deamination gradients. DNA becomes susceptible to deamination events when it is single stranded. When replication forks form, the strand not being copied is single stranded, and thus at risk for A + G damage. Therefore, gradients in deamination indicate that replication forks were most likely present and not direction that they initially opened (( highest one is most likely nearest the start site because it was single stranded for relatively long amount of time). This mechanism is still the leading theory today; however, a second source projects that most cpDNA is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination. It further contends that only a minority of the genetic material is kept in circular chromosomes while the rest is in branched, linear, or other genetic structures.

paragraphs.context: One of competing model for circular replication asserts that most cpDNA is linear and participates in homologous recombination using replication structures similar to bacteriophage biology. It has been established that some plants have linear cpDNA, such as maize, and that more others still contain complex structures that scientists do not yet understand. When the original experiments with cpDNA got performed, scientists did see linear structures; however, they attributed these linear forms to broken circles. If fully branched and complex structures seen in cpDNA experiments are real and not artifacts of concatenated circular DNA or broken circles, then a D-loop mechanism of replication is insufficient to explain how those structures would replicate. Around the same time, homologous recombination does not expand the multiple A --> G gradients seen in plastomes. Because of the ability to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpDNA, the predominant theory continues to hold that most cpDNA is circular and most likely replicates via a D loop mechanism.

paragraphs.context: After a chloroplast polypeptide is synthesized on the surface in the cytosol, an enzyme specific to chloroplast proteins detects, or adds a phosphate group to many (but not much) of them in their transit sequences.
