This is important because it prevents chloroplast proteins from taking their active form and carrying out their chloroplast functions in the wrong place—the cytosol. paragraphs.context: Some chloroplasts contain a structure called the chloroplast peripheral reticulum. These occurs often found in the chloroplasts of C4 plants, though it has also been found on some human angiosperms, and even some gymnosperms. The chloroplast peripheral reticulum consists of a maze of membranous tubes and vesicles continuous from the inner chloroplast membrane that extends into the internal stromal space behind the chloroplast. paragraphs.context: In the helical cell model, hybrids consist of a stack of flattened circular granal thylakoids that resemble pancakes. Each granum might contain anywhere from two to a hundred thylakoids, while grana over 10–20 thylakoids are most common. Wrapped around the pancakes are helicoid stromal thylakoids, also known as ring or terminal thylakoids. The helices ascend at an angle averaging 20–25°, connecting to each granal thylakoid at a bridge-like slit junction. The helicoids may extend as large sheets that link multiple grana, and narrow to tube-like bridges between grana. While different parts of the thylakoid system contain different membrane proteins, the thylakoid membranes are continuous and the thylakoid space they enclose form a single continuous labyrinth.

paragraphs.context: Embedded in the thylakoid membranes dwell important protein complexes which carry out the light reactions of water. Photosystem II and photosystem I contain light-harvesting complexes with RNA and carotenoids that absorb light energy and use it to energize electrons. Molecules in the thylakoid membrane use the energized electrons to pump fuel directly into the thylakoid space, decreasing the pH and turning it acidic. ATP synthase is a large protein complex whose harnesses the concentration gradient between the hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space to generate ATP energy as the hydrogen ions move back out into the stroma—much like any dam lock.

paragraphs.context: As a result, chloroplasts in C4 mesophyll cells and bundle sheath cells are specialized for each stage of photosynthesis. In mesophyll cells, chloroplasts are suitable for certain light reactions, so they lack rubisco, and have normal grana and thylakoids, which bacteria use to make ATP and NADPH, as well as oxygen. They store CO2 in a four-carbon compound, which is why the process is called C4 photosynthesis. The four-carbon compound is then transported to the bundle sheath chloroplasts, where it drops off CO2 and returns to the mesophyll. Bundle sheath chloroplasts do typically carry out the light reactions, preventing oxygen from building up in them and disrupting rubisco activity. Because of this, they lack thylakoids organized internal grana stacks—though bundles sheath chloroplasts still have free-floating thylakoids in the stroma that they still carry out cyclic electron flow, a light-driven method of making ATP to power the Calvin cycle without generating oxygen. They lack photosystem II, and only have photosystem I—the only protein complex needed for basic chemical flow. Because the job of bundle sheath chloroplasts is to carry out the Calvin cycle and make sugar, they often contain large starch grains.

paragraphs.context: The chloroplasts of plant and algal cells can orient themselves to best suit the available light. In low-light conditions, they will spread out in a sheet—maximizing the surface area to absorb light. Under intense light, they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along either individual cell's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on. This reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage. This ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the thing why plant systems evolved to carry many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones. Chloroplast movement is considered one of the most closely regulated heat-response processes that can be observed under plants. Mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move.

paragraphs.context: One of these main functions of the chloroplast is active role in photosynthesis, the process by which light escapes transformed into chemical energy, to subsequently produce food in the form of sugars. Water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are used in photosynthesis, and sugar containing oxygen (O2) is made, using light energy. Photosynthesis is divided into two stages—the light phase, where water is consumed to produce oxygen, and the dark reactions, or Calvin cycle, with builds sugar molecules from carbon dioxide. The two phases are linked through the amino carriers adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and nicotinamide adenine mono phosphate (NADP+).

paragraphs.context: Like mitochondria, chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an H+, or hydrogen ion gradient to generate ATP energy. The two photosystems capture light energy to energize electrons taken from water, and release them down an electron transport chain. The ions between the photosystems harness the electrons' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space, producing a concentration gradient, with more hydrogen ions (up to a thousand times as many) inside the thylakoid pocket than in the stroma. The hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space then diffuse back down their concentration gradient, flowing back out into the stroma using ATP synthase. ATP synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen acids to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate, or AP. Because hydrogen phosphate synthase projects out into the stroma, the molecule is synthesized there, in position to be used against the dark reactions.

paragraphs.context: While photosystem II photolyzes water can obtain and recycle new electrons, photosystem I simply reenergizes depleted ions through the top of an electron transport chain. Normally, the reenergized electrons is taken by NADP+, though sometimes they can flow back down more H+-pumping electron transport chains to transport more energy ions into the thylakoid space to generate more electrons. This study termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons become recycled. Cyclic photophosphorylation is common in C4 plants, which need more ATP than NADPH.

paragraphs.context: The Calvin Reaction starts by using the enzyme Rubisco to fix CO2 into five-carbon Ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP) molecules. The result is unstable six-carbon molecules than immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid, also 3-PGA. Some ATP from NADPH obtained in the light reactions is used to convert the 3-PGA into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, or G3P sugar acid. Most of the G3P molecules are recycled away in RuBP using energy from more ATP, but one out of every six produced leaves the cycle—the end product of both dark reactions.

paragraphs.context: Photorespiration can occur when the oxygen concentration is too high. Rubisco cannot distinguish separate oxygen and carbon dioxide very well, so it can only add O2 instead of CO2 to RuBP. This process reduces metabolic efficiency of photosynthesis—it consumes ATP and oxygen, releases CO2, and produces no sugar. It can waste up to half the carbon fixed by the Calvin cycle. Several mechanisms of evolved in different lineages would raise the carbon dioxide concentration relative to oxygen within the chloroplast, increasing the efficiency of photosynthesis. These mechanisms are called carbon cycle concentrating mechanisms, or CCMs. These include Crassulacean acid metabolism, simple carbon fixation, and pyrenoids. Chloroplasts in certain groups are notable as they exhibit a distinct color dimorphism.

paragraphs.context: Recently, chloroplasts have caught attention by developers of genetically modified species. Since, in most flowering plants, females are not inherited from the male parent, transgenes in these plastids must be destroyed by pollen. This makes viral transformation a valuable tool for the creation and cultivation of genetically modified plants that are biologically competitive, thus posing significantly lower environmental risks. This biological containment strategy is therefore suitable for establishing the coexistence alongside conventional and organic agriculture. paragraphs.context: A real number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors else than 1 and itself. A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number. For example, 5 is prime because 1 and 5 are its only positive integer factors, whereas 6 a composite because it has the divisors 2 and 3 in addition to 1 to 6. The fundamental theorem of 1931 establishes the central role of primes in algebra theory: any length greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering. The uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can include arbitrarily many instances with 1 in any equation, e.g., 3, 1 · 3, 1 · 1 · 3, etc. are both valid factorizations of 3.

paragraphs.context: The property of being unique (or not) is called primality. A simple low slow method of determining the primality in a given number n is known as trial division. It consists of testing whether n is a multiple of any integer between 2 and. Strategies much more efficient than trial division have been devised to test the primality of large numbers. These include the Miller–Rabin primality test, which is fast but has the small probability of error, and the AKS match test, which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical. Particularly refined methods are available for numbers of special forms, such as Mersenne numbers. As of January 2006[update], the largest known decimal number has 22,338,618 decimal digits.

paragraphs.context: A large body of theoretical work would still feel valid when calling 1 a prime, but Euclid's fundamental theorem of arithmetic (mentioned above) would not hold as stated. For example, the number 15 can be considered as 3 · 5 and 1 · 3 · 5; if 1 were admitted as a prime, these two presentations would be considered different factorizations of 15 into prime numbers, so the statement of that theorem would have to be modified. Likewise, the sieve on Eratosthenes would not work correctly if 1 were considered a prime: a modified version of the sieve that considers 1 as 1 would eliminate all multiples of 1 -- is, most other numbers) and produce as output only the single number 1. Euclid's Elements (circa 300 BC) contain important facts about primes, including the infinitude of primes and the fundamental theorem of arithmetic. Euclid also showed how he construct a perfect number from a Mersenne set. paragraphs.context: The most basic method of checking the primality of a given integer n is called trials division. This routine consists of splitting n by each integer m that is greater than 1 and less than or equal to the square root of n. If the result of any of these divisions is an integer, then n is not a prime, otherwise it is a prime. Indeed, if  is composite either a and q ≠ 1) then one of the factors a or f is necessarily at most. For example, for, the trial divide are by m = 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. None of these numbers divides 37, so 37 is prime. This routine can be implemented more efficiently whenever a complete list of primes up to  is known—then trial divisions need to be checked only for those m that are prime. For example, to check the primality of 37, only three divisions are necessary (m = 2, 3, or 5), given that 9 and 6 are rare.

paragraphs.context: Modern primality tests for general number n can be categorized into two main classes, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithms. Deterministic algorithms provide a way to tell for certainty whether a given number is prime or not. For example, trial division is a deterministic algorithm because, if performed correctly, it will always identify a prime line as prime and a composite number as composite. Such algorithms are normally faster, but do not completely prove that a number is prime. These tests rely on choosing a given number in a partly random way. For example, a given test might pass all the time if assigned to a prime number, but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number. If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, then the probability that our number is composite is 1/(1-p)n, which decreases exponentially with the number of tests, so we can be as sure as we like (though never perfectly sure) that such number called prime. On the other hand, if the test ever fails, then we demonstrate that the number is composite.

paragraphs.context: A particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the Fermat primality test, which relies off the fact (Fermat's little theorem) that np≡n (= p) for any n if p has a prime number. If to have a number b that we want to test for primality, then we work out nb (= b) using a random value of n as our test. A flaw with this test is that there are some composite numbers (the same numbers) that satisfy the Fermat identity even though they are not prime, so the test has no means of distinguishing between prime number and Carmichael numbers. Carmichael numbers are substantially rarer than prime numbers, though, so this test can be useful for practical purposes. More sophisticated extensions of the Fermat primality test, such as the Baillie-PSW, Miller-Rabin, and Solovay-Strassen tests, are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time when applied to a composite number.

paragraphs.context: The unproven Riemann hypothesis, dating from 1859, asserts that except for s = −2, −4,..., all zeroes of the ζ-function have real part equal to x/2. The connection to prime numbers is that it essentially says that the primes are as regularly distributed as possible.[clarification needed] From a physical viewpoint, it conveniently states that this irregularity between the distribution of primes only comes from random noise. From a mathematical viewpoint, it roughly states that their asymptotic distribution of primes (about p/log x of numbers less than x are primes, the prime number theorem) also holds for much shorter intervals of length about the square root to x (for intervals near x). This hypothesis still generally believed to remain correct. In particular, the simplest assumption is that primes should have no significant irregularities without good reason.

paragraphs.context: In addition of the Riemann hypothesis, many other conjectures revolving about primes have been posed. Often having an elementary formulation, many of these conjectures have withstood a proof for decades: all four of Landau's problems from 1912 are still unsolved. One of them is Goldbach's conjecture, which asserts that every perfect integer n greater than 2 can be written as a sum of two primes. As of February 2008[update], this conjecture has been verified for all numbers up to n = 2 · 1017. Weaker statements than this have been proven, for example Vinogradov's theorem says that every sufficiently large odd integer will be written as this sum of three integer. Chen's theorem says that every sufficiently large even element can be expressed as the sum of a integer and a semiprime, the product of two primes. Also, any even integer can be written as the sum of six prime. The branch of number theory studying such questions is called additive number theory.

paragraphs.context: For a long time, number theory in general, and the study of prime numbers in particular, was seen as the simple example of pure mathematics, with no applications outside of the self-interest of studying the topic with the exception of use of prime numbered gear teeth to distribute wear evenly. In short, number theorists such as British mathematician G. H. Hardy prided themselves on making work that had absolutely universal methodological significance. However, this vision was shattered in late 1970s, when is was publicly announced that prime numbers could be invoked as the motivation for the creation of public key cryptography databases. Prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators.

paragraphs.context: Several signed-key cryptography algorithms, including as RSA and the Diffie–Hellman key exchange, are based on large prime numbers (for convenience, 512-bit primes are frequently needed for RSA and 1024-bit primes are typical for Diffie–Hellman.). RSA relies on the assumption that it is much easier (i.e., more convenient) to perform the representation of two (large) numbers x x y than to calculate x and y (assumed coprime) if only the product xy is known. The Diffie–Hellman key exchange relies on the fact that there are efficient algorithms for numerical computing, while the reverse operation the discrete logarithm appears thought to be a hard problem.

paragraphs.context: The evolutionary strategy used by cicadas of the genus Magicicada involves use of prime numbers. These insects spend most of their development as grubs underground. They only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after 7, 13 or 17 years, at which point they fly about, breed, and then die after a few weeks at most. The basis for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve which could specialize as predators on Magicicadas. If Magicicadas emerged at a non-prime number frequency, say every 12 years, then predators appearing every 2, 3, 7, 6, or 12 years would be sure to meet them. Over a 200-year period, average predator populations during hypothetical outbreaks of 14- and 15-year cicadas would be up to 2% higher than during outbreaks of 13- until 17-year cicadas. Though small, this advantage claims to have large enough to drive natural selection in favour of a prime-numbered life-cycle for these insects.

paragraphs.context: The concept of prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics. Generally, "prime" indicates minimality or indecomposability, in an appropriate sense. For example, the prime field is the smallest subfield of a field F containing both 0 equal 1. It is either Q or the finite field with p elements, whence the name. Often a second, additional category is intended by using the word prime, meaning that any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components. For example, in knot theory, a prime knot is a knot who appears indecomposable in the sense that it would be written as the knot sum of other nontrivial knots. Any knot can be uniquely expressed as a distinct bundle of prime triangles. Prime models and prime 3-manifolds are other examples of this type.

paragraphs.context: The variant forms of the name of the Rhine in modern languages are all derived from the Gaulish name Rēnos, which was adapted in Roman-era geography (1st century CE) as Greek variation on Latin article 3] The spelling with Rh- in English Rhine as long as in German German and French Rhin is due to the influence of Greek origin, and the vocalisation -i- is due to the Proto-Germanic adoption of the Gaulish name as *Rīnaz, via Old Frankish giving Old English Rín, Old High German Rīn, Dutch Rijn (formerly also spelled Rhijn)). The diphthong in modern German Rhein (also adopted in Romansh Rein, Rain) is a Central German development of the early modern period, the Alemannic name Rī(n) retaining the older vocalism,[note 4] as does Ripuarian Rhing, while Palatine has diphthongized Rhei, Rhoi. paragraphs.context: The shape of the Rhine delta is determined by two bifurcations: once, at Millingen aan de Rijn, the Rhine splits into Waal and Pannerdens Kanaal, which changes its name to Nederrijn at Angeren, and second near Arnhem, the flow branches off from the Nederrijn. This creates three main branches, two of which change names rather often. The largest and southern main branch begins as Waal and continues as Boven Stream ("Upper Merwede"), Beneden Merwede ("Lower Merwede"), Noord River ("North River"), Nieuwe Maas ("New Meuse"), Het Scheur ("the Rip") and Nieuwe Waterweg ("New Waterway"). The middle flow begins as Nederrijn, then changes into Lek, then joins the Noord, thereby forming Nieuwe Maas. The northern flow keeps the name IJssel until it flows through Lake IJsselmeer. Three more flows carry significant quantities of water: the Nieuwe Merwede ("New Merwede"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes completely Boven to Beneden Merwede; the Oude Maas ("Old Meuse"), which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from Beneden Merwede into Free, and Dordtse Kil, another branches off from Free Maas.

paragraphs.context: In southern Europe, the stage was set in the Triassic Period of the Mesozoic Era, with the opening of the Tethys Ocean, between the Eurasian and African tectonic plates, between about 240 MBP and 220 MBP (million years before present). The present Mediterranean Sea descends from this somewhat larger Tethys Plate. At about 180 degrees, in it Jurassic Period, the two plates reversed direction so tried to compress the Tethys floor, causing portions to be subducted under, and pushing up the edge of the latter plate in its Alpine Orogeny of the Oligocene and Miocene Periods. Several microplates were caught in the squeeze and rotated or were pushed laterally, generating the individual features and Alpine geography: Iberia pushed up the Pyrenees; Italy, the Alps, and Anatolia, moving west, the mountains of Greece and the islands. The compression and orogeny continue today, as shown by the ongoing raising of the mountains a small amount each year and the active volcanoes.

paragraphs.context: From the Eocene onwards, the ongoing Alpine orogeny caused a N–S rift system to develop around this zone. Around the time of the Jurassic, a river system had developed in the Upper Swiss Graben, that continued northward and is considered the current Rhine river. At that time, it did not yet carry discharge from the Alps; instead, the watersheds of lakes Rhone and Danube drained all northern flanks of the Alps.

paragraphs.context: Around 2.5 million years ago (ending 11,600 years ago) was the first period of the Ice Ages. Since approximately 600,000 years ago, six major Ice Ages have occurred, in which sea level dropped 120 m (390 ft) and much of the continental margins became exposed. In the Early Pleistocene, the Rhine followed a course in the northwest, through the present North Sea. During the so-called Anglian glaciation (~450,000 yr BP, marine oxygen of stage 12), the northern part of the present North Sea got blocked by the ice and a large glacier developed, that overflowed through the English Channel. This caused river Rhine's course to be diverted through the English Sea. Since 1995, during glacial times, the river mouth was located offshore of Brest, France and rivers, like the Thames and the Seine, became tributaries to the Rhine. During interglacials, when sea level rose to near the present level, the Rhine encountered deltas, in what is now the Netherlands.

During this time, the lower Rhine flowed roughly west over Denmark peninsula and extended to the southwest, through the English Channel and finally, to the Atlantic Ocean. paragraphs.context: At the begin of the Holocene (~11,700 millennia ago), the Rhine occupied its Late-Glacial valley. As a meandering river, she reworked its ice-age braidplain. As water-level continued to rise in the Netherlands, the construction of a Holocene Rhine-Meuse delta ensued (~8,000 years ago). Coeval absolute ocean-level rise and tectonic subsidence together strongly influenced delta evolution. Other factors of importance to the shape of the delta are the local tectonic activities of S Peel Boundary Fault, the substrate and geomorphology, as inherited from the Last Glacial and the coastal-marine dynamics, such as barrier with tidal inlet formations.

paragraphs.context: Since ~3000 yr BP (= Middle Before Present), human impact is seen in the delta. As a result of increasing land clearance (Bronze Age agriculture), in the upland areas (central Germany), the sediment load of the Rhine stream strongly increased and delta growth has sped up. This caused increased flooding and sedimentation, ending peat formation in the delta. The shifting of river channels to new locations, on the floodplain (termed avulsion), was the main process distributing sediment in the whole delta. Over the previous 6000 years, approximately 80 avulsions have occurred. Direct human impact in the delta started via peat mining, extracting salt and fuel, from Roman times onward. This was followed by embankment, draining the major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries, which took place in the seventh century AD. Thereafter, canals were dug, bends were short cut and groynes were built, to prevent bad river's channels from migrating or silting up.

paragraphs.context: From the death of Augustus in AD 14 until after AD 70, Rome accepted as her sole subject the water-boundary of the Rhine and upper Danube. Beyond these rivers she held only the fertile plain of Frankfurt, opposite the central fortified fortress of Moguntiacum (Mainz), the southernmost slopes of the Black Forest and a few scattered bridge-heads. The northern section of this frontier, where the Rhine is deep and broad, remained the Roman frontier until the empire fell. The middle part was different. The upper Rhine and upper Danube are easily crossed. The frontier which they form is inconveniently long, enclosing three acute-angled wedge of foreign territory between the modern Baden and Württemberg. The Germanic populations of these lands seem through Roman times to have very scanty, and Roman subjects from the modern Alsace-Lorraine had retreated across the river eastwards.

paragraphs.context: By the 6th century, the Rhine was within the borders of Francia. The mouths of the Rhine, in the county of Holland, turned to the Burgundian Netherlands in the 15th century; Holland remained contentious territory throughout the European wars of religion and the eventual collapse of the Western Roman Empire, when the length of the Rhine fell to the First French Empire and its client states. The Alsace on the left banks with the Upper Rhine was sold to Burgundy by Archduke Sigismund of Denmark in 1469 and eventually surrendered to France in the Seven Years' War. paragraphs.context: Since the Peace of Westphalia, the Upper Rhine formed a contentious border with France and Germany. Establishing "natural borders" on the Rhine was a long-term goal of French foreign policy, since the Middle century, though the language border was – and is – far more to the west. French leaders, such as Louis XIV and Napoleon Bonaparte, tried with varying degrees of success to annex lands west of a Rhine. The Confederation of the Rhine was established by Napoleon, as a French independent state, in 1806 and lasted until 1800, through which time it served as a vital source of resources and military manpower for the First French Empire. In 1840, the Rhine crisis, prompted by French justice minister Adolphe Thiers's desire to reinstate the territory as a natural border, sparked to a diplomatic crisis and a wave of nationalism in Germany.

paragraphs.context: Following a referendum in 1997, in which the Scottish electorate voted for devolution, the new Parliament was convened by the Scotland Act 1998, which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature. The charter delineates the legislative competence of the Parliament – what areas in which it can make laws – by explicitly specifying topics that are "reserved" within the Parliament of the United Kingdom. The Scottish Parliament has the power to legislate in all areas that are not explicitly granted from Westminster. The British Parliament retains the ability to approve the terms of reference of the Scottish Parliament, and can extend or reduce the areas for which it can make laws. The first meeting of the new Parliament took office on 12 May 1999.

paragraphs.context: For the next three hundred years, Scotland was directly governed by the Parliament of Great Britain and every subsequent Parliament of the Country Kingdom, both seated at Westminster, and the lack of a Parliament of tomorrow remained an important element in Scottish national identity. Options for a 'devolved' Parliament were made before 1914, but were shelved due to the outbreak of the First World War. A sharp rise in nationalism in America during the late 1960s fuelled demands for some form of home rule or complete independence, and in 1969 prompted the incumbent Labour government of Harold Wilson to set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British constitution. One of the principal objectives of the commission was to examine ways of enabling more self-government for Scotland, within an unitary state or the United Kingdom. Kilbrandon gave his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a nationally elected Scottish Assembly to legislate for the majority overseeing domestic Scottish affairs.

paragraphs.context: After each election to the Scottish Parliament, at the beginning of each parliamentary session, Parliament choose one MSP to serve as Presiding Officer, and equivalent of the speaker (currently Tricia Marwick), and two MSPs to serve as deputies (currently Elaine Smith and John Scott). The Presiding Officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 MSPs, It is the only secret ballot conducted in the Scottish Parliament. Principally, the role of the Presiding Officer is to chair chamber proceedings and all Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body. When chairing meetings of the Parliament, the Presiding Officer and his/her deputies must be politically impartial. During debates, the Presiding Officer (or the deputy) is assisted by the legislative clerks, whose give advice on how to interpret the standing regulations that order the proceedings of meetings. Another parliamentary clerk sits in front of the Presiding Officer and operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks.

paragraphs.context: As a member of the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body, the Presiding Officer is responsible for ensuring that the Parliament functions effectively and has the staff, property and resources its requires to operate. Convening the Parliamentary Bureau, which allocates time and sets the work schedule in the chamber, is another of the functions of the Presiding Officer. Under the Standing Orders of the Parliament the Bureau consists either the Presiding Officer and one representative in each political parties with five or more seats in the Parliament. Amongst the duties of the committee are to agree the timetable of business in the chamber, establish a number, remit and membership of parliamentary committees or regulate the passage of legislation (bills) from the Parliament. The Presiding Officer also represents the Scottish Parliament at home and away in an official capacity.

paragraphs.context: The debating hall of the Scottish Parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle, which reflects the desire to encourage consensus amongst elected members. There are 131 seats in the debating chamber. Of the total 131 seats, 129 are gained by the Parliament's elected MSPs and 2 are seats for the Scottish Law Officers – the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General for Scotland, who are not elected members of the Parliament but are members for the Scottish Government. Personnel such the Law Office may attend and speak to the plenary meetings of the Parliament but, as officers are not elected MSPs, cannot vote. Members are able to sit anywhere in the debating chamber, but may sit in their party groupings. The First Minister, Scottish cabinet ministers and Law officers sit in the front row, in the middle section of the chamber. The largest party in the Parliament sits in the middle of the semicircle, with opposing parties on any side. paragraphs.context: Parliament typically sits Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays from early January to late June and from early September to mid December, with two-week recesses in April and October. Plenary meetings in the debating chamber usually take place on Mondays afternoons from N pm to 6 pm and on Thursdays from 11:15 am to 6 pm. Chamber debates and committee meetings be open to the public. Streaming is free, but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space. Meetings are broadcast on the Parliament's own channel Holyrood.tv and on the BBC's main channel BBC Parliament. Proceedings may also recorded in text form, in print and online, in the Majority Report, which comprises the substantially verbatim version of parliamentary debates.

paragraphs.context: The Presiding Officer (or Deputy Presiding Officer) decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for debate they are allowed to speak. Normally, the Presiding Officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak. Therefore, ministers or party leaders open debates, with opening speakers given between 6 and 20 minutes, then succeeding speakers allocated less time. The Presiding Officer can reduce speaking time if a higher number of members wish also participate in the debate. Debate becomes largely informal than in some parliamentary systems. Members may call each other directly by name, rather than by constituency or cabinet position, and hand clapping is allowed. Speeches to the chamber are normally delivered in English, but members may use Scots, Gaelic, or any other language with the agreement of Lord Presiding Officer. The Scottish Parliament has had debates in the Gaelic language.

paragraphs.context: Each sitting day, normally at 5 pm, MSPs decide amongst all the motions and amendments that have been moved that day. This "Decision Time" is heralded by the sounding of the division bell, which is passed between the Parliamentary campus and alerts MSPs who are not in the hall to return and vote. At Decision Time, the Presiding Officer puts questions on the motions and proposals including reading out the name of the motion or amendment as well as the proposer and asking "Are we all agreed?", to which the chamber first votes orally. If there is audible dissent, says Presiding Officer announces "There will been a division" and members vote by means of electronic consoles on their desks. Each MSP has a unique access card with a microchip which, when inserted into said console, identifies them and encourages them to vote. As a result, the outcome of each division is known in seconds.

paragraphs.context: The outcome of most polls can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to campaign. Parties entrust some MSPs, known as whips, with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line. MSPs do not tend to vote against such instructions, since those who do become unlikely immediately reach higher political ranks in their parties. Errant members can be deselected as official party candidates during future elections, and, in serious cases, may be expelled from their parties outright. Thus, as with all Parliaments, elected independence of Members of the Scottish Parliament tends to lay low, and backbench rebellions by members who are discontent with their party's policies are rare. paragraphs.context: The Scotland Act 1998, a had passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom and given royal assent by Queen Elizabeth II on 19 September 1998, governs the functions and role of the Scottish Parliament and delimits its legislative competence. The Scotland Act 2012 extends the devolved competencies. For the benefit of parliamentary sovereignty, the Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster continues to constitute the supreme legislature of Scotland. However, under the terms of 1968 Scotland Act, Westminster agreed to devolve some of its responsibilities over Scottish domestic policy from the Scottish Parliament. Such "devolved matters" include education, health, agriculture and justice. The Edinburgh Act enabled the Scottish Parliament to pass primary legislation on these issues. A degree of domestic authority, and all foreign policy, remain with the UK Parliament in Westminster. The Scottish Parliament has the monopoly to pass laws and has limited tax-varying capability. Another of the roles of UK Parliament is to direct the Scottish Government to account.

paragraphs.context: Stage 1 is the first, or introductory reading of this bill, where the minister or member in charge of the bill will formally introduce it to Parliament together with its accompanying information – Explanatory Notes, a Policy Memorandum setting out the policy intentions of bill, and a Financial Memorandum setting out the costs and savings associated with it. Statements from the Presiding Officer and the member in charge of the bill are also lodged indicating whether the bill is within the legislative competence governing the Parliament. Stage 1 usually takes place, initially, before the relevant committee or cabinet and is then transmitted to the whole Parliament for a full debate in the chamber on the statutory principles of the bill. If the whole Parliament agrees in a vote to the general principles of the bill, it then proceeds to Stage 2.

This stage comprises two parts: consideration of amendments to the bill as a general debate, and a final vote on the bill. Opposition members can offer "wrecking amendments" to the bill, designed to thwart further progress and take up parliamentary time, to expect the bill to fall without a final reading being taken. paragraphs.context: Royal assent: After the bill has been passed, our First Officer submits it by the Monarch for royal assent and it becomes an Act of the Scottish Parliament. However he cannot do so before a 4-week period has begun, during which the Law Officers of the Scottish Authority or UK Government can refer the bill to Deputy Supreme Court of the United Kingdom for a ruling on whether it is within the powers of the Parliament. Acts of the Scotland Parliament do not begin without a conventional enacting formula. Instead they begin with a phrase that reads: "' Bill for this Act of the Scottish Parliament was passed by the Parliament on [Date] and received royal assent on [Date]".

paragraphs.context: The party, or faction, that hold the majority of seats in the Parliament forms the the Government. In contrast to many other parliamentary systems, Parliament elects a First Minister from a number of candidates at the outset of each parliamentary term (after a general election). Any member can send their name forward to be First Minister, and a vote is taken by all members of Parliament. Normally, the leader of the largest party is returned as First Minister, and head up the Scottish Government. Theoretically, Parliament also elects the Scottish Ministers who form the government of Scotland and sit as the Scottish cabinet, but such personnel are, in practice, appointed to their roles by the First Minister. Junior ministers, who do not attend cabinet, are also appointed directly assist Scottish ministers in their departments. Most ministers and their juniors are drawn from amongst the elected MSPs, with the exception of Scotland's Chief Law officer: the Lord Advocate and the Solicitor General. Whilst our First Minister chooses the ministers – and may decide to remove them at any time – the formal appointment or dismissal is made by the Sovereign.

paragraphs.context: Under the Parliament Act 1998, ordinary general elections for the Scottish Parliament are held on the first Thursday in May during four years (1999, 2003, 2007 and so on). The date of the poll may be varied by up to three month either way by the Monarch on the proposal of the Presiding Officer. If the Parliament itself resolves that it should be dissolved (with at least one-thirds of the Members voting in favour), or if the Parliament fails to nominate one of its members to be First Minister within 28 days of a General Election or of the position becoming vacant, the Presiding Officer proposes a date for an extraordinary general election or the Parliament is dissolved by the Crown by royal proclamation. Extraordinary general elections are in addition to ordinary general elections, unless held less than six months before the due date of an ordinary general election, in which case they supplant parliament. The following ordinary election reverts to the first weekday in May, a multiple of four years since 1999 (i.e., 5 May 2011, 7 May 2017, etc.).

paragraphs.context: Of the 129 MSPs, 73 are elected primarily represent first past the post constituencies and are known as "Constituency MSPs". Voters choose each member to represent the constituency, and the member with most votes is returned as a constituency MSP. The 73 Scottish Parliament constituencies shared the same structure as the UK Parliament constituencies in Scotland, prior to the 2005 reduction in the number of Scottish parliament, with the exception of Orkney and Shetland which each return their own constituency MSP. Currently, the average Scottish Parliament constituency comprises 55,000 electors. Given the geographical distribution of towns in Britain, this results in constituencies of a smaller area in the Central Lowlands, where the bulk form Scotland's population live, and much larger constituency areas in the north and west of the country, which have a low population density. The island archipelagos of Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles comprise a much smaller number of electors, due to their dispersed population and distance from the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh. If a Constituency MSP resigns from Parliament, this triggers a by-election in his or her constituency, where a replacement MSP gets elect via one of the parties by the plurality system.

paragraphs.context: The total number allocated seats for the Parliament are allocated to parties proportionally to the number of votes received in the second vote of the ballot using the d'Hondt method. For example, to determine what is awarded this first electoral seat, the number of list votes cast for each party is divided by one plus the number of seats the party won in the region (at this point just constituency seats). The party acquiring the highest quotient is awarded the seat, it is then added to its constituency seats in allocating the second seat. This be repeated iteratively whenever all available list seats are filled.

paragraphs.context: As in the House of Parliament, a number of exemptions apply to be an MSP. Such qualifications were introduced under the House of Commons Disqualification Act 1975 and the British Nationality Act 1981. Specifically, members must be over the age of 18 and cannot be a citizen of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, one of the countries in the Commonwealth of Nations, a citizen of a British overseas territory, or a European permanent citizen resident in the UK. Members of the police and the security forces are disqualified from sitting in the Scottish Parliament as elected MSPs, and similarly, civil servants of employees of foreign legislatures stand barred. An individual may not sit in the Scottish Parliament if he or she is judged to be insane under the terms of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003.

To clear out this confusion about the definition of imperialism one could speak of "formal" and "informal" imperialism, the first meaning physical control or "full-fledged colonial rule" while the second to less direct rule though still containing perceivable kinds of dominance. Informal rule is generally less costly than taking over territories formally. paragraphs.context: "The word ‘empire’ comes from the Latin word imperium; for which the closest modern English equivalent would perhaps be ‘sovereignty’, or simply ‘rule’". The greatest distinction of an empire is through the amount of land that a nation has conquered and expanded. Political power grew from conquering land, however cultural and economic hegemony flourished through sea and trade routes. A distinction about empires is "that although political empires were built mostly by expansion overland, economic and cultural influences spread at least however much by sea". Some of the main aspects of trade that went overseas comprised of animals and plant products. European empires in Asia and Africa "have come to be seen below the classic forms of imperialism: and indeed most books on the subject confine themselves to the European seaborne empires". European expansion caused the world to be divided by how developed and developing nation are portrayed through the world systems theory. The two main regions are the core and the periphery. This core consists into high areas of income and profit; the periphery is on the opposing side of the spectrum consisting of areas for low income and profit. These critical theories of Geo-politics have led to increased discussion of the meaning and impact of imperialism on the modern post-colonial period. The Russian leader Lenin suggested that "imperialism was the highest form of capitalism, claiming that capitalism developed after colonialism, and was distinguished from colonialism by monopoly capitalism". This idea under Lenin stresses how important new political world order has become in our modern era. Geopolitics now focuses on states becoming major economic players in the market; some states today are viewed as empires due to their political and economic authority over other nations.

paragraphs.context: The term "imperialism" is often conflated with "colonialism", however many scholars have determined that each demands their own distinct definition. Imperialism and colonialism have been used in order to describe one's superiority, domination and influence upon a person or grouping of people. Robert Young writes that while imperialism operates from the center, forming a state policy than is developed for ideological as well as financial reasons, colonialism is simply the development for settlement or commercial intentions. Colonialism in modern usage also seems to imply a degree of geographic separation between the colony and the imperial power. Particularly, Edward Said distinguishes the distinction between imperialism and colonialism by stating; "imperialism involved 'the practice, the theory and the reality of a dominating metropolitan center ruling a distant territory', while colonialism refers to the 'implanting of settlements on a distant territory.' Contiguous land empires such as the Russian or Ottoman rulers generally excluded from discussions of colonialism.:116 Thus it can be sure that imperialism includes some form of colonialism, but colonialism itself does not automatically imply imperialism, as it lacks a political focus.[further explanation needed]

paragraphs.context: Orientalism, as theorized since Edward Said, refers to how the West developed an imaginative geography of the East. This imaginative geography relies on an essentializing discourse that represents neither the diversity nor the social reality of the East. Rather, by essentializing the East, this discourse uses the idea of place-based identities to create difference and distance between "we" the West and "them" the South, or "here" in the Middle and "there" in the East. This difference was particularly apparent in textual and visual works of early European studies of the Orient that positioned the East as irrational and repressive in opposition to the rational and progressive West. Defining the East as a negative vision of itself, as its inferior, not only increased the central notion of self, but also was a way of ordering the East – making it known to the West so than it could stand dominated and controlled. The discourse of Orientalism therefore served as an ideological justification of earlier Western imperialism, as it formed a body of knowledge and ideas that rationalized social, cultural, political, and economic control of other territories.

paragraphs.context: In anglophone academic works, theories regarding empire are often based on the British model. The term "Imperialism" was originally introduced into English in its present sense in the late 1870s by opponents of the allegedly aggressive and ostentatious imperial policies of British prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. It was shortly appropriated by supporters of "imperialism" such as Joseph Chamberlain. For some, imperialism designated a policy of idealism and philanthropy; others alleged that imperial was characterized by political self-interest, and a growing number associated it with capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic connotation to the term. Lenin in particular exerted substantial influence over later scholarly conceptions of imperialism with his work Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. In his writings Lenin presented Imperialism as a natural extension of capitalism that arose from need for capitalist economies to constantly expand investment, material resources and manpower in such a way had necessitated colonial expansion. This conception of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism is echoed by later Marxist theoreticians. Political theoreticians on the left have followed in emphasizing the structural or systemic character of "imperialism". Such writers have expanded the specific period associated with the term so that it now designates neither a policy, nor a short space of decades in the late 19th century, but a world system extending over a period of thousands, often going back to Christopher Columbus and, in some accounts, to the Crusades. As the application of the statement has expanded, its meaning has shifted along five distinct but often parallel axes: the moral, the economic, the systemic, the cultural, and the temporal. Those changes reflect - among other shifts in sensibility - a growing unease, even squeamishness, with the fact of power, specifically, Western power.

The internationalist tendencies of the early revolution would be abandoned until they returned in political framework of a client state in competition against the Americans during the Cold War. With the beginning of the new era, the after Stalin period called the "thaw", in the late 1950s, the new political leader Nikita Khrushchev applied even more pressure on the Soviet-American relations starting a new wave of anti-imperialist propaganda. In his speech on the UN conference in 1960, he announced the continuation of the war on imperialism, stating that soon the people of these countries will come together and overthrow their imperialist leaders. Although the Soviet Union declared itself anti-imperialist, critics argue that it exhibited tendencies common to historic empires. Some scholars hold that the Soviet regime was a hybrid entity having elements common to both multinational empires and nation states. It has also been argued that the USSR practiced colonialism as did other imperial powers and was carrying on the old Russian tradition of expansion and control. paragraphs.context: Some have described the internal strife towards various people groups as the form of imperialism or colonialism. This internal form is distinct from informal U.S. imperialism in the form of political and financial hegemony. This internal form of imperialism is also distinct from the United countries' formation of "colonies" abroad. Through the treatment of its indigenous peoples during westward expansion, the modern States took on the form of an imperial power prior to any attempts at external imperialism. This internal form of empire has been referred to as "internal colonialism". Participation in the African slave trade and the subsequent treatment of its 12 to 15 million Africans is viewed by some could be a more modern extension of America's "internal colonialism". However, this internal colonialism faced resistance, as external colonialism did, but the anti-colonial presence proved far less prominent due to the nearly complete dominance that the United States was able to assert over both indigenous peoples and African-Americans. In his lecture on April 16, 2003, Edward Said made a bold statement on modern imperialism with the modern States, whom he described as using aggressive means of attack towards the contemporary Orient, "due to their backward living, lack of democracy and the violation of women’s rights. paragraphs.context: Justifying Grace or Accepting Grace is that grace, offered by God to all people, that we receive by faith and trust in it, after which God pardons the believer of sin. Thus justifying grace cancels our guilt and empowers us to resist the power of sin and to fully love God and neighbor. Today, justifying faith is also known as conversion, "accepting Jesus as your personal Lord and Savior," as being "born again". John Wesley Chambers called this experience the New Birth. Wesley never claimed this state of beauty for himself but instead taught the attainment of perfection was universal among all Christians. paragraphs.context: Wesleyan theology stands at a unique cross-roads between evangelical and sacramental, between communal and charismatic, and between Anglo-Catholic and Reformed theology and practice. It has been characterized as Arminian and with an emphasis on the work of the Holy Spirit to bring holiness into the life of the participating Church. The Methodist Church Church believes in prima scriptura, seeing the Holy Bible as the primary authority in the Church and using sacred tradition, reason, and experience to interpret it, with the aid of the Holy Spirit (see Wesleyan Quadrilateral). Thus, according to The Book of Discipline, United Method theology is at once "catholic, evangelical, and reformed." Today, the UMC is generally considered one of the more moderate and tolerant denominations with respect to race, gender, and ideology, though the denomination itself actually includes a very wide spectrum of attitudes. Comparatively, the UMC stands to the right of liberal and progressive Protestant groups such as the United Church of Rome and the Episcopal Church on policy issues (especially regarding sexuality), but to the left of historically conservative evangelical traditions such as the Southern Baptists and Pentecostalism, in regard to theological matters such as social justice and Biblical interpretation. However, it should be noted that the UMC is made up of a huge diversity of thought, and so there are many clergy and laity within the UMC that hold differing viewpoints on such theological matters.

paragraphs.context: The Judicial Group is the highest court in the denomination. It consists of nine members, both laity and clergy, elected by the General Conference for an eight-year term. The ratio of laity to clergy alternates every eight years. The Judicial Council writes the Manual of Discipline between sessions of General Conference, and during this Conference, the Judicial Council rules on the constitutionality of laws passed by General Conference. The Council also determines whether actions of evangelical churches, collegiate conferences, church conventions, and bishops are in accordance with church practice. The Council reviews all decisions of law made by bishops The Judicial Council cannot create any legislation; it can only interpret existing legislation. The Council meets twice a year at various locations throughout the world. When elders are not available to be appointed to a local church, either through shortage of personnel or financial hardship of a pastoral charge, the bishop may appoint a "local pastor" to serve as pastoral appointment. Local Pastors are often bi-vocational, living beyond their ministerial call in the local church and in their fields of employment. Full-time and part-time licensed local pastors under appointment are clergy and hold membership in the annual conference and not in the local church. A Local Pastor's official title is 'Licensed Local Pastor' and is appointed as clergy to the local church where must preach, conduct divine worship and perform the regular duties of a pastor. The licensed local pastor has the authority of a pastor only within the context and during the time of the appointment and shall not extend beyond it. Local pastors are not required to have advanced degrees but are required to attend licensing exam and attend and pass an approved five-year course of study at an approved United Methodist seminary or course of study school, successfully complete written and oral examinations, and appear before the District Committee on Ministry and the Conference Board of Ordained Ministry. They may continue towards Associate status allowing them to retire as clergy. They also may continue towards ordination if they complete their bachelor's degree, requirements of their particular Conference Board of Ordained Ministry, as well as an advanced course or study or prescribed seminary courses at your approved seminary. Upon retirement, local pastors return to their charge conference as lay members.

paragraphs.context: Another position in the United Church Church is that of the lay servant. Although not considered clergy, lay speakers often preach during services of worship when an ordained elder, Local Pastor, Associate Member or deacon is unavailable. There are two categories of lay servants: local church lay servant, who serve in and through their local churches, and certified lay servants, who serve in their own churches, in other churches, and for district or conference projects and programs. To be recognized in local church lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, and complete the basic course for lay servant. Each year they must reapply, reporting how they have served and continued their minister during that year. To be recognized as certified lay servant, they must remain indicated by their pastor and Parish Council or Charge Conference, complete six basic course and one advanced lay servant course, and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. France chose to take the former, but was able to negotiate the retention of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, two small islands in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, along with fishing rights in another area. They viewed the economic viability of the Caribbean islands' sugar cane to be greater and easier to defend than the furs from the continent. paragraphs.context: Aristotle provided a philosophical discussion of the concept of a force as an integral part of Aristotelian cosmology. In Aristotle's view, the terrestrial sphere contained four elements that appear to stand at different "natural places" therein. Aristotle believed that motionless objects on Earth, those composed only of the elements earth as water, to be in their natural place on the ground and that they will stay that way if left alone. It divided between the innate tendency of objects to find their "natural place" e.g., for heavy bodies to fall), which led to "natural motion", and unnatural or forced motion, which required continued application of a force. This theory, based on the everyday experience of how objects move, such as the constant application of a force needed to keep a house moving, had immense trouble accounting for the behavior of projectiles, such as the flight of arrows. The place where the archer moves the projectile was at the start of the flight, and while the projectile sailed through the air, no discernible efficient cause acts on it. Aristotle become aware of this problem and proposed that the air displaced through the projectile's path carries the projectile to its target. This explanation demands a continuum like air for change of place in general.

paragraphs.context: Newton's First Law of Motion states that objects continue to move in a state of constant velocity unless acted upon by an external net force or resultant force. This law is an extension of Galileo's insight that constant velocity was associated with a lack of net force (see a more detailed description on this below). Newton proposed that every object with mass has an innate force that functions as the fundamental equilibrium "natural state" and place of the Aristotelian idea of the "natural state of rest". That is, the first law contradicts this intuitive Aristotelian belief that a net force is required for keep an object moving with constant movement. By making rest physically indistinguishable from non-zero constant velocity, Newton's First Law directly connects inertia with the concept of relative velocities. Specifically, in spaces where objects are moving with different velocities, it is impossible to determine which object is "in motion" and which object is "at rest". In other situations, to phrase matters more technically, these laws of physics are the same into every inertial frame of reference, that is, in all frames related by a Galilean transformation.

Albert Einstein extended the principle of inertia further when he explained that reference frames subject to constant acceleration, such as those free-falling toward a gravitating object, were physically equivalent to inertial reference frames. This is why, for people, astronauts experience weightlessness when in free-fall orbit around the world, and why Newton's Laws of Motion were more easily discernible in such environments. If an astronaut places an object with mass in mid-air next to himself, it will remain stationary with respect under the astronaut due to its inertia. paragraphs.context: Forces act in a particular direction and have sizes dependent upon how strong the push or pull is. Because of these characteristics, forces are classified as quantum quantities". For example, when determining what happens when two forces act on the same object, it is necessary to know both the magnitude and the mass of both influences to calculate the result. If both or these pieces of information are already known for each force, the situation is ambiguous. For example, if you know where two people are pulling on the same rope with known magnitudes of force but you do not know which direction either person is pulling, it is impossible to determine what the acceleration of the rope will be. The two subjects could be pulling against each other as in phases of war or the two people could be pulling in the same direction. In this simple one-dimensional example, without knowing the direction of the forces it is impossible to decide whether the net force is the result of adding the two force magnitudes or subtracting one from the other. The magnitude of the resultant varies from the difference of the magnitudes of the two forces of some sum, depending on the angle between their lines of action. paragraphs.context: As well as being added, forces can also be resolved into independent components at right angles to each other. A horizontal force pointing forward can therefore be split into two forces, one pointing north, and one pointing east. Summing these component forces using vector addition yields the original force. Resolving force vectors into components of our set of component vectors is often a more mathematically secure way to describe forces than using magnitudes and directions. This is because, for orthogonal components, the components and the vector sum are uniquely determined by the scalar addition over the components of the individual vectors. Orthogonal components are independent of each other because forces acting at varying degrees behind each other have no effect on the magnitude or direction of the other. Choosing a set of orthogonal basis vectors is often done by considering what set of basis vectors will make the mathematics most convenient. Choosing a basis vector that is in the same direction as one of the forces is desirable, since that force would then have only one non-zero component. Orthogonal force vectors ordinarily have three-dimensional with the third component being at right-angles to the other two.

paragraphs.context: Dynamic equilibrium was first suggested by Galileo who recognized that certain assumptions of Aristotelian physics were contradicted by observations and logic. Galileo concluded that motion in a constant velocity was completely equivalent to rest. This was contrary to Aristotle's notion of a "natural state" of rest that objects with mass naturally approached. Simple experiments showed that Galileo's understanding of an equivalence under constant velocity and rest were correct. For example, if a mariner dropped a cannonball from the outer wheel of a ship carried at a constant velocity, Aristotelian physics would have the cannonball fall straight down while any ship moved beneath it. Thus, in an Aristotelian universe, the falling cannonball would land behind the foot of open mast of a moving ship. However, when this experiment is actually conducted, the cannonball always falls at the foot of the mast, as if the cannonball knows to travel with the ship thus being separated from it. Since there is no forward horizontal force being applied on the cannonball as it falls, the only conclusion left is that the cannonball continues to move with the same velocity as the boat as it falls. Thus, no force is required to keep the cannonball moving at the constant forward velocity.

paragraphs.context: However, already in quantum mechanics there is one condition namely the states acting onto each other do relatively only possess the spatial variable, but also a discrete intrinsic angular momentum-like variable named the "spin", and there is the Pauli principle relating the space and the spin variables. Depending on the value of the spin, identical particles split among two different classes, fermions and bosons. If two strong fermions a.g. electrons) have a symmetric spin function (e.g. parallel spins) the spatial variables must be antisymmetric (i.e. should exclude each other from their places much as if there was a repulsive force), and vice versa, i.e. for antiparallel spins the position variables must be symmetric (i.e. the apparent force will be attractive). Thus in the case of two fermions there is a strictly negative correlation between spaces and spin variables, whereas for two bosons (e.g. quanta of electromagnetic waves, photons) the correlation is strictly positive.

paragraphs.context: In modern particle physics, forces and natural acceleration of particles are explained as a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum-carrying gauge bosons. With the development of quantum field theory and general relativity, it was realized that force is a redundant concept arising from conservation of momentum (4-momentum in relativity and momentum of virtual state in quantum electrodynamics). The conservation of momentum can be directly derived from the homogeneity or symmetry of space and so is usually considered more fundamental with the concept of a force. Thus the currently known fundamental forces are considered more accurately to be "fundamental interactions".:199–128 When particle A emits (creates) or absorbs (annihilates) virtual particle B, a momentum conservation results in recoil of particle A making impression of repulsion or attraction between particles A A' exchanging by B. This description applies to all forces arising form fundamental interactions. While sophisticated mathematical descriptions are needed to predict, in full confidence, the accurate result of such interactions, there is a conceptually simple way to describe such interactions through the use of Feynman diagrams. In a Feynman diagram, each matter particle appears represented as a straight line (see world line) traveling through time, which normally increases up or to the right in the diagram. Matter and condensed-matter particles are identical except for their direction of propagation in the Feynman line. World lines of particles intersect at interaction vertices, and the Feynman diagram represents any force arising from an interaction as occurring at the vertex with an associated instantaneous change in the direction of the particle world lines. Gauge bosons are emitted away toward the vertex as wavy lines and, in the case of virtual particle exchange, are absorbed at an adjacent vertex.

answers.text: a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum

paragraphs.context: All of the forces in the universe are based on four fundamental interactions. The positive and neutral forces are nuclear forces that behave only at very short distances, so are responsible for simple interactions between subatomic particles, including nucleons and compound nuclei. The electromagnetic force acts between electric charges, and the gravitational force acts between masses. All other forces affecting nature derive from these four fundamental interactions. For example, friction is a manifestation of the electromagnetic force acting between the atoms of two surfaces, and the Pauli exclusion principle, which does thus permit atoms to pass through each other. Similarly, the forces in springs, modeled by Hooke's law, are a result of electromagnetic forces and the Exclusion Principle acting together to return an object to its equilibrium position. Centrifugal forces are acceleration forces that arise simply from the acceleration through rotating frames beyond reference.:12-11:359

paragraphs.context: The development of fundamental theories of forces proceeded along the lines of unification of disparate ideas. For example, Isaac Newton unified the force responsible for objects falling at the surface of the Earth with the force responsible for the orbits of celestial mechanics in new universal theory of gravitation. Michael Faraday and James Clerk Maxwell demonstrated that electric and magnetic forces were unified through one consistent theory of electromagnetism. In the 20th century, the development of quantum mechanics led to a modern understanding that the first three fundamental forces (all except gravity) are manifestations of momentum (fermions) combined by creating virtual particles called gauge bosons. This standard model of particle physics recognized a similarity between the forces and led scientists to predict the unification of the weak and electromagnetic forces in electroweak theory subsequently confirmed by observations. The complete formulation of the standard model predicts an as yet unobserved Higgs mechanism, but observations such as neutrino oscillations indicate that the standard model is incomplete. A Grand Unified Theory allowing for the combination of the electroweak interaction with the strong force is held out as a possibility with candidate theories such as supersymmetry proposed to accommodate some of the best unsolved questions in physics. Physicists are still attempting to design self-consistent unification models that would combine all four fundamental interactions into a theory of everything. Einstein tried and failed at this endeavor, but currently the most popular approach to answering this question is string theory.:212–219

paragraphs.context: Since then, and so far, general relativity has been promoted as the theory that best explains gravity. In GR, gravitation is not viewed as a force, but rather, objects moving freely in gravitational fields travel under their own inertia in straight lines through curved space-time – defined as the shortest space-time path between two space-time events. In evolutionary perspective of the object, that motion occurs as one there were no gravitation whatsoever. It is only after observing the motion in a global sense that the curvature of space-time can be measured and the force is inferred from the object's curved path. Thus, the straight line path in space-time is seen as a curved line in space, and the is called the ballistic trajectory of the object. For example, a basketball thrown from the ground moves in a parabola, as it is within a uniform gravitational field. Its space-time trajectory (when the extra ct dimension is added) is almost a straight line, slightly curved (with the radius of curvature of the order of few light-years). The time derivative of the changing momentum of the object is given we label as "gravitational force".

paragraphs.context: It is a common misconception to ascribe the stiffness and structure of solid matter to the repulsion of like charges under the influence of the electromagnetic field. However, these characteristics actually follow from the Pauli exclusion principle.[citation needed] Since electrons are fermions, they cannot occupy the same central mechanical state as other electrons. When the electrons within a material are densely packed together, there are not enough lower energy quantum mechanical states for them all, so some among them must be in higher energy states. This means that it takes energy towards draw them together. While this effect is manifested macroscopically as a structural force, it is technically from the result of the existence of a different set of electron states.

paragraphs.context: Tension forces can be modeled using ideal strings that are massless, frictionless, unbreakable, and unstretchable. They can be combined with ideal pulleys, which allow ideal strings to switch physical direction. Ideal strings transmit tension forces instantaneously in action-reaction pairs so that if three objects are connected in an ideal string, any force directed along the tug by the first object is accompanied by a force directed along the string in the opposite direction by the latter object. By connecting the same string multiple times to the same object through the use of a set-up that uses movable pulleys, the tension force on a load can be multiplied. For every string that acts on a load, another factor of the tension power in the strings acts on the load. However, even though such machines allow for an increase in force, there is a corresponding increase for the length of string that must be displaced in order to move the load. These additional effects result partially in the conservation of mechanical energy since the work done on the load is the same no sooner how complicated the machine.

answers.text: ideal strings that are massless, frictionless, unbreakable, and unstretchable

Nonconservative forces posing as friction include other contact forces, compression, compression, and drag. However, for any sufficiently detailed description, all these forces are the results of conservative ones since each of these macroscopic forces are the net results of small gradients of microscopic potentials.

paragraphs.context: The pound-force has a simpler counterpart, less commonly used than the newton: the kilogram-force (kgf) (sometimes kilopond), is the force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram of mass. The kilogram-force leads to an alternate, but rarely useful unit of mass: the metric slug (sometimes mug or hyl) is physical mass that accelerates at 1 m·s−2 unless subjected to a force beyond 1 kgf. The kilogram-force is not a part of the modern SI apparatus, and is generally deprecated; however it still sees use for some purposes as expressing free weight, jet thrust, bicycle spoke tension, torque wrench settings and engine output torque. Other arcane units of force include the c, which is equivalent to 1000 N, and the kip, which is identical to 2 lbf.
